A cakravartin is said to possess ‘seven jewels’ (saptaratna). They are: cakra, chariot, jewel, queen, wealth, horse and elephant. Here ‘cakra’ may mean the auspicious sign of the Sudarśanacakra of Lord Viṣṇu on his hand.
In Jainism, the word is used as an epithet for a group of twelve great souls like Bharata and Brahmadatta. They were emperors in the spiritual field.
See AKṢIMOCANA.
Keeping the religious vows either for getting a desired fruit or for getting rid of some difficulties, is common to all religions. Such vows in Hinduism are called ‘vratas’.

‘Cakṣurvrata,’ also called ‘netravrata,’ is performed on the second day of the bright half of the month Caitra (March-April). The performer has to worship the Aśvins (twin deities, said to be the physicians of gods identified with the sun and the moon) and has to subsist only on curds and ghee. It can be done only once or repeated for twelve years. The performer is assured of a good eyesight. If the vow is kept up for twelve years, he will become a king.
Eye is the most important of all the sense organs. The sun is described by the Vedas as the eye of all that exists.

According to the Upaniṣads the power to see that exists in the eye, and the power of light capable of revealing objects, that exists in the sun, are both essentially the same; and, Āditya is the deity that presides over both. When a human being dies, his ‘eye’ (the power to see) gets merged in the Āditya.

Belief in the evil influence of the eyes of some people (dṛṣṭidoṣa) is common to India as to many other countries. It is said to cause death, illness, injury, poverty and other evil effects. Children and animals are said to be more vulnerable to it. Hence the use of amulets, countercharms and protective gestures has been resorted to over the years. According to the Atharvaveda, an amulet of the ‘jiṅgiḍa’ plant gives such protection. The same Veda (2.7.5) contains a hymn called ‘Cakṣurmantra’ directed against curses and those who curse, the invoker requesting for the possessor of the ‘evil eye’ to be harmed (so that he will not harm others).
Cakṣu is the name of one of the seven branches of the river Gaṅgā after it descended on earth and got divided. It is generally identified with the river Oxus or Amu Darya in central Asia.
The desire to acquire and to use supernatural powers is a natural trait of human beings. It has given rise to a whole range of occult sciences.

One of the powers that is most fascinating and sought after is the clairvoyant power, the power to see at will anything that is taking place anywhere in the world. This is called ‘cākṣuṣī’ in the ancient Sanskrit works. The Mahābhārata (1.186) refers to it in the episode of Arjuna and a Gandharva hero Citraratha. Arjuna taught him about the fire missile (āgneyāstra) and learnt the cākṣuṣīvidyā from him.

Śivaliṅgas or emblems of Śiva, the third deity of the Hindu Trinity, are of two types: acalaliṅgas and calaliṅgas. The former are immovable or fixed, whereas the latter are movable or portable. Stone liṅgas fixed in temples belong to the former category.

The calaliṅgas are of various types: mṛṇmaya (made of earth or clay), lohaja (prepared out of metal), ratnaja (shaped out of precious stones), dāruja (carved out of wood), śailaja (made of stone) and kṣaṇika-liṅgas (those prepared temporarily for the occasion and disposed off, like the ones made out of riverside clay or cooked rice).

White clay gathered from pure places such as hilltops or river-beds is recommended for mṛṇmayaliṅgas. The lohaja liṅgas are generally cast from metals like gold, silver or copper. The ratnaja variety is shaped out of precious stones like pearls, coral, topaz or emerald. The timber of trees like śamī (Prosposis spicegera), madhuka (Bassis latifolia), arjuna (Termi-nalia arjuna) pippala (Ficus religiosa) or udumbara (Ficus glomerata) is recommended for dāruliṅgas. The śailaja or stone liṅgas are generally worn on the body by the followers of Śaiva cults like the liṅgāyats. The kṣaṇika liṅgas are shaped out of riverside sand or clay, uncooked or cooked rice, cowdung, butter, sandal paste, flour or jaggery. They are made for the occasion and then disposed off, soon after the worship is over.
Worship of different kinds of liṅgas confers different results. For instance, that of gold liṅga gives wealth; that of cooked rice, plenty of food; that of cowdung, freedom from diseases.
Baked clay liṅgas are used for ābhicārika purposes, i.e., for harming others through black magic.
See also ACALALIṄGA, ŚIVA and ŚIVALIṄGA.
See UTSAVAMŪRTI.
See PAÑCĀṄGA.

‘Camarī-mṛga’ is the animal yak normally found in Tibet. A long chowrie prepared from the hairs on the bushy tail of the yak was commonly used by the attendants of a king as a sort of a fan, to ward off flies and insects. However, in course of time, it became a part of the royal insignia, along with the chatra or umbrella. It is used in the ceremonial worship of a deity also, at the time of ārati or vespers.
Cāmara, according to the Devī-māhātmya section of the Mārkaṇḍeya Purāṇa, was one of the generals of the demon king Mahiṣāsura, who was slain by Durgā.

Out of the several implements used in a Vedic sacrifice, ‘camasa’ is an important one. It is a kind of cup, with or without a handle, usually square in shape and made of the nyagrodha wood (Ficus indica). The handle could be round, square or even triangular.
It is generally used for containing the Soma juice for libation, for drinking the same by priests, and for bringing the ‘praṇītā’ waters for making dough for the caru in a sacrifice. (See PRAṆĪTĀ.)
Out of the sixteen priests involved in a sacrifice, only ten are entitled to have camasa and they are called ‘camasins’.
The Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad (2.2.3) compares the human head to a camasa, kept inverted.

Campā, variously known as Campā-purī, Campakāvatī, Campānagara and so on, was the capital of the once well-known Aṅgadeśa. Romapāda, father of Śāntā and father-in-law of the famous sage Ṛṣya-śṛṅga, was the king here in very ancient times. Rāmāyaṇa mentions it. During the times of the Mahābhārata Karṇa was ruling from here.
It has been identified with Nathnagar near Bhagalpur in Bihar.
Some scholars opine that the famous Buddhist work, the Laṅkāvatāra-sūtra was composed here probably in the 4th century A.D.
Campā is said to be the birthplace of Vāsupūjya, the twelfth Tīrthaṅkara and also associated with the last, Mahāvīra.

Hindu religion, culture and way of life had spread beyond the borders of India even from the ancient days. There are archaeological, epigraphical and other evidences to prove its existence in the South East Asian countries from the 1st century A.D. The kingdom of Campā—the South Annam region of Vietnam—is a country of this group.
One Śrīmāra established a Hindu dynasty there in A. D. 192. The kingdom itself—though the rulers changed now and then—continued till A. D. 1471 when it was annexed by the kings of Annam.

Among the several distinguished rulers of Campā, the names of Bhadravarma, Rudravarma, Harivarma, Mahendra-varma, Jayasiṁhavarma and Jaya Indra-varma may be mentioned. They were all Hindu rulers and had adopted Hindu ways of administration. Most of them were well-versed in Sanskrit and Hindu sciences, both religious and secular. Hence they had adopted Sanskrit as the State language.

In the social fabric, the varṇa-āśrama system had been deeply rooted. The various saṁskāras (religio-social sacraments) like marriage, were being done by the priests according to the Hindu dharma-śāstras.

Though Śaivism had been patronized by the State, Vaiṣṇavism and Buddhism also flourished. Several Hindu temples including innumerable images of Śiva as also liṅgas, have been discovered. However, these temples are smaller in size and are built mostly in brick. In architectural style they resemble the ‘rathas’ of Mahābalipuram or the temples of Bādāmi in Karnataka.

Mother worship and Mother cult are not alien to Vedic religion as some suggest. The concept of Aditi (mother of gods and a personification of nature) as also the Ambhṛṇīsūkta and the Rātrisūkta of the Ṛgveda clearly contain the origins of the worship of God as Śakti or the Divine Mother.

One of the early basic texts of the Śakti cult is the Devīmāhātmya also called Durgāsaptaśatī or Caṇḍī. According to this, Kālī, one of the aspects of Durgā that emanated from her forehead, killed the two demons Caṇḍa and Muṇḍa, gene-rals of the demon king Śumbha, and got this name. She is described as a fierce goddess, black in colour, emaciated and wearing the cheetah skin as also severed human heads. Her mouth and tongue were of immense proportions. She could kill troups of demons at one stroke and could swallow several elephants in a gulp.
Cāmuṇḍā is sometimes included in the list of ‘Saptamātṛkās’ or ‘Seven Mothers’, in the place of Nārasiṁhī.
She actually symbolizes the power of time in its all-destroying aspect.
The word is also spelt as Cāmuṇḍī.
See also DURGĀ, KĀLĪ and SAPTA-MĀTṚKĀS.
See ARTHAŚĀSTRA.

From the Vedic days certain groups of people used to be kept outside the pale of civilized society. ‘Aspṛśyas’ or ‘untouchables’ was the general name given to most of them since any kind of contact or proximity with them was considered polluting. This was mostly due to their horrendous ways of living and avocations fraught with potential dangers to the general health of the society.

The cāṇḍālas—also spelt as ‘caṇḍālas’—are an important group of aspṛśyas. Manu defines the cāṇḍāla as one born from a brāhmaṇa woman by a śūdra father (vide Manusmṛti 10.12). Other smṛtis define the word in other ways.

The cāṇḍālas were expected to live in their own colonies outside the village or town. But they were given to roaming. Their wealth was dogs and donkeys. They lived by cleaning the dirt of the village or town. They ate the carcasses of dead animals and carried corpses of persons who had no relatives, as also looked after the cremation or burial grounds. They acted as executioners of people sentenced to death by the king. They wore ornaments of lead, iron or leather.
The cāṇḍālas were perhaps the conquered aboriginal tribes, dropouts from the society who never cared to follow its norms, abominable sinners and those following dreadful occupations.
See also ASPṚŚYATĀ.
Candana is sandalwood (Santalum album) well-known for its fragrance and medicinal properties. Indians knew its use even from very ancient days.

It grows mostly in the Malayagiri (Western Ghats). Three varieties—white, yellow and red—are known to exist. Because of its fragrance and cooling properties it is used as an item of luxury and also for its curative effects. Its paste is one of the most important items offered to a deity in ritualistic worship and is called ‘gandha’. In some temples, on certain special days, the image of the deity is decorated entirely with sandal paste.
He is one of the attendant deities of Śiva. According to the mythological lore he was a brāhmaṇa boy, Vicāraśarman by name, who rose to that status by his intense devotion to Śiva.

Iconographically, he is shown as a fierce deity, holding weapons of war and destruction like the bow, arrow, trident, chisel, noose and so on. Though independent shrines dedicated to him are not uncommon, he is generally installed in every Śiva temple in the north eastern corner, facing south. Devotees believe that he can act as a mediator interceding with the Lord on their behalf. Hence supplication before him is a duty of every devotee visiting a Śiva temple.
He is also known as Caṇḍi and Caṇḍeśa.

Caṇḍeśvara (14th cent. A.D.) of Mithilā is a very important compiler of digests on dharmaśāstras. He was a minister as well as the chief justice at the court of the king Harisiṁhadeva of Tirhut (now in Bihar). He belonged to the Karṇāta family. Smṛtiratnākara or Ratnā-kara is the extensive digest compiled by him. Divided into seven sections—each containing the word ‘ratnākara’ as part of the title—it deals with kṛtya (what ought to be done), dāna (gifts), vyavahāra (judicial procedure), śuddhi (purificatory rites), pūjā (ritualistic worship), vivāda (disputes—civil and criminal laws) and gṛhastha (duties of householders). Kṛtyacintā-maṇi and Rājanītiratnākara are his other works considered important.
Later writers on dharmaśāstras from Mithilā and Vaṅga (Bengal) have been greatly influenced by him.
Caṇḍī is one of the names of the goddess Durgā. The book expounding her exploits is also called ‘Caṇḍī’. For details see DEVĪMĀHĀTMYA.
Throughout the history of India, religious lyrics have proved to be immen-sely popular with the masses. They have often shaped their philosophy of life too.

During the middle ages, when the cult of Kṛṣṇa-bhakti was gradually gaining ground, the compositions of Caṇḍīdāsa (in the Middle Bengali language) became very popular. ‘Baḍu’ Caṇḍīdāsa, as he was best known, preceded Śrīkṛṣṇa Caitanya (A. D. 1486-1534) and is assigned to the 15th cent. A. D. He belonged to Chātna and was a member of the Vaiṣṇava Sahajīya cult. His Śrīkṛṣṇakīrtana is a remarkable poem on the Kṛṣṇa legend in that language. It consists of a chain of lyric songs depicting the principal amorous episodes of Kṛṣṇa and Rādhā. Though the tone of the poem is entirely secular often bordering on crude-ness, the style and diction are considered as agreeable.
There are reasons to believe that there were more Caṇḍīdāsas than one, with epithets such as Dīna, Dvija and Anantabaḍu. But it is difficult to come to any definite conclusions.

It is a religious vow undertaken on the 8th and 9th days of each fortnight (both dark and bright) when the goddess Caṇḍikā is to be worshipped. Fasting is a necessary discipline. The vrata is spread over one year. It helps the worshipper to get Mother Caṇḍikā’s grace and fulfil his desires.

Recitation of stotras or hymns has long been accepted as a part of the Hindu religious discipline. Its immense popularity can be gauged from the fact that the Hindu hymnal literature extant today is as vast as the sky and as deep as the ocean.

Some of these hymns like the Viṣṇu-sahasranāma, the Durgāsaptaśatī (also known as Devīmāhātmya and Caṇḍī) and the Lalitāsahasranāma have acquired an esoteric significance, so much so, that they are considered as ‘mantras’ or mystic formulae. Consequently, ceremonial recitals of these texts have also been prescribed, often for the fulfilment of specific desires.

The Caṇḍī or Durgāsaptaśatī is a basic text of the Śākta cult or the cult of the Divine Mother. Its ceremonial recital is called Caṇḍīpāṭha. The recital can be done on any day or days, but the 8th, 9th and the 14th days of the dark lunar fortnight have been specially recommended.

Since the ceremonial recital is equi-valent to worship, many preliminary disciplines that apply to the latter, apply to the former also. For instance: ācamana (ceremonial sipping of water), prāṇāyāma (regulation of breath), saṅkalpa (religious resolve), dīpasthāpana (establishing a lighted lamp as a witness) and so on. A regular worship has to be offered to the book that is used for the recital. The recital itself should be done audibly and clearly since that is believed to create a wonderful atmosphere, in which the deity presents herself. The main text is preceded by certain hymns like the Kavaca and followed by others like the Rahasyatraya. A regular homa or havan is to be done after the chanting is completed.

Normally one is expected to chant all the thirteen chapters—which are divided into three books called Caritras—together at one sitting. If this is not possible, alternative modes have also been recommended. Details can be learnt from standard works on the subject or from the adepts in the field.

Recitation by others—competent brāhmaṇas—may also be arranged, the benefit accruing to the person who arranges it. Recital of the Caṇḍī a hundred times (Śatacaṇḍī) or a thousand times (Sahasracaṇḍī) are done this way and are invariably for the good of the entire community or society or country.
The recital of the Caṇḍī is said to confer innumerable fruits, from the lowest secular ones to the highest spiritual enlightenment.
See also DEVĪMĀHĀTMYA.

The deity who presides over the moon is called ‘Soma,’ ‘Indu’ or ‘Candra’. The entire ninth maṇḍala of the Ṛgveda is devoted to his praise. He is the presiding deity of the soma creeper, the juice of which is often used in sacrifices as oblation and also partaken by the participants. Sometimes identified with the Supreme God, he is said to cure the mortals of their diseases and lead them to immortal blissful worlds. He rules over the mind and activates our speech. Hence he is sometimes called ‘Vācaspati’ or the ‘Lord of speech’.
The Puruṣasūkta of the Ṛgveda declares that Candra was born out of the mind of the Supreme Being.

In the mythological literature, his birth is described variously as the embodiment of the brilliant light that emerged from the eyes of the sage Atri, as the son of Dharma-prajāpati or as rising out of the ocean of milk when it was being churned. Śiva wore him as his diadem. The 27 constellations of stars like Rohiṇī are described as his wives. His waxing and waning are due to a curse he got from his father-in-law, Dakṣa. His eclipse is due to his being swallowed by the demon Rāhu. He has special power over the vegetation on this earth. He is full of amṛta or nectar. That is why the gods drink him. He is replenished by the offerings in the sacrifices. He is the originator of the Candravaṁśa or the Lunar dynasty of which Śrī Kṛṣṇa was the last member.
Works on Hindu Astrology consider him as one of the Navagrahas or nine planets, with a beneficial influence.
Iconographically, he is represented with a face and two hands holding lotuses, sitting in a chariot of two or three wheels and drawn by ten horses.

In the works on Yoga and tantras, Candra is described as the ‘moon of mystery,’ full of nectar, existing just below the middle of the sahasrāra. By contemplating on him the yogi becomes fit to be adored by the world.
Connection between the phases of the moon and the condition of mental patients has long been recognized by the Hindu works on health and sickness.

Once there was a dispute about Candra (moon) between Śiva who had worn him as his diadem and the nakṣatras (constellations) who were his wives. Brahmā mediated, divided Candra into two halves and distributed them to the disputants. The place in the Himālayas where this was done came to be known as ‘Candrabhāgā.’ A river arose at that spot and it was also christened ‘Candra-bhāgā.’ This is the story given in the Mahābhārata.

Actually the river rises in the Himālayas in two streams, one being called Candrā and the other, Bhāgā. The two join at Taṇḍi and the united stream is known as Candrabhāgā. It is identified with the river Chenab now in Pakistan. It is called ‘Asiknī’ in the Ṛgveda.
Sāmba, the son of Śrī Kṛṣṇa, is said to have built a temple for Sūrya (sun) at the spot where it joins the river Sindhū (Indus).
There is another small river of the same name in Orissa. At the place where it joins the bay of Bengal, the famous Sūrya temple of Koṇārka (Konarak) has been built.
The river Bhīmā, a tributary of the Kṛṣṇā, in Maharashtra is also known as Candrabhāgā. The celebrated Viṭhoba temple is situated very near this river.
See GRAHAṆA.
Hindu itihāsas and purāṇas contain lots of historical material. Two dynasties, the Sūryavaṁśa and the Candravaṁśa (Solar and Lunar dynasties) have often been mentioned in these works.

Candravaṁśa starts with Candra-Soma. His son was Budha from Iḷā, and was better known as Purūrava Aila. He became so famous and important that the Lunar dynasty is often stated to have commenced from him. He ruled from Pratiṣṭhāna (now a village Pihan by name, near Allahabad in Uttar Pradesh). Nahuṣa, Yayāti and Pūru are the other celebrated rulers in this dynasty. The dynasty branched off with Yadu, the eldest son of Yayāti, into the Yādava dynasty, of which Balarāma and Śrī Kṛṣṇa were the most famous descendants.
Pūru’s descendants came to be known as Pauravas. The Kauravas and the Pāṇḍavas belonged to this line.
Ānavas and Haihayas were the other branches of the lunar race.

The dharmaśāstras have described several kinds of prāyaścittas or expiations for sins of omission and commission. Cāndrāyaṇa is a universal expiation prescribed for almost any sin, especially where no other specific remedy has been suggested.

The name is derived from the fact that in this expiation, the eating pattern follows the phases of the moon. Starting with 15 morsels of food (per day) on the full-moon, the same is gradually reduced by one morsel every day, ending in total fasting on the new-moon day. It is again increased, now from 1 to 15 morsels, till the full-moon day. This is one cycle. It can be repeated as many times as desired or needed. Since the quantity of food is full in the beginning and end, becoming nil at the middle, it is called ‘pipīlikāmadhya’ or ‘middle of an ant.’

If on the other hand, it is started with one morsel on the first day after the new-moon, increasing to 15 morsels on the full-moon and again reducing to nil on the new-moon, it is called ‘yavamadhya’ or ‘middle of the wheat grain.’ The similes are self-explanatory. Size of the morsel is that of a big myrobalan fruit.
Prescribing 8 morsels of food per day and keeping the month as a unit period, other varieties of cāndrāyaṇa as yati-cāndrāyaṇa have been derived by permutations of the morsels.
Tonsure of hair, initial fasting, offering libations of water and clarified butter, consecrating the sacrificial food and worship of moon—these are common disciplines for all the candrāyaṇas.
See also ARDHAKṚCCHRA, KṚCCHRA and PRĀYAŚCITTA.

The word ‘candrikā’ which literally means moonlight, has often been used in a figurative sense to any literary work that throws a ‘cool light’ on any subject. Two such works that are comparatively more well-known are the Candrikā of Jñānottama and the Candrikā of Vyāsatīrtha.

The former is a commentary on the Naiṣkarmya Siddhi of Sureśvara (8th cent. A.D.), a disciple of Śaṅkara, by one Jñānottama, who was probably a pontiff of the Advaita-maṭha at Kāñcīpuram, and lived around A.D. 1300.

The latter is actually an abbreviation for Tātparyacandrikā, a commentary by Vyāsatīrtha (A.D. 1447-1539) on the Tattva-prakāśikā of Jayatīrtha (14th cent. A.D.), this again being a commentary on Madhvācārya’s (A. D. 1238-1317) Brahma-sūtra-bhāṣya.

Cāṅgadeva was a saint from Maha-rashtra who was a contemporary of the famous Sant Jñāneśvar (13th cent. A.D.). He was a haṭhayogi with several miraculous powers and a host of disciples. Having heard of the great fame of Sant Jñāneśvar he wanted to humiliate him by making a show of his power. He once flew through the air riding on a fierce tiger. Jñāneśvar who was then sitting on a mud wall, along with his brother Sopāna and sister Muktā-bāī, commanded the wall to fly and it did, carrying them all, much to the chagrin of the haṭhayogi! Cāṅgadeva surrendered. At the instance of Jñāneśvar, his younger sister Muktābāī initiated Cāṅgadeva into the mysteries of Jñānayoga. He became one of their most devoted disciples and has composed quite a few abhaṅgas in which he has described some of his mystic experiences got by their grace.

There is another Cāṅgadeva who was a grandson of the great mathematician Bhāskarācārya (A. D. 1114-1160). He was the chief astrologer under Siṅghana (a Yādava king) and founded a college for the study of Siddhānta-śiromaṇi, Bhāskara’s magnum opus.
See also ABHAṄGAS.
See KANYĀKUMĀRĪ.
The word is used to indicate a spy as well as the saṁnyāsin both of whom are given to much movement.
As regards Caraka, the great teacher of Āyurveda, see CARAKASAṀHITĀ.

Caraka and Suśruta are the two brightest stars in the firmament of Āyurveda or the Science of Life. Due to several reasons including the destruction or plundering of valuable manuscripts by the various hordes, invading this country, it is very difficult to know about their period or original works.

The Hindu traditions which ascribe the origin of Āyurveda to the creator Brahmā himself mention about the sage Ātreya Punarvasu and his brilliant disciple Agniveśa. Caraka is said to be the disciple of Agniveśa. Since his name has been mentioned in the epic Mahābhārata, some scholars assign him to the period 1400 B.C. Others however opine that Caraka was the court physician of Kāniṣka (3rd cent. A.D.), the Kuśāna king.

His work Carakasaṁhitā, as it has come down to us today, is undoubtedly a much revised edition. Dṛḍhabala, a prominent writer (of Āyurveda), is said to have edited the earlier work and added several sections since the original was incomplete. It consists of eight prakaraṇas or sections divided into thirty chapters. It is exclusively a book of medicine and not of surgery.
The contents of the eight prakaraṇas, very briefly, are as follows:

ol.li: Sūtrasthāna: origin of medicines; duties of the physician; use of medicines; cure of diseases; materia medica; diet.
Nidānasthāna: curing of diseases like fever, tumours, diabetes, leprosy, tuberculosis, manias and epilepsy.
Vimānasthāna: epidemics; nature of food; symptoms and diagnosis of diseases; use of medicines; peculiarities of the fluids of the body.
Śarīrasthāna: nature of the soul; conception; varieties of species; qualities of elements; description of the body; connection of body and the soul.
Indriyasthāna: organs of senses and their diseases; loss of strength and death.
Cikitsāsthāna: diseases like dropsy, swelling, piles, jaundice, asthma, dysentery and effects of poisons; means of improving health and enjoying long life.
Kalpasthāna: emetics, purgatives, antidotes and medical charms.
Siddhisthāna: evacuating medi-cines, injections, abscesses and other topics.

description.p: It is a remarkable work written in the campū (mixture of prose and poetry) style. Even mental illnesses and epidemic diseases have been dealt with in detail. It has been translated into Persian and Arabic languages in the 8th cent. A. D. There are 17 commentaries on it in Sanskrit.
See also ĀYURVEDA and SUŚRUTA-SAṀHITĀ.
The cult of Vīraśaivism, with its philosophy of Śakti-viśiṣṭādvaita, took a definite shape during the middle ages in the province of Karnataka. But it is rooted in the ancient schools of Śaivism.

According to it, ‘Sthala’ or the Absolute (equivalent of Brahman) with its ‘Śakti’ or inherent power divides itself into ‘aṅga’ (the jīva) and ‘liṅga’ (Para or Paramātman). ‘Caraliṅga’, also called ‘jaṅgamaliṅga’, is one of the aspects of this liṅga. Since the human body is animated by Paramātman and is capable of movement (cara or jaṅgama = that which moves), it is called ‘caraliṅga’ or ‘jaṅgamaliṅga’.
For details see ŚAKTIVIŚIṢṬĀDVAITA and VĪRAŚAIVISM.
Rāmānuja’s (A. D. 1017-1137) teachings are twofold. The philosophical aspect is known as Viśiṣṭādvaita Vedānta. The practical, religious, aspect is called Śrīvaiṣṇavism.
Śrīvaiṣṇavism lays great emphasis on bhakti (devotion to God) and prapatti (self-surrender) as the two parallel means of attaining mokṣa or liberation.
Prapatti depends upon receiving the rahasyatraya (‘the three secrets’) from a qualified preceptor and practising the same.
They are: aṣṭākṣarīmantra, dvaya-mantra and caramaśloka. (See AṢṬĀKṢARĪ and DVAYAMANTRA for details.)

The caramaśloka is the 66th verse in the last chapter of the Bhagavadgītā (18.66). Though it is not the last in the section, since it contains the ultimate or final (= carama) message of Śrīkṛṣṇa, it has been designated as such.
The verse is:

sarvadharmān parityajya
māmekaṁ śaraṇam vraja |
ahaṁ tvā sarvapāpebhyo
mokṣayiṣyāmi mā śucaḥ ||
(‘Abandoning all dharmas [human efforts at moral and spiritual upliftment] come to Me as the only Refuge. Grieve not; I will deliver you from all sins’)
See also RAHASYATRAYASĀRA.
The word ‘caraṇa’ has been used in several senses like: foot, a quarter of verse, pillar of a temple and part of a musical composition (in Carnatic music).

In the Vedic terminology, it refers to a branch of the Veda (in a much larger sense) and the group of people who study it. It includes not only the particular śākhā (the branch or recension of Veda traditionally allotted to them for specialization) but also its allied literature like the law-books.
In Buddhism it refers to the eight aspects of character like fearlessness and self-control, fit to be cultivated.

He is the founder of the Caraṇadāsī sect that goes in his name. He lived in the 18th century. He was born at Dehara near Delhi. His guru was Sukhadevadāsa. He founded his sect when he was about 35 years of age and lived for about 78 years. The followers of this sect are generally found in Delhi, Haryana, western Uttar Pradesh and northern Rajasthan.

He lived mostly in Alwar and taught devotion to Kṛṣṇa. The eleventh book of the Bhāgavata was the basic text for his teachings. He wrote several works on yoga and bhakti. Two of his distinguished disciples were women: Sahajobāī and Dayābāī.
His followers sing bhajans in honour of Kṛṣṇa.

Vedic seers have accepted the princi-ple that revelation is a continuing process. Hence the volume of revealed mantras that constitute the Vedas went on growing, gradually reaching such levels that were beyond the normal ranges of human memory. It thus became necessary to compile index-works and appendices that would help the memorization process or locate the needed information. Anukrama-ṇikās and pariśiṣṭas are such works. The caraṇavyūhas belong to the latter group.

Among the two caraṇavyūhas extant, the first belongs to Śukla Yajurveda and is said to be the work of Kātyāyana. This lists the various śākhās or branches of that Veda. The work as it obtains today seems to be of later origin and its list is incomplete.

The second one is the 49th pariśiṣṭa of the Atharvaveda. It mentions the chief characteristics of the Atharvaveda and gives the number of the mantras as 12,380 included in 2000 sūktas. The ṛṣis (sages) and devatās (deities) of the mantras are also mentioned.
For each śākhā of the Vedas, the caraṇavyūhas mention the names of the related Brāhmaṇas, Āraṇyakas, Sūtras, Upaveda etc.
There is a work called Caraṇavyūha-sūtra attributed to Śaunaka giving the details of the four Vedas, their śākhas and allied literature in five chapters.
See also ANUKRAMAṆĪ and PARIŚIṢṬA.

Rantideva, an ancient king, performed several sacrifices in which many animals had been immolated. The hides of these had been heaped in one place. A river is said to have started flowing from there and it was christened ‘Carmaṇvatī’. Drupada’s (father of Draupadī and king of Pāñcāla) kingdom extended up to this river.

It is generally identified with the modern Chambal river that rises about 14 kms. (9 miles) south-west of Mhow (in Madhya Pradesh) and joins the river Yamunā 40 kms. (25 miles) south of Etawah town in Uttar Pradesh.

Caru is one of the several materials normally used in Vedic sacrifices for oblation. It is a kind of porridge prepared from unpounded rice or barley grains by cooking it in water and mixing it with butter or milk. It is used for oblation and also consumed by four of the priests specified in the sacrificial works. It is sometimes substituted for puroḍāśa (a kind of rice-cake used for offering) in the subsidiary or modified rites called ‘vikṛtis’. The vessel used for keeping or serving it is also called caru and sometimes as carusthālī.
See also PUROḌĀŚA.

Schools of Indian materialism, of various hues and shades, are generally called Cārvākadarśana or Lokāyatamata. Whether there was a real founder of this school by name Cārvāka is difficult to prove; probably not. The name of Bṛhaspati, son of Loka, is sometimes mentioned as the founder of this system.

The word ‘Cārvāka’ itself has been interpreted as ‘one who speaks sweetly’ (from cāru = sweet, vāk = speech) or as one who lives ‘to eat’ (from carv = to eat or enjoy). The term ‘Lokāyata’ means ‘restricted to the world of common experience’. Both these names refer to the nature of this system.

There are no extant basic texts of this school. Information has to be gleaned from various other works which state these views sometimes even quoting from their works, with the sole purpose of contradicting and criticizing them.

The Cārvāka system accepts pratyakṣa or direct perception as the only pramāṇa or valid source of knowledge, rejecting even anumāna or inference. Consequently it admits of only four elements—pṛthvī (earth), ap (water), tejas (fire) and vāyu (air)—as the fundamental substances constituting the world. It denies the existence of God and soul. Consciousness, according to it, is a chemical product of the combination of the elements that make up the body. Kāma or pleasure here and now, is the only goal of life. Artha or wealth is a means to it. One is advised to get the maximum pleasure out of life, before it is too late. In this process no attention need be paid to dharma, any moral or ethical scruples. Mokṣa or emancipation is a myth. Since death is the end of life and there is no rebirth, life need not be ‘all labour’ except for what is necessary to get pleasure.

The Cārvākas are sometimes classified into two groups: dhūrtas or the crass ones and suśikṣitas or the cultured ones. The former are base materialists interested only in the crude satisfaction of beastly instincts. The latter as represented by Vātsyāyana and others, accept dharma or righteousness also along with artha and kāma, and stress the need for self-control and discipline in life.
Whatever be their defect, the Cārvākas have certainly forced the later philosophers to give up dogmatism and spurred their free thinking.
See ĀGAMAS.

Though human beings come all alone into this world and return to the Abode of their Father in Heaven, also alone, they cannot live alone here! It is in their very nature to create a family or a group, to live with. However, when their gregarious instinct makes their herds grow into crowds, divisions into smaller groups become inevitable. Various factors may contribute to this division: professions, racial features, beliefs and customs carried over from the ancient generations, status consciousness brought about by economic well-being or higher levels of education and culture, and so on.
People all over the world have been subjected to this phenomenon.

Nor have such groups, clans and tribes remained static and unaffected by the vicissitudes of time and life. Terrific changes brought about by variegated experiences, the impact of the different ways and values of life of other groups, growth or deterioration of civilization and culture or even unexpected upheavals from inside their own groups have often wrought permanent transformations in them. Such groups as were incapable of withstanding the shocks of changes, have either been decimated or have been devoured and digested by the more aggressive ones.

The one social system that has successfully withstood all the onslaughts from without and within, over several millennia, is the caste system of the Hindus. If similar systems that existed in Greece, Rome, Persia or Japan have quietly disappeared into oblivion and only the Hindu system has survived, it speaks volumes for not only its resilience and tenacity, but also for its having fulfilled a great need and purpose of the Hindu peoples. This point will be dealt with later.

It may not be irrelevant to mention here a notion that we normally have—that the Semitic religions are monolithic and do not have any social system that is comparable to the Hindu caste system. It is true that—unlike the Hindu religion—they have only one founder and one Book. But one will be surprised to know that there are numerous varieties or schools of Christianity and that, in India at least, there are several castes even among the Muslims!M. N. Srinivas, Caste in Modern India, Bombay, Media Promoters & Publishers Pvt. Ltd., 1994, pp. 88 and 108.
description.h3: Varṇa, the Basis of the Caste System
description.p: The division of the Hindu society into four broad groups, known as varṇas is now a well-recognized fact.

Though the word ‘varṇa’ has been used in the sense of ‘colour’ of the skin, in the earlier sections of the Ṛgveda wherein the Āryans (fair in colour) and the Dasyus (of dark skin) have been divided into two eternally warring groups, it soon lost this sense.

The fourfold varṇa system goes back to the Ṛgveda Saṁhitā itself (vide 8.35.16.7; 1.10.8.7). To make a living by choosing a profession as per one’s desire and aptitude is a common phenomenon seen in all civilized societies. It is the duty of the society to provide suitable opportunities for its members to choose and pursue those vocations that agree with their nature. This is the philosophy behind the varṇa system. The Vedas, including the Puruṣasūkta (wherein this fourfold division of the society has been enunciated very clearly) have only recognized its existence and not created it.

As a society grows in size and civilization, there has got to be a division of labour since all persons cannot do all things. In the early Vedic period, this division of labour might have taken place on a voluntary basis even as the members of a family do so on any important occasion affecting the whole family. Some chose the occupation of accumulating knowledge, wisdom and culture, and training the younger generation in them. They became the brāhmaṇas. Those who were physically sturdy and strong, took to arms to protect the society from external aggression as also maintain internal law and order. They were the kṣattriyas. A great majority of the rest devoted themselves to the production and distribution of wealth and goods through agriculture, dairy-farming, trade and commerce. They were called the vaiśyas. The others who could not fit into any of these vocations made a living by supplying manual labour and serving others. They became the śūdras. In course of time, each of these varṇas—from the brāhmaṇas to the śūdras—acquired hierarchical superiority over the succeeding ones.

Though this was a natural process based on guṇa (aptitude) and karma (vocation chosen as per that aptitude), it was more a general rule and an ideal one at that. It was almost impossible to estimate the guṇa of every individual and assign an appropriate karma to him. (What about a baby that is just born?) Hence birth in a varṇa became an easier and a more practicable principle to fix up the varṇa of that individual. This was the beginning of the jāti system—now called the ‘caste system’—wherein the varṇa got automatically fixed by birth (jāti = birth).

Though the varṇa of a person had been assigned to him by virtue of his birth into it, there is enough evidence to surmise that one had enough freedom to choose one’s calling. Viśvāmitra and Vītahavya who were kṣattriya kings chose to become brāhmaṇa sages by their Vedic learning and austerity. Paraśurāma and Droṇā-cārya, on the other hand, took to arms and fighting as their profession and became—for all practical purposes—kṣattriyas, retaining their brāhmaṇahood only in name. However, these conversions seem to be rather an exception.

Human nature being prone to sense attraction and sex desire, the general rule of endogamy among the varṇas was often violated. Hence anuloma marriages—marriages of the men of the higher varṇas with the women of the lower ones—became common and had to be accorded legal sanction. On the other hand, pratiloma marriages—the reverse of the anuloma ones—could not be prevented, though frowned upon. This led to what is technically known as ‘varṇasaṅkara’ (mixing up of the varṇas or the castes) ultimately giving rise to a plethora of mixed castes.

Even by the time of the great epic, the Mahābhārata (circa 3000 B. C.), the problem of varṇasaṅkara had become stupendous. Incessant invasions from outside, by people of other races and cultures like the Greeks, the Hūṇas, the Śakas, the Scythians, the Persians and others who often settled down in India and got integrated into the Hindu society, also contributed to the multiplication of the castes.

While the law-givers, the authors of the smṛtis and dharmaśāstras (secondary scriptural works) were struggling to invent new names for those innumerable castes, and even subcastes, the natural flow of time and human history came to their rescue, at least in one way. Increase of population and development of civilization necessitated the manufacture of many new implements, instruments and devices for greater comforts and smoother living. This led to a multiplication of new professions, automatically absorbing more and more number of persons into them. They became the new castes. That the nomenclatures of many castes and subcastes contain a direct or indirect reference to their professions is proof enough, of this development. Over the decades or even centuries, a very high degree of specialization took place in these skills and professions.
description.h3: Positive Aspects of the Caste System
description.p: It has become a fashionable pastime for anyone who considers himself as modern, to rail against the caste system. People are not wanting who ‘discover’ in it, the ‘sinister machinations’ of the ‘clever and crooked’ brāhmaṇas to keep a whole nation under slavish subjugation. How a handful of people, who had neither military might nor the power of wealth to back them up, could keep millions under their thumb for millennia, except by the sheer power of their noble character and a life dedicated to the welfare of all, does not seem to penetrate their prejudiced brains. Impartial savants, whether from the West or from the East, have showered encomiums on this system which has survived many a brutal onslaught over the centuries. Sidney Low in his Vision of India (2nd edn., 1907, pp. 262-263) eloquently praises it thus:

‘There is no doubt that it is the main cause of the fundamental stability and contentment by which Indian society has been braced up for centuries against the shocks of politics and the cataclysms of Nature. It provides every man with his place, his career, his occupation, his circle of friends. It makes him at the outset a member of a corporate body, it protects him through life from the canker of social jealousy and unfulfilled aspirations; it ensures him companionship and a sense of community with others in like case with himself. The caste organization is to the Hindu his club, his trade union, his benefit society, his philanthropic society. There are no workhouses in India and none are as yet needed.’
This is what Abbe Dubois (A. D. 1770-1848), a Christian missionary from France, who lived in close touch with the Indians of all castes for over fifteen years, has to say on the same subject:

Quoted from: P. V. Kane, History of Dharmaśāstra, Vol. II, pt. 1, Edn. 1941, Poona, Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, p. 20.‘I consider the institution of castes among the Hindu nations as the happiest effort of their legislation; and I am well convinced that, if the people of India never sunk into a state of barbarism, and if, when almost all Europe was plunged in that dreary gulf, India kept up her head, preserved and extended the sciences, the arts and civilization, it is wholly to the distinction of castes that she is indebted for that high celebrity.’
Here is another quotation from Swami Vivekananda, the great prophet of Modern India:

‘We believe in Indian caste as one of the greatest social institutions that the Lord gave to man. We also believe that though the unavoidable defects, foreign persecutions, and above all, the monumental ignorance and pride of many brāh-maṇas who do not deserve the name, have thwarted in many ways, the legitimate fructification of this most glorious Indian institution, it has already worked wonders for the land of Bharata and is destined to lead Indian humanity to its goal.’India and Her problems, Edn. 1992, Mayavati, Advaita Ashrama, p. 63.
An unbiased study of the reasons for the survival of the caste system can easily reveal its positive and constructive aspects thus:

ul.li: It has given social security to every member of the caste by instilling a sense of belonging even from his early childhood days.

It has, in an easy and natural way, given excellent training in the parti-cular trade or profession, since the whole family is engaged in it. Most often, since people of the same caste, practising a particular profession, lived in colonies of their own, the very atmosphere was congenial to this training. This has automatically eliminated the problem of unemployment which has assumed alarming proportions now.
It has abolished unhealthy and cut-throat competition in the trade due to the cooperative efforts of the entire community.
Endogamous marriages within the community have further strengthened the social bonds among the various members, thus safeguarding the interest of the individual even in emergencies.

A clear demarcation of the duties and obligations of each caste group towards the society in general and a recognition of the rights and privileges of each group by the others in particular, conduced to peaceful coexistence over several centuries.

description.h3: Gradual Decadence of the Caste System
description.p: There is no gainsaying the fact that during the last 150 years, there has been a gradual decline of the true spirit behind the caste system. It has been much more pronounced during the 50 years after our political independence. These may be listed as follows:

ul.li: Men decay where wealth accumulates. Concentration of power leads to corruption. The brāhmaṇas and the kṣattriyas, developed vested interests in their position, status and power, which had helped them to better their worldly prospects. Instead of striving to serve the society through these, they tried to subju-gate it for selfish ends. It naturally produced reactions and caste conflicts. In fact, these conflicts have spread even to the so-called lower castes, each of which trying to establish its ‘superiority’ over the others.

Forgetting their duties and obligations to the society as a whole, people have started asserting their rights and privileges and fighting for them. This has led to the disturbance of the equilibrium and peace of the social structure.

The import of science and techno-logy from the West, with its concomitants of less work, more leisure and greater material comforts, has had a devastating effect on the Indian society. The need-based pattern of life has yielded its place to a greed-based one, thus sowing unrest in all fields of life.

As a result, all sections of the society including the brāhmaṇas—the original custodians of religion, ethical and spiritual values—have forsaken their great and time-tested ideals and have fallen a prey to the sensate culture of the machine-made civilization, of the West.

description.p: Before taking up a study of the remedial measures, it is better to turn our attention to the original Brāhmaṇa Ideal, to which everybody in the society was expected to be raised, in course of time.

The strength and stamina of any society depends not so much on its physical vigour and vitality or its economic power as on the general personal character of the individuals it comprises. People who are endowed with a will that inspires them, ‘to strive, to seek, to find, and not to yield,’ are the real wealth of a nation. Such a high degree of evolution cannot be achieved in a day. It may take decades, nay, even centuries to do so. And, this needs highly evolved, ideal, persons who become the models for others to emulate. Not only that, they should actively train and guide the rest of the society by their work, example and precept.
It is exactly this that the ancient sages of India, the founding fathers of Vedic religion and philosophy, did, when they gave us the varṇa system with the brāhmaṇa ideal as its pinnacle of glory.

A brāhmaṇa was, first of all, to be a ‘brahmavid,’ a knower of Brahman, a knower of God. Since ‘Brahman’ or the Vedas (which taught the science of the Spirit), was the means to it, a brāhmaṇa was commanded to master it and then spread its wisdom to the worthy disciples that may approach him for the same.

A life of the spirit leads to the life in the Spirit, called Brahman. This means, maximizing the intellectual, moral and spiritual (or soul) powers through tapas or austerity, enabling one to ultimately reach that goal. Since the physical body, the sense-organs and an unripe mind as also a wild ego are capable of knocking down even highly evolved spiritual aspirants, the brāhmaṇa is urged to spare no efforts in chastising and subjugating them. Thus a brāhmaṇa has to wage a relentless war on two fronts simultaneously—to control the physical instincts and to raise the mind to higher levels.

In every country, a soldier who is prepared to lay down his life in defending it, is given certain prerogatives and privileges; and, rightly so. Then, why not accord the same to these noble souls who have willingly forsaken their personal comforts and luxuries for the sake of an ideal that ultimately helps the entire society? Recog-nizing this, the smṛtis and the dharma-śāstras (scriptures considered as next in importance to the Vedas and guiding the lives of people in all its aspects) have given some rights and privileges to the brāhmaṇa.

A brāhmaṇa is primarily expected to study the Vedas, teach it to others competent to acquire its knowledge and lead a contemplative life. He may be an expert in several branches of sciences and arts and train others in them without expecting any fee for the same. He may, if he chooses, act as a priest in sacrifices conducted by others or perform them himself. On such occasions he is free to accept gifts and also bestow them on others.

He is not normally expected to practise remunerative professions except in times of great distress. Hence it is the duty of the society—especially the kṣattriya kings and the well-to-do vaiśyas—to maintain him, as also his family and disciples, if he is running a gurukula (forest academy). The king should not collect taxes from him and should exempt him from the general laws of the land. Punishment for transgressions, if any, must be very mild. On all occasions in general and during religious festivals in particular, the brāhmaṇa should get precedence over others and a place of honour and veneration.

From the foregoing description it should not be surmised that the brāhmaṇa was above the laws of the land and hence a law unto himself! His own pure conscience being the best judge, the brāhmaṇa often applied the rules to himself even more ruthlessly than he wished for the others. The story of Śaṅkha and Likhita (vide Mahābhārata, Śāntiparva, ch. 23), is a case to the point.

Human nature being rather fragile, easily subject to the weaknesses of the flesh and lucre, not all the brāhmaṇas could keep to the superhuman ideals expected of them. As they gradually slided down from the lofty ideals, they took to other means of living as were prescribed for the kṣattriyas and vaiśyas, like fighting, agriculture, trade and commerce. As long as they sincerely struggled to keep up the Vedic studies and also lead a simple and austere life, the smṛtis and dharma-śāstras (of later periods) permitted them to do so.

During further periods of decline of their brāhmaṇahood, they advocated the theory of the superiority of a brāhmaṇa just by birth and started claiming the privileges as of old, as a matter of right.‘While finding fault with the brāhmaṇa writers of over two thousand years ago, for the eulogies they bestowed upon themselves, one should not forget that even in the 20th century when the pursuit of scientific studies is professed to have reached its zenith, we hear ecstatic and arrogant achievements of the Nordic race and the greater and more glorious future it is destined to attain (vide the very first sentence in Spengler’s The Decline of the West, English translation by S. F. Atkinson). The brāhmaṇas never arrogated to themselves the authority to depose kings and to hand over vast territories forever to whomsoever they liked, as Pope Alexander VI by his Bull of 1493 made over the New World to Isabella of Castille and Ferdinand of Aragon (vide Dean Inge, Christian Ethics, Edn. 1930, p. 160, where this astounding Bull is set out).’

This had a twofold deleterious effect: They contributed to their own spiritual damnation. They also generated unhealthy reactions from the other members of the society. Gradually they lost their privileges. They were forced to obey the general laws of the land as others.

Since the brāhmaṇas were the trend-setters for the society—it being universally conceded that they represented the Ideal Man—their forsaking the spiritual ideals of human excellence, had a catastrophic effect on the whole society. If today the Hindu society in general is sunk in the quagmire of corruption, nepotism and immorality, much of the blame should be apportioned to the brāhmaṇas themselves.
If in the original varṇa system, the brāhmaṇa stood at the top of the ladder of social hierarchy, the śūdra occupied the bottom rung.

Who exactly the śūdras were, has been a point of discussion and debate among scholars, especially the sociologists and the anthropologists. As per the original varṇa system, the śūdras were very much a part and parcel of the Āryan society. Though they earned their livelihood by physical labour and service to the other three varṇas they did enjoy social status and honour. In the early Vedic society rules about inter-dining and inter-marriage do not seem to have been very stringent. The brāhmaṇas could employ the śūdras as cooks (vide Āpastamba Dharmasūtras, 2.2.3.4) and could accept their invitation for dinner if they were their own servants or tillers of their land or even their family friends (vide Gautama Dharmasūtras 17.1 and 6). Some authorities like Bādari even allowed them to establish Vedic fires or have the saṁskāras (religious sacraments) performed.

From all these we can perhaps conclude that except for keeping the Vedic fires and studying or teaching the Vedas, they were allowed to live a decent life like any other member of the Āryan society. And, they were certainly entitled to the acquisition of spiritual knowledge and wisdom, though not through the Vedas, but through the secondary works like the itihāsas and the purāṇas.

However, things did change for the worse, for the śūdras as time rolled by. Their freedom got gradually curtailed. Their social disabilities were multiplied. Their honour and dignity were lowered. Some sections from among them were even branded as untouchables, segregated from the general society and forced to live outside the towns and villages. Punishments for transgressions against the higher varṇas became more and more severe. Legal protection became less effective.
The gradual decline of the śūdras in the hierarchy of the Āryan society might have been due to several causes:

As the general population increased, that of the śūdras also naturally swelled. An unconscious fear of their numerical strength might have induced the upper classes of the society to impose greater restrictions on them.

Offsprings of the anuloma and prati-loma marriages along with those of clandestine unions as also the parents of the latter, were relegated to the śūdra class. Persons of the upper varṇas guilty of heinous sins, were also pushed down into the śūdra class. They being renegades, the brāhmaṇas were perhaps unwilling to give them the facilities that the śūdras enjoyed earlier.

Invading tribes of foreign origin when they decided to stay on in India and get domiciled, could neither be ignored nor assimilated completely. Hence they might have grudgingly been given a place among the śūdras. Since they were totally alien to the local religion and culture, restrictions had to be placed on them to protect the Āryan way of life from being adversely affected.

Along with the decline of the śūdras there appeared in the Hindu society, an evil practice worse than the ones known so far—that of aspṛśyatā or untouchability. Neither during the Vedic period, nor during the period of the early dharma-śāstras, was untouchability mentioned, much less practised. Even the cāṇḍālas, considered the lowest in the social rank, were counted only among the śūdras.

How and when exactly the practice began, it is difficult to say. Ceremonial impurity as on the birth or death in a family was fairly well-known. Contact with unclean objects or persons made a person ‘aspṛśya’ or untouchable, but a bath could remedy the defect.

Gradually, the notion must have gained ground that certain persons constantly engaged in very unclean occupations like cleaning human ordure, butchery and sale of meat, tanning and so on—which were a health hazard for others—had to be segregated and treated as untouchables in the best interest of the society as a whole. Hence they were made to live outside the towns and villages and their entry and movements were restricted.Compare this with the most brutal treatment meted out to the Bushmen of Africa and Australia, and the Negroes of America by the European races, merely due to racial prejudice. What might have begun thus was, unfortunately, extended to all the persons of those castes later on, even though they might have been engaged in more decent occupations.

That untouchability is a blot on the Hindu society has been conceded by one and all. Vigorous efforts have been made by the teachers of the Bhakti Schools like Śrīkṛṣṇa Caitanya (A. D. 1485-1533) earlier and by Nārāyaṇa Guru (A. D. 1854-1928) and Mahātmā Gāndhī (A. D. 1869-1948) in recent history, to eliminate it and restore a place of dignity to these unfortunate persons.
description.h3: Solution to the Caste Problem in Modern India
description.p: In spite of all the encomiums heaped upon the Caste System by a few far-sighted savants of the East and the West, it is an undeniable fact that serious situations are, off and on, arising out of it (as it obtains now), sometimes creating law and order problems too! The caste consciousness has become so deep-rooted in the psyche of our people that even among the so-called untouchable classes, some sections are claiming ‘superiority’ over other sections! The problem has further been compounded by selfish and narrow-minded political and social leaders, ever eager to fish in troubled waters. Various laws enacted by the governments—whether at the Centre or in the States—though done with the best of intentions, have not had the desired impact on the society.

One of the solutions that is often ‘graciously’ given by many a leader in social life is that the system itself should be scrapped. It is akin to advising the abolition of all the political systems since none has really helped humanity perfectly. (Or, why not cut off the head, to get rid of headaches?!)

In fact some of the religious leaders of the medieval ages (of India) who tried this method, not only failed in their efforts, but ultimately ended up in adding one more caste along with many subcastes to the already existing ones!

Even in countries that have no caste system as we have in India, social tensions and violent conflicts have not disappeared. Racial riots, sectarian violence and even religious conflicts among people professing the same religion are the order of the day.
Hence the solution of abolishing the caste system itself is worse than the problem it is supposed to solve.

Wisdom lies in a reappraisal of the entire system over the centuries, discover the various loopholes and plug them, and also improve the system itself in other ways so that we can get the best out of it. Let us not forget that it has successfully worked for over five millennia or even more!

The causes of all conflicts among the human beings, including those rooted in caste-consciousness, are basically two: selfishness and egoism. If and when one caste group succeeds in getting better off in life, both economically and culturally, it also succeeds in rousing the wrath of other caste groups that may be lagging behind. False pride and hurt-feelings roused by the progress of other castes may also be responsible for initiating friction, tensions and conflicts.

The best and the only remedy for this is good education for all the people of our country. Education can be the panacea for many an evil in our society. However, this education, apart from giving general knowledge and proficiency in some calling, should also give a person refinement and culture through the imparting of moral, ethical and spiritual values. In other words dharma, in its true sense, must become an integral part of an education system. If and when such an education makes all the people feel that they are one people belonging to a great country and are endowed with tremendous potentialities to raise themselves from the brute level to the human level, and ultimately to the divine level, they will become an invaluable asset to the whole of humanity. In fact, it was exactly this ideal that our ancient sages envisaged when they attempted to raise everyone ultimately to the level of the ideal brāhmaṇa, through their propagation of the varṇa system and eulogy of the true brāhmaṇa. And, many of these great ones like Vyāsa, Vālmīki or Vasiṣṭha, were themselves not brāhmaṇas by birth!

Most unfortunately, during the last few decades, a virulent and systematic propaganda has been mounted by certain non-brāhmaṇa leaders against the brāhmaṇas, blaming them for all the ills that have afflicted their own societies. It is best to quote in reply, Swami Vivekananda (who himself was not a brāhmaṇa by caste) here:

Swami Vivekananda, India and Her Problems, Edn. 1992, Mayavati, Advaita Ashrama, pp. 67, 69, 70.‘Therefore, it is no use fighting among the castes...It will divide us all the more, weaken us all the more, degrade us all the more. The solution is not by bringing down the higher, but by raising the lower upto the level of the higher. And that is the line of work found in all our books...The ideal at one end is the brāhmaṇa and the ideal at the other end is the cāṇḍāla, and the whole work is to raise the cāṇḍāla upto the brāhmaṇa. Slowly and slowly you find more and more privileges granted to them.

‘It is true that he (the brāhmaṇa) was the earliest preacher to the Indian races, he was the first to renounce everything in order to attain the higher realization of life, before others could reach to the idea. It was not his fault that he marched ahead of the other castes. Why did not the other castes so understand and do as they did? Why did they sit down and be lazy, and let the brāhmaṇas win the race?

‘To the non-brāhmaṇa castes I say, wait, be not in a hurry. Do not seize every opportunity of fighting the brāhmaṇa, because as I have shown, you are suffering from your own fault. Who told you to neglect spirituality and Sanskrit learning? What have you been doing all this time?...Why do you not spend millions to bring Sanskrit education to all the castes of India? ...The moment you do these things you are equal to the brāhmaṇa. That is the secret power of India.’

Vivekananda, during his days, vigorously advocated the study of Sanskrit by all, because according to him, Sanskrit education brought with it refinement and culture, by opening up the entire treasure for our ancient religio-cultural literature.

Another problem which is intimately connected with caste conflicts is that of inter-dining and inter-marriage among the castes. Though inter-dining in urban India seems to have become common, it is still a taboo in the rural areas. As for inter-caste marriages it is not at all common even in the urban areas.

In the rural areas it is not only frowned upon even now but has often led to violent conflicts. With all the propaganda in favour of inter-caste marriages by the government media, people in general are yet to accept the concept. Attitudes among the common people have hardened to such an extent that inter-marriages even among the sub-groups of the same caste are not favoured. It being a rather sensitive issue, one has to tread very slowly and carefully. As Vivekananda aversSwami Vivekananda, The Complete Works, Mayavati, Advaita Ashrama, Vol. 5, pp. 405, 406., the unity moves should begin at the levels of subcastes and subgroups, gradually integrating them into the main varṇas, thus restoring the original four varṇa system. At the same time the notion of privileges should be given the go-by and the duties of everyone towards the society as a whole must be stressed. Of course, the right type of education imparted from the young age can achieve this in course of time.

If the brāhmaṇas show the way, by returning to a life of ‘simple living and high thinking,’ by producing from among themselves great persons of sterling character, the balance in the society also can be restored more easily and quickly.
To sum up:

ol.li: The Hindu caste system is a natural growth and evolution from within the varṇa system, from the Vedic culture and the Āryan society.
It has imparted stability to the Hindu society and has successfully survived for over five or six millennia in spite of the repeated invasions against India.

Its decadence started first by the forsaking of the spiritual ideal by the brāhmaṇas for pelf and power; and later by the impact of Western civilization and culture centred round heavy machines and emphasis on greater physical comforts.

The caste system as such need not be and should not be given up. Right attitudes must be created in the minds of people by imparting proper education and culture to eliminate mutual suspicions and animosities and cultivate a sense of social responsibility towards all sections of the society.

description.p: An example can make this point clear. Suppose in a family, the last child has been handicapped; will its elder brothers and sisters throw it into the well thinking it is a useless child and a burden upon them? On the other hand, they will lavish extra love and affection on it, to bring it up and make it happy. In exactly the same way, if the forward sections of the society—those who are economically, educationally and culturally forward—take some extra trouble for the upliftment of the weaker sections, not only will the latter be happy but the former too will be happy by the joy of fulfilment of their efforts. And, all social tensions will automatically disappear into the thin air.
Did not Lord Buddha declare 2500 years ago that hatred begets hatred and only love can conquer hatred? Why not give a fair trial to such an eternal truth that has stood the test of time?

Once the people wake up to these simple truths and practise them seriously, the social equilibrium and peace will easily be restored. And caste, instead of being a problem, will become an asset that may be coveted by other nations too!

The four places of pilgrimage in the four corners of India, viz., Badarīnātha in the north, Rāmeśvara in the south, Jagannātha Purī in the east and Dvārakā in the west—are the four dhāmas or abodes of God which every Hindu aspires to visit during his life time.
See under each for details.

The Hindu scriptures, by and large, have given a very high status to the king, even calling him as ‘pratyakṣa-devatā’ (‘visible deity’). It was his primary duty and responsibility to protect the lives, properties, honour and religion of his subjects at any cost. Whatever he did for discharging this, was considered dharma or righteousness, as long as he had no selfish or impure motives.

For this, he was advised to employ four kinds of ‘upāyas’ or means which were technically called ‘guṇas.’ They are: sāma (conciliation), dāna (concessions, favours and gifts), bheda (dissensions) and daṇḍa (conflict and war).

The enemies of the State could be internal or external, the former being considered as the more dangerous. The king was advised to make use of the daṇḍopāya as the last resort. He was to try for conciliation through sweet words, concessions, favours and gifts. If these did not have the desired effect, then he should secretly try to bring about dissensions among the enemies and trouble-makers through spies of proven loyalty. Daṇḍa or war was to be the last resort.
Both Manu and Kauṭilya have dealt with this subject in detail.

Certain Vedic sacrifices belonging to the ‘iṣṭi’ group (See IṢṬI.) are known as ‘cāturmāsya’ since these sacrifices have to be repeated every four months. They are: Vaiśvadeva, Varuṇapraghāsa, Sākamedha and Śunāsīrīya. (See under the respective titles for details.) Each is called a ‘parvan’ or a part of the Cāturmāsyas. They were performed respectively on the full-moon days of Phālguna or Caitra (February—April), Āṣāḍha (July), Kārttika (November) and on the fifth full-moon from the day on which the Sākamedha is performed. Obviously these are the beginnings of the spring, monsoon and autumn seasons. The Maruts were the most prominent deities receiving offerings in all of them with the set of gods peculiar to each. The attainment of heaven was the promised fruit. These sacrifices could be performed either throughout one’s life or for one year only.

The four months of the rainy season are also called ‘cāturmāsya’. A ‘vrata’ or a religious observance, has been prescribed for these months for those who are interested, by the smṛtis and dharma-śāstras. It begins with a saṅkalpa or resolve on the 11th or the 12th day of the bright half of Āṣāḍha (July), or on the full-moon day. During these four months, the person under the vow, should desist from consuming some specified edibles like vegetables, curds and milk, and give up some luxuries such as cot. It is to be concluded on the Utthāna-dvādaśī day (12th day of the bright half of Kārttika which generally comes in November). Many rewards, both here and hereafter, have been promised to those that observe this vrata. It is open to women also.

The saṁnyāsins (monks) also have a cāturmāsya. During the days when the saṁnyāsins were mendicants, realizing the difficulty of moving about during the rainy season, it was made obligatory for them to spend the four or even two months of the rainy season by camping in a suitable place. Their vrata or vow begins on the Vyāsa-pūrṇimā (full-moon day in Āṣāḍha), with a ceremonial worship of God, the sage Vedavyāsa and one’s gurus (preceptors). (Hence the day is also called ‘Guru-pūrṇimā’.) During these days they can live in the congenial company of other monks, study the scriptures, practise their personal spiritual disciplines and also preach to the householder devotees that may approach them.
In Indian mythological accounts, Brahmā the Creator, is called ‘Caturmukha’ since he has four faces, representing the four Vedas. See BRAHMĀ for details.
In the works on temple architecture ‘caturmukha’ is the name given to a circular type of temple with four doors.
See CATURVYŪHAS.

While dealing with other kings who may cause trouble to himself, either now or in future, a wise ruler should adopt the caturopāyas or four means judiciously. They are: sāma (reconciliation); dāna (yielding something to appease him); bheda (bringing about a split in the enemy’s ranks) and daṇḍa (going to war).

Honouring the dead ancestors through appropriate rituals is a pheno-menon common to many cultures. Such a ceremony among the Hindus is called ‘śrāddha’. Riceballs called ‘piṇḍas’ are offered to the ancestors with suitable mantras during these ceremonies.

In one of these śrāddhas called ‘pārvaṇaśrāddha,’ the offerings are made to the dead ancestors up to three generations (father, grandfather and great-grandfather) only, omitting the fourth and beyond (visarga = omitting). This is called ‘caturthavisarga’.
See also PĀRVAṆA-ŚRĀDDHA and ŚRĀDDHA.

The Hindu society has always consi-dered vivāha or marriage as sacred, as a sacrament. The rites of marriage breathe this spirit. The husband and the wife were expected to observe continence for three nights though sleeping together on the ground, with a daṇḍa or staff between them. This was called ‘trirātravrata’ (‘the vow of three nights’). The marriage was consummated on the fourth day—hence the name caturthīkarman—after appropriate rites. The smṛtis consider this as part of the rites of marriage.
See also VIVĀHA.

The four ‘puruṣārthas’ or ends of life to be sought after by all human beings are called ‘caturvarga,’ ‘the group of four’. They are dharma (righteousness), artha (wealth), kāma (pleasures of the flesh) and mokṣa (release from transmigratory existence). Sometimes, the first three are called ‘trivarga’ (‘group of three’) and mokṣa as ‘apavarga’ (‘that which is beyond the group’).
See PURUṢĀRTHAS for details.

head.note: (‘the wish-yielding gem of the four ends of life’)

description.p: One of the most voluminous and celebrated digests of ancient religious rites and observations is Hemādri’s (13th cent. A.D.) Caturvarga-cintāmaṇi. Hemādri who was a minister at the court of the Yādava king of Devagiri (modern Daulatabad in Maharashtra) might have composed this during A.D. 1260-70. According to the state-ments in the book, the author intended to treat the subject in five sections: vrata (religious observances), dāna (gifts), tīrtha (pilgrimage), mokṣa (emancipation) and pariśiṣṭa (supplement). Since the sections dealing with tīrtha and mokṣa are not available now, some scholars feel that Hemādri could not complete his work according to his original intentions. The book is more popular in the Deccan and South India, and is considered as a standard work.
The Vedas are the basic scriptures of Hinduism. Their language is archaic. Their ideas are often unintelligible. Hence a bhāṣya or a commentary is necessary to understand them.

Out of the several commentators on the Ṛgveda, some like Sāyaṇa, are well-known. Among the lesser known ones is Caturvedasvāmin. He lived at the end of the 15th cent. A.D. Sūryapaṇḍita, who wrote a commentary on the Līlāvatī of Bhāskara (12th cent. A.D.) was his disciple.
His explanations of ṛks have been considered as rather odd since he often connects them to the epic personalities like the Pāṇḍavas.

In Vaiṣṇavite rituals, very often, 24 names of Viṣṇu like Keśava, Nārāyaṇa and Vāsudeva are used. All these names refer to the same deity and give his attributes from different standpoints. Iconographical works have devised a simple method by which these 24 aspects of Viṣṇu can be shown, just by altering the positions of the four well-known appurtenances viz., śaṅkha (conch), cakra (discus), gadā (mace) and padma (lotus). For instance, if they are held—in that order—in the right upper and lower hands, and, left upper and lower hands, the image is that of Vāmana. If, on the other hand, the right upper and lower hands hold the gadā and the śaṅkha, and, the left upper and lower hands hold the cakra and padma, it is the image of Vāsudeva.

The 24 names are: Keśava, Nārāyaṇa, Mādhava, Govinda, Viṣṇu, Madhusūdana, Trivikrama, Vāmana, Śrīdhara, Hṛṣīkeśa, Padmanābha, Dāmodara, Vāsudeva, Saṅkarṣaṇa, Pradyumna, Aniruddha, Adhokṣaja, Puruṣottama, Nṛsiṁha, Acyuta, Upendra, Janārdana, Hari and Kṛṣṇa.
See VIṢṆU for symbology.

According to the Sāṅkhya system of philosophy it is prakṛti or pradhāna comprising the three guṇas of sattva, rajas and tamas, that is the originator of this world. It evolves in stages into 23 fundamental principles—itself being the 24th—by the permutation and combination of which the whole world is created. They are: prakṛti (Mother Nature), mahat (‘the great’, the intellect), ahaṅkāra (egoism), manas (mind), five jñānendriyas (organs of sense), five karmendriyas (organs of action), five tanmātras (subtle elements) and five bhūtas (gross elements).
See SĀṄKHYA-DARŚANA for details.
The Bhāgavata or the Pāñcarātra religion, which preaches the cult of Viṣṇu-Nārāyaṇa, puts forth the theory that the Supreme Lord Viṣṇu has four aspects of manifestation:

ul.li: The Para or the supreme;
the Vyūha or the emanation;
the Vibhava or the incarnation and
the Arca or the icon.

description.p: Para is the Supreme as He is, in all His glory. Vibhava represents the incarnations. Arca is the descent of the Lord into the icon ceremonially installed and worshipped in the temples.

The Vyūhas or the emanations are four in number. Hence the term Catur-vyūhas, also called Caturmūrtis. They are: Vāsudeva, Saṅkarṣaṇa, Pradyumna and Aniruddha. According to Vaiṣṇava mythologies, while Śrī Kṛṣṇa is Vāsudeva, his brother Balarāma is Saṅkarṣaṇa. Pradyumna and Aniruddha are Kṛṣṇa’s son and grandson respectively. Historically speaking, it is possible that these Yādava heroes were in course of time, apotheosised into these Vyūhas. Symbologically, Vāsudeva represents Citta (mind-stuff), whereas Saṅkarṣaṇa stands for Ahaṅkāra (egoity), Pradyumna for Buddhi (intellect) and Aniruddha for Manas (mind). They represent the cosmic psychological evolution.

Later on, these Vyūhas were increased to as many as twenty-four. Icono-graphically, all these Vyūhas are identical in appearance except for the arrangement of the four emblems—Śaṅkha, Cakra, Gadā and Padma.
The Pāñcarātra theology often adds another aspect of the manifestations, viz., the Antaryāmin (the indweller), which obviously, cannot be represented through icons.
See YUGAS.

The four ‘mānasaputras’ or mind-born sons of Brahmā, the Creator, are called ‘Catus-sanas’ since their names begin with the word ‘Sana’. They are: Sanaka, Sanatkumāra, Sanatsujāta and Sanandana. They are in the state of eternal boyhood.

Once they went to Vaikuṇṭha, the abode of Viṣṇu but were denied admittance by the gatekeepers, Jaya and Vijaya. Hence they were cursed by the sages to be born on earth as demons. Jaya and Vijaya, consequently, took birth as Hiraṇyākṣa and Hiraṇyakaśipu, Rāvaṇa and Kumbhakarṇa, and Siśupāla and Dantavakra.

The sage Sanatkumāra taught the greatness of Viṣṇu to Vṛtra (the demon enemy of Indra) and spiritual wisdom to Nārada, another great sage. Sanatsujāta taught spiritual truths to Dhṛtarāṣṭra, the blind king and father of the Kauravas like Duryodhana. Sanaka is said to be an eternal companion of Lord Viṣṇu. Sanandana is accepted as an ancient teacher of Sāṅkhya, more ancient than even Kapila.
See CŪḌĀKARAṆA.
See CĀMARA.

Yoginīs are minor goddesses, aspects of Śakti or Durgā. They are often the gramadevatās or village deities supposed to protect the people of the village when propitiated, or, bring evil and disaster when offended. Their number is variously stated as 8, 60, 64 or even 65.
The Cauṣaṭ Yoginī Temples are temples of that class where these deities are placed in niches on a circular or rectangular wall with a temple in the centre for the main deity.

Such temples, most of which were built between the 9th and 12th centuries, are found in Bheraghat near Jabalpur (Madhya Pradesh), Ranipur Jhorial near Patna (Bihar), Dudhati near Jhansi (Uttar Pradesh) and Khajuraho (Madhya Pradesh). The only temple outside Central India is found near Coimbatore in Tamil Nadu.
See KĀVERĪ.

Artificial caves excavated for religious purposes date from the time of Aśoka. Three phases of development of rock-cut architecture are listed by Indologists: the first phase from the 2nd cent. B.C. to the 2nd cent. A.D.; the second phase from the 5th to the 7th cent. A.D.; the third phase from the 7th to the 10th cent. A. D.

The two caves of Barabar Hill near Gayā in Bihar, dedicated by Aśoka to the Ājīvika monks, the cave at Karli and some Buddhist caves at Ajanta (both in Maharashtra), as also the Jaina caves at Udayagiri and Khaṇḍagiri (Orissa) belong to the first phase.
