Several forms of Dakṣiṇāmūrti are also described in the tāntrik works. Some of them are: Saṁhāra-Dakṣiṇāmūrti, Lakuṭi-Dakṣiṇāmūrti, Medhā-Dakṣiṇā-mūrti, Sāmba-Dakṣiṇāmūrti and so on. Each one of these is, iconographically speaking, sculptured in a different manner.
His worship may involve elaborate rituals. His yantra (magical diagram) is a lotus with eight petals on which the deities Brahmā, Sarasvatī, Gaṇapati and some sages are inscribed.
See also ŚIVA.

This is a short Upaniṣad of 33 verses, assigned to the Kṛṣṇa Yajurveda, but classed among the minor ones. It deals mainly with the meditation on Dakṣiṇā-mūrti, an aspect of Śiva representing a teacher of divine wisdom.

Once, a group of sages under the leadership of Śaunaka, approached the deathless sage Mārkaṇḍeya with due respect and asked him how he had attained the cirajīvatva or the deathless state as also eternal bliss. He replied, ‘By the esoteric knowledge of the principle of Śiva.’
Then they put him nine questions:

What is that esoteric knowledge of the principle of Śiva? Who is the deity in it? Which are the mantras (spiritual formulae)? What is the steadfast devotion needed? What is the means of attaining that knowledge? What is its instrument? What is the offering? What is its final state? What is the final abode?

The esoteric knowledge of Śiva is the realisation of him in his aspect as Dakṣiṇā-mūrti. Śiva is called Dakṣiṇāmūrti since he can silently give the gift (= dakṣiṇā) of Self-knowledge to anyone that is seen by him.
He himself is the deity (= deva) since he shines (deva = one who shines) in his own glory and joy at the time of dissolution of the world.
As regards the mantras, the Upaniṣad offers five of them:

(1) Oṁ namo bhagavate dakṣiṇāmūrtaye
mahyam medhām prajñām
prayaccha svāhā ||
(2) Oṁ dakṣiṇāmūrtir-atarom ||

(3) Oṁ blūṁ namo hrīm aiṁ
dakṣiṇāmūrtaye jñānaṁ dehi svāhā ||

(4) Oṁ hrīṁ śrīṁ sāmbaśivāya
tubhyaṁ svāhā

(5) (Oṁ) namo bhagavate tubhyaṁ vaṭamūlanivāsine |
vāgīśāya mahājñāna-dāyine māyine namaḥ ||
The steadfast devotion needed is the conviction that one is Brahman, which should last till the death of the body.
The means of attaining that know-ledge is the repetition of the mantra (one of the five already given) with the conscious thinking that one is identical with the deity denoted by the mantra.
The instrument is singular devotion to the mantra.
Offering is the offering of the movement of one’s limbs as worship to the deity of the mantra.
The final state is the attainment of the perfect equanimity of the three guṇas.
And, the final abode is the heart or the sahasrāra (thousand-petalled lotus in the crown of the head) which are the places for the realisation of the Self.
The Upaniṣad ends with the eulogy that one who learns this esoteric wisdom is freed from all sins and attains liberation from transmigration.
See also DAKṢIṆĀMŪRTI and UPANIṢADS.
According to the purāṇas which contain a lot of geographical and historical material on India, the Bhāratavarṣa is a part of the Jambūdvīpa and is divided into seven regions.

Dakṣiṇāpatha is that region which is south of the river Narmadā. Its extent is about one-fourth of Bāratavarṣa. Some of the people inhabiting this region are: Pāṇḍyas, Keraḷas, Coḷas, Setukas, Mūṣikas, Kumāras, Māhiṣakas, Kāveras, Vidarbhas, Daṇḍakas, Āndhras, Ṛṣikas, Kuntalas and so on.
The modern Deccan region is almost the same as Dakṣiṇāpatha.
See PITṚYĀNA.

Visiting a famous place of pilgrimage at least once in a life-time has been a great ambition cherished by all devout Hindus. And, such places of pilgrimage are legion in Hinduism. Many of these pilgrim centres have acquired their importance due to their intimate association with great saints and religious leaders.

One such place, of a rather recent origin, is Dakṣiṇeśvara, now a part of the city of Calcutta. Due to its close connection with the life of Śrī Rāmakṛṣṇa (A. D. 1836-1886) it is now attracting thousands of votaries and visitors throughout the year.

As one enters the temple complex from the riverside through the landing ghāṭ on the eastern bank of the Ganges river, one comes to the main portico called ‘Cāndni’. On either side of it are the Śiva temples six to the north and six to the south. They are all identical. One has to cross the open courtyard to reach the temple of Kālī, the main shrine.

Built by Rāṇī Rāsamaṇi (A. D. 1793-1861), a rich landlady, in 1855, this temple of Kālī is the central attraction of this place. The goddess is known as ‘Bhava-tāriṇī’, ‘redeemer from the sufferings of the world’. The image has been carved out of a single piece of basalt and faces south. The deity is standing on the chest of Śiva (her spouse) who lies prostrate on a thousand-petalled silver lotus. The height of the image is 85 cms. (33.5 inches) and the shrine-room is 4.5 metres (15 ft.) square excluding the raised plinth and the overall height is more than 33 metres (100 ft.).

Open on all sides and facing the main shrine is the Nāṭmandir (literally, ‘dance-hall’) measuring 22.5 metres (75 ft.) by 15 metres (50 ft.). It is meant for meditation and religio-cultural activities like devotional music, dramas and dances with religious themes.
Behind the temple of Kālī stands another temple dedicated to Kṛṣṇa in his Rādhākānta aspect. The images of Kṛṣṇa and Rādhā are 55 cms. (21.5 inches) and 40 cms. (16 inches) respectively.
Other holy spots in the campus are: Śrī Rāmakṛṣṇa’s room, Nahabat and Bakultala ghāṭ, the Pañcavaṭī and the Bel tree as also the small cottage or meditation hut.

Śrī Rāmakṛṣṇa spent nearly thirty years of his life in that room. The room is about 7 metres (24 ft.) square. The two wooden cots—one smaller than the other—which he was using have been preserved. The room opens on to a semicircular verandah to the west which faces the Ganges river.

The Nahabat or music tower is to the north of Śrī Rāmakṛṣṇa’s room and has an octagonal room on the ground-floor measuring 2.3 metres (7.75 ft.) across. The entrance door is hardly 1.2 metres (4 ft.) in height. Śrī Sāradā Devī (better known as the Holy Mother) lived in this room. Candrādevī, mother of Śrī Rāmakṛṣṇa, lived on the first floor.
The Bakultala-ghāṭ is the bathing ghāṭ (close to the Nahabat) of the Ganges river, which Śrī Sāradā Devī used to use.
The Pañcavaṭī is a grove of five sacred trees intended as a place for spiritual practices. It was renovated by Śrī Rāmakṛṣṇa himself.
The Bel tree which is a little away from the Pañcavaṭī is the very tree under which Śrī Rāmakṛṣṇa practised severe tāntric disciplines guided by Bhairavī Brāhmaṇī.
The small cottage is the very meditation room where the great saint attained Advaitic samādhi under the guidance of the monk Totāpurī.
See also (RĀṆĪ) RĀSAMAṆI and RĀMA-KṚṢṆA.

All the Hindu philosophical systems which accept the authority of the Vedas, posit mokṣa or liberation from transmigratory existence, as the final goal of life. This becomes possible only when one realises one’s real nature as the ātman, the Self, of the nature of pure consciousness, totally different from the body-mind complex. This, again, involves a lot of spiritual struggle wherein one has to conquer the pulls and pushes of the powerful sense-organs and sense-objects. ‘Dama’ is the technical term given to this aspect of spiritual discipline, by the Vedāntic treatises, especially the Upaniṣads and the Bhagavadgītā.

It is generally defined as restraining and pulling back the external sense-organs like the eyes and the ears from all those objects which do not aid the meditation on the ātman, but try to distract and disturb the mind.
See also SĀDHANACATUṢṬAYA.
See TANTRAS.
Pictures and images of Śiva (one of the major forms of God in Hinduism) show him as holding the triśūla (trident) and the ḍamaru (a small drum) in his hands.

The ḍamaru which is a folk or tribal musical instrument of the percussion type, is in extensive use even now in the rural parts of India, especially by the folk-dancers and priests of the tāntrik tradition. It is a sort of kettle-drum, very small in size. It is made of two inverted bowls of wood or clay, the open ends being covered with parchment or thin leather. Strings with beads at their ends are attached to the slender middle portion. When the drum is rhythmically shaken by hand, a pleasant rattling sound is produced, as the beads strike the membrane on the open ends.
In the images of Śiva (especially the dancing ones like Naṭarāja) the ḍamaru is held in the upper right hand.

According to some mythological accounts, Śiva, at the request of the gods in heaven, is said to have danced with power and grace—a rare combination indeed—using the ḍamaru and sounding it fourteen times. Each time, the sound that emerged, formed a specific pattern, giving rise to the fourteen basic aphorisms of Sanskrit grammar (called Māheśvara-sūtras, like ‘a-i-uṇ,’ ‘ṛ-lṛk’ and so on). Consequently the symbolical meaning of the ḍamaru in Śiva’s hand is sound or alphabets or grammar or language. It may also represent the ākāśa or the ether principle, the first of the five basic elements in the process of creation of the world.
See also ŚIVA.

Damayantī is one of the five ideal ladies extolled for her wifely virtues along with Sītā and Sāvitrī. As per the story given in the Vanaparva (chapter 52 onwards, called Nalopākhyāna) of the Mahābhārata, she was the daughter of the king Bhīmabhūpala (of Vidarbha) and the wife of the king Nala (of Niṣadha).
For more details see NALA.
Giving gifts to worthy persons has been considered as a meritorious act of great value by all the important religions of the world. The most common Sanskrit word for giving gifts is ‘dāna.’

Having had its origin in the Ṛgveda itself, the concept has gradually evolved to an astonishing degree of details as also finesse over the centuries. It has been extolled as equal to tapas or austerity and as a primary religious duty of this Kaliyuga or Iron-age.

The concept first appears in the Ṛgveda (1.125.6) as dakṣiṇā or sacrificial fee to be paid to the priests and the gifts of cows and gold to deserving persons. Anna-dāna or giving food to hungry beings has also been extolled there highly (10.117).

The Upaniṣads describe dāna as a religious duty and as a discipline that helps one to conquer one’s greedy nature. The Bhagavadgītā (16.1; 17.20-22) calls it as a divine quality and classifies it into three categories.

However, it is in the dharmaśāstras (independent compendiums on the various aspects of dharma, as related to varṇa and āśrama) and the purāṇas that the meticulously worked out details about dāna are met with.

Dāna may be nitya (obligatory dailyduty), naimittika (occasional), kāmya (desire-motivated) or vimala (pure). Giving food to hungry beings as a part of daily duties, gifting of useful things on special occasions like the periods of eclipses, presenting cows or other prescribed things as a part of rituals performed with desires and donations conferred upon persons of saintly character with the sole object of pleasing God are, respectively, the examples for these four categories mentioned above.
Apart from this, it is also emphasised that dāna should be given unostentatiously and unknown to others.
Since dāna has been considered as a religious act and has also acquired a ritualistic colour, certain rules and regulations, some formalities, have come to be associated with the same.
The dātā or the giver of gifts must be free from incurable diseases and heinous sins, be virtuous and clean, and must have acquired his wealth by right means.

The receiver must really be in need of what he is asking for, and these may be basic things required for a living like food, clothing, shelter or money. Persons of evil or doubtful character like gamblers, cheats, drunkards or criminals should not be helped with gifts.

It is essential that the giver must have śraddhā or faith in the act of giving as religious or meritorious. It is this that really matters and not the quality or the quantity, though a minimum standard is expected to make it really useful.
The dharmaśāstras vehemently oppose the gifts made by persons who have amassed wealth by unrighteous means. The receiver too should never accept them if he knows about it!

A householder should never give gifts beyond his means and should not make his family and dependents suffer on account of it. Generally ten per cent of the earnings is given as the limit for giving gifts.

Mention is also made of certain things which should not be given nor accepted as gifts. No one can gift away things that do not rightfully belong to him—as for instance, things that have been borrowed from others or kept in one’s safe keeping!

Similarly there are restrictions with regard to accepting things if they are against one’s svadharma or sense of righteousness and prescribed duties. For example, a brāhmaṇa devoted to Vedic learning and a purely spiritual life, should not accept weapons or intoxicating substances even if offered.

The religious works prescribe certain periods or times as very auspicious for giving gifts. Among them are the two solstices (summer and winter), days of eclipses of the sun and the moon, new-moon and full-moon days as also important festival days.
Gifts given in places of pilgrimage are also extolled highly.
Objects once given away as a gift should never be taken back. This applies even to promises of gifts.
Gifts given by mentally deranged persons or those suffering from very serious illnesses or immature young children are considered invalid for obvious reasons.

The dharmaśāstras and the purāṇas eulogise certain special gifts like godāna (gift of cows) and suvarṇadāna (gift of gold) as also tulāpuruṣa (weighing a person against the things to be gifted and then give them away).
Gift of knowledge, especially spiritual wisdom, has been considered as the highest and the best gift.
To summarise:

ul.li: Giving dāna or gifts is a sacred act that helps one to earn religious merit.
One can give gifts only from what one has earned by right means.
One should never give beyond one’s means and capacity.
Things given should be useful to the donee.
Rules concerning time, place and occasion should be observed as far as possible.

description.p: Depiction of the conflict between the forces of good and evil is a common phenomenon seen in many cultures and civilisations of the world. In the Hindu scriptures including the mythological works, such conflicts are always described as wars between the suras and the asuras or the devas and the dānavas.

These ‘anti-gods’ or evil beings are described by various names such as asuras, daityas, dānavas and rākṣasas. Asuras are those addicted to sense-pleasures and hence opposed to all spiritual values and ways of life. Daityas and dānavas are, respectively, the sons of Diti and Danu, two of the thirteen wives of the sage Kaśyapa, one of the Prajāpatis or progenitors of mankind. Strangely enough, the devas or gods are also the sons of Kaśyapa, but from his virtuous wife Aditi. (Hence the name ‘āditeyas’ for the devas.)
The rākṣasas are the children of Khasā the father, again, being Kaśyapa.
Sometimes, in the mythological lore, all these three—the daityas, the dānavas and the rākṣasas—are bracketed and treated as one type.

Perhaps, the daityas and the dānavas may be taken as archetypes of races, physically stronger and more prone to violence, though, even among them there have been good ones like Prahlāda and Bali. The rākṣasas could be classed as even one shade worse, as evil-doers.
See also ASURAS.

head.note: (‘[that] by which punishment is [meted out];’ ‘[that] by which control [is exercised].’)

description.p: The word ‘daṇḍa’ is one of the commonest terms that we come across in the dharmaśāstras and allied works. Etymologically, it means anything by which control is exercised, including punishment.

In its simplest form it means a stick or a rod. The stick that a Vedic student or an itinerant monk keeps constantly with him for protection in emergencies is a ‘daṇḍa’. It also acts as a symbol of self-control.
In the purāṇas, it is the rod of death or punishment, in the hands of Yama, the god of death. Consequently he is also called ‘daṇḍadhara’ or the wielder of the daṇḍa.

A daṇḍa can also be in the form of a long staff, a cudgel or a stick often unornamented, and is shown in the hands of some images like those of Kārttikeya (or Subrahmaṇya), the minor deities such as Maṅgala, Śukra and Śani (planet-deities), Kapila and even the goddess Rati (wife of Kāmadeva or cupid).

As applied to a king it can mean the armed forces, one of the seven rājyāṅgas or constituents of a State. As one of the four ‘upāyas’ or means of achieving the desired end, especially while dealing with hostile kings, it means war, but as a last resort.
The word is sometimes used as a unit of time, an equivalent of ‘ghaṭikā,’ and is equal to 24 minutes.

Standard works on Haṭhayoga like the Gheraṇḍa Saṁhitā give various cleansing processes, generally called ‘dhauti’, to purify the body and make it healthy and strong. It is only such a healthy body that is fit to practise other forms of yoga like Rājayoga.
The daṇḍadhauti is one such process and is one of three classed under hṛd-dhauti. (See HṚDDHAUTI also.)

The yogi takes the plantain stalk or the stalk of a turmeric plant or cane and thrusts it slowly into the esophagus and then draws it out slowly. By this process the phlegm, bile and other impurities are expelled out of the mouth.
Like the other practices of Haṭhayoga, this too should be practised under the direct guidance of an expert teacher, as otherwise, it may prove to be dangerous.
Prince Daṇḍaka, one of the sons of the famous king Ikṣvāku, is a fine example to show how a person can render even a fertile land into a desert, by his sinful behaviour. See DAṆḌAKĀRAṆYA for details.
According to the Rāmāyaṇa of Vālmīki, the Daṇḍakāraṇya is the forest where Śrī Rāma, the banished king of Ayodhyā, spent most of his years of exile.

Daṇḍaka was one of the hundred princes, sons of the king Ikṣvāku, who had been assigned to rule over this area. His villainous nature made him molest Arajā, the daughter of his own guru, Śukrācārya. Consequently, he incurred the wrath of Śukrācārya who cursed him. As a result, Daṇḍaka and his entire entourage was decimated and the kingdom itself reduced to a barren land, leaving a small part. Hence the name Daṇḍaka or Daṇḍakāraṇya to this region. It was also known—later on—as Janasthāna since several sages (jana = people) came there and settled down.
The area around the modern town of Nāsik (in Maharashtra) has now been identified as a part of Daṇḍakāraṇya.

head.note: (‘[that which helps] to lead [people] by the power of punishment’)

description.p: Any civilised society needs a government and someone to head it and run it. In the ancient and medieval days, the king (called ‘rājā’) was the pivot of the governmental system. The science and art of governance was given several appellations, of which the words ‘rājadharma’ and ‘daṇḍanīti’ were most common.
The Arthaśāstra of Kauṭilya (300 B. C.) deals with the two subjects vārtā (economics) and daṇḍanīti (statecraft) as one unit.
See ARTHAŚĀSTRA for details.

head.note: (‘one [who holds the] daṇḍa or the staff in his hand’)

description.p: In the Hindu mythological and iconographical literature, this word can apply to Yama (the god of death and the deity presiding over the southern quarter) and also to the god Subrahmaṇya (variously known as Skanda, Kumāra and Kārttikeya), more to the latter. He is shown as holding a long cudgel or staff (daṇḍa) in his right hand and the left hand resting on the left loin. He is also known as Daṇḍāyudhapāṇi, the meaning of this word too being the same.
See SUBRAHMAṆYA for details.

Though, literally, the word means anyone who holds a daṇḍa or a staff in his hand, it is a technical term used to indicate the saṁnyāsins or monks. The daṇḍa or the staff which is a part and parcel of their monastic apparel is a constant reminder that the saṁnyāsin has to be ever vigilant to practise dama or self-control in all its aspects.
The daṇḍīs are of two types: the ekadaṇḍīs and the tridaṇḍīs. Whereas the former hold only one staff, the latter hold one, made of three sticks tied into one unit.
The single staff reminds its wearer that he has to keep his mind always under control and the three-in-one staff symbolises the control of the body, the speech and the mind.
See also SAṀNYĀSINS.

Sanskrit or saṁskṛta is not only an ancient language but also very rich in its various aspects of grammar, poetics and literature. Daṇḍin (6th century A. D.) was one of the earliest writers on poetics. He probably lived in the Vidarbha region of Maharashtra. Three works are attributed to him: Kāvyādarśa (poetics), Daśa-kumāracarita (a collection of romantic tales) and Chandoviciti (prosody).
See also ALAṄKĀRAŚĀSTRA.

Hindu sages were very particular about personal hygiene since cleanliness of the body and the surroundings was conducive to the cleanliness and peace of mind. Hence, the writers of the dharma-śāstras have dealt with this aspect of one’s life—generally grouped under the titles āhnika and ācāra—in meticulous detail.

Dantadhāvana or cleaning one’s teeth is one of the earliest acts in one’s daily routine. It is generally done with a small piece of a twig with its bark, taken from certain specified plants or trees (having medicinal properties) after shaping it like a toothbrush by crushing one of its ends. It is interesting to note that even this simple act of cleaning one’s teeth has to be accompanied by the chanting of certain mantras, the main purport of which is prayer for a long life, health and strength as also good memory and intelligence.
It is to be repeated, though in a modified form, in the night also.

Works on Haṭhayoga like the Gheraṇḍasaṁhitā describe certain processes for cleansing the body known as ‘dhautis’ to make it fit for Rājayoga. One such is the dantadhauti, aimed at cleansing the teeth, the root of the tongue, the two holes of the ear and the sinuses.
The practical process has to be learnt directly under the guidance of a competent teacher.
See also DHAUTI and ṢAṬKARMAS.

Also spelt as Dantavaktra (‘One whose mouth is full of teeth,’ i.e., one with protruded teeth) was the prince of the country of Karūṣa (in Kaliṅga, identi-fied with the modern Orissa). He was a nephew of Vasudeva, father of Śrī Kṛṣṇa. Being a close friend of Śiśupāla who blasphemed Śrī Kṛṣṇa during the Rājasūya sacrifice of the Pāṇḍavas and got killed by him, he invaded Dvārakā along with his another friend Sālva. However, he was killed by Śrī Kṛṣṇa in the duel. At the time of his death, a light emerged out of his body and got merged in Śrī Kṛṣṇa. This is because he was actually Jaya (one of the two gate keepers of Vaikuṇṭha) reborn as Dantavakra due to the curse of the sages, Sanatkumāra and others.
See also JAYA and ŚIŚUPĀLA.

Right from the Vedic times certain varieties of grass like the darbha have been considered as sacred and have been used in the sacrificial rites. Since a dry piece of this grass can cut our skin (dṛ = to cut) it might have got this name. Sometimes it has been identified with the kuśa grass and sometimes described as different. But in today’s ritualistic practices the two names refer to the same (kuśa) grass.
In the Atharvaveda (6.43) it is mentioned that it can be used as an amulet for protection against certain evils.
Works on the Āyurveda predicate several uses to this grass such as appetising, purification of blood and semen, curing of certain diseases like jaundice and herpes.
The botanical names given for this grass are: Saccharum cylindricum or Poa cynosuroides.
See also KUŚA.
The word ‘darpaṇa’ is one of the common terms that indicates a mirror. It has been so called since it increases the ‘darpa’ or the pride of a beautiful or a handsome person!
A mirror is one of the several objects that is shown in the hands of a female figurine or a goddess, sculptured according to the rules of the Mūrtiśilpaśāstra or Hindu Iconography.
It is also one of the aṣṭamaṅgalas—eight objects signifying auspiciousness—normally used on auspicious occasions like the coronation of a king.
See also AṢṬAMAṄGALAS.

Though the word means ‘seeing’, it is often used in a technical sense, indicating any system of philosophy. Generally the Indian philosophical systems are called ‘darśanas’ since they claim to have been based on the ‘seeing’ or the ‘experiencing’ of the final truths.
These darśanas are classified into two broad groups: the āstika-darśanas and the nāstika-darśanas. The former accept the authority of the Vedas whereas the latter do not.

The former, being six in number, is often called ‘ṣaḍdarśanas’ (ṣaṭ = six) They are: the Nyāyadarśana of Gautama the Vaiśeṣikadarśana of Kaṇāda the Sāṅkhyadarśana of Kapila the Yogadarśana of Patañjali the Mīmāṁsādarśana of Jaimini and the Vedāntadarśana of Bādarāyaṇa. The latter are: the Cārvākadarśana of Cārvāka the Jainadarśana and the Bauddhadarśana.

The last two represent the various philosophical systems of Jainism and Buddhism. The first represents materialism of various shades and hues. Though the work itself is not available now, excerpts from it have been quoted in the treatises of other writers.
See under each title for details.

Vedic sacrifices—called yajñas and yāgas—are an ancient institution. One of its varieties is ‘iṣṭi,’ a sacrifice performed with the four priests adhvaryu, āgnīdhra, hotṛ and brahman. (See under each title for details.) The Darśapūrṇamāsa is a prakṛti (an archetype) in this iṣṭi group and is obligatory.

The words ‘darśa’ and ‘pūrṇamāsa’ actually stand for the new-moon and the full-moon days. Hence, the Vedic rites to be performed on these days have also been named ‘Darśa’ and ‘Pūrṇamāsa’. The two are identical in almost all respects except for some minor variations. Consequently, they are often clubbed together and called, ‘Darśapūrṇamāsa.’
The Darśa sacrifice is done on the new-moon day and the day next to it (pratipad). The Pūrṇamāsa is performed on the full-moon day and the following day.
The only difference in the procedure between these two sacrifices is that the puroḍāśa (rice-cake) is offered to Indra and Agni in the Darśa whereas the same is offered to Agni-Soma in the Pūrṇamāsa.

The preliminaries like shaving, bathing and fasting are done by the sacrificer on the day called ‘upavasaha’ (= fasting and living near the fire). This is followed by anvādhāna (offering of three pieces of sacrificial wood into the fire). The other rites to follow are: piṇḍapitṛyajña (obsequial rites for the forefathers up to three generations); usual daily Agnihotra; preparing the curdled milk for offering on the next day; preparing the puroḍāśa (rice-cakes) for offering; repetition of the sāmidhenī verses (eleven verses from the Ṛgveda, mostly from the third Maṇḍala, aimed at kindling the fire); āghāra libation (wherein the adhvaryu pours ghee into the fire moving the spoon all over, with appropriate mantras) and five prayāja and two ājyabhāga oblations (preliminary offerings).

Then, the principle offerings are made with puroḍāśa (rice-cakes) to the accompaniment of puro’nuvākyas (call or invitation to the deities by the hotṛ priest) and yājyās (technical formulae of consecration chanted by the hotṛ priest while the adhvaryu priest offers a libation of ghee).
In the Darśa, eleven offerings of Puroḍāśa kept in small earthen plates are offered to Indra and Agni. In the Pūrṇa-māsa, the offerings are made to Agni and Soma.

This is followed by the sviṣṭakṛt offering (a secondary offering to Agni by whose goodwill the sacrifice has been successfully done) and iḍābhakṣaṇa (eating the portions cut off from all the main offerings) by the priests.
Then comes anuyāja (three supplementary offerings) followed by sūktavāka (speech of adoration by the hotṛ priest) and śaṁyuvāka (formula of benediction, also by the hotṛ priest).

After a few more minor rites like the patnīsaṁyāja (offerings to the consorts of the deities), removal of the yoktra (a belt of muñja grass), prāyaścittas (expiatory rites) and viṣṇukrama (ceremonially taking four steps with appropriate mantras, by the yajamāna or the sacrificer) the whole sacrifice comes to a close.
See also VEDIC SACRIFICES.

Unlike the other deities, Śiva (one of the three aspects of the Supreme, the aspect of involution or withdrawal or destruction of the world) is invariably worshipped in the form of a liṅga. A liṅga is an icon, cylindrical in shape, with a spherical top. Since God is beyond name and form and since we cannot conceive of an abstract principle like him without the aid of concrete symbols, a spherical surface or emblem is perhaps the nearest approach to him.

‘Dāru’ means wood. Liṅgas carved out of wood are called ‘dārujaliṅgas’. They are of the sthāvara or stationary type. The minimum and maximum heights prescribed for such liṅgas are 16 and 144 aṅgulas. (One aṅgula is roughly 1.9 cms. or 0.75 inch.)

The dārujaliṅgas are classified into 9 or even 33 varieties, depending upon their height. For instance, if the makara-liṅga is 16 aṅgulas in height (the minimum height permitted), the daṇḍaliṅga is 80 aṅgulas and the phalodbhava liṅga is 144 aṅgulas (the maximum permissible height).

As regards the type of wood out of which it is carved, about 20 varieties are recommended. Some of them are: śamī (Prosopsis spieigera), devadāru (Cedrus deodara), candana (sandalwood), bilva (Aegle marmelos), aśvattha (peepul tree) and aśoka (Saraca asoca).
See also LIṄGA.

The word ‘dāsa’ occurs in the Ṛgveda (5.34.6; 6.22.10) many times and refers to the enemies of the Vedic people. Since these dāsas were, in many cases, reduced to slavery, the term has been used in the sense of a ‘slave’ also. (See SLAVERY.)
In later literature, the word refers to a paid servant.
While naming a person, this word was used as a suffix for persons belonging to the śūdra caste.

In the devotional literature, this expression has been widely used to indicate a devotee as a servant of God or as a servant of the devotees of God. For instance: Rāmadāsa, Kṛṣṇadāsa, Caṇḍī-dāsa and so on.

head.note: (‘[spiritual and philosophical] wisdom [as taught by Samartha] Rāmadāsa’)

description.p: Samartha Rāmadās (A. D. 1608-1681) was a great saint of Maharashtra. He was the guru (preceptor and guide) of Chatrapati Śivājī (A. D. 1627-1680). It was he who was primarily responsible for the rejuvenation of Hindu religion and society by inspiring Śivājī.
He has left behind him two immortal works both in Marāṭhi: Manāce Śloka and Dāsabodha.

The work Dāsabodha comprises twenty daśakas or decads. Each of these daśakas consists of ten long sections called samāsas. The samāsas again, have a number of ovīs or metrical stanzas, their total number being 7756.
The contents in brief may be given as follows:
prayers to Gaṇeśa, Sarasvatī, guru and saints; greatness and usefulness of human birth.
descriptions of various types of persons, from fools to wise persons; the three guṇas sattva, rajas and tamas; characte-ristics of a good and holy person.
various evils in worldly life; tāpatrayas or three kinds of sufferings; death and detachment.
navavidha bhakti (nine modes of devotion); four kinds of mukti or liberation.
characteristics of a good guru (spiritual teacher) and of a good śiṣya or disciple; different kinds of teachings on sādhanā (spiritual practice); signs of a siddha or a perfected being.
on Brahman, māyā and sṛṣṭi or creation; worship of God with form; denial of this world which is seen but does not really exist; indescribable nature of Brahman.
fourteen kinds of Brahman; offsetting the effects of dvaita or sense of duality; on śravaṇa (listening to the Vedāntic truths); death and jīvanmukta (one who is liberated even while living).
on God; various kinds of doubts; the pañcamahābhūtas (the five elements); on mokṣa (liberation) and the perfected being.
various kinds of doubts and their answers; description of the inner state of a man of knowledge.
the consciousness in all, is one and the same; creation and dissolution; prakṛti (nature) and puruṣa (soul).

on creation and dissolution of the world; four kinds of manifestations of God; how a sādhaka (spiritual aspirant) should lead his life; behaviour of a true leader of a society; nature of the Self within.
on devotion; viveka (discrimination) and vairāgya (renunciation); need for self-effort; how to become great.
philosophical truths through a story; on God the creator, various opinions; need to protect the purity of one’s mind.

desirelessness necessary; a sādhaka (aspirant) should live by bhikṣā (begging); efficacy of singing God’s names; greatness of a householder’s life and the need to keep it pure; remember God constantly.

how to live in this world, in peace and harmony with others; knowledge makes one superior to others; Brahman as the origin of the world; all activities of prakṛti (nature) and puruṣa (individual soul) are transient; interpretation of the mahāvākyas of the Upaniṣads (like tat-tvam-asi).
hymns devoted to Vālmīki, Sūrya (sun-god) and the five elements like the earth and water; on the ātman or the Self; various types of upāsanā or meditation.

Supreme God (Jagadīśvara) manifests himself as various souls; Śiva and Śakti are at the root of all beings, male and female; doubts are obstacles in the path of understanding Vedāntic truths; explanation of ajapājapa (process of breathing associated with the repetition of the mantra so’ham); four kinds of bodies.

This section deals with miscellaneous topics like various gods—Gaṇapati, Brahmā, Veṅkaṭeśa, Rāma, Kṛṣṇa and so on—as different manifestations of the Antarātman (the Ātman inside), company of jñānis (persons of spiritual wisdom), importance of human body in the path of spiritual progress and so on.
on handwriting and scholarship; condemnation of laziness; signs of a wise person; methods of giving good advice; efficiency in work and management.

discussion about pūrṇa and apūrṇa (what is complete and what is incomplete); the three guṇas; upāsanā or meditation on God with form; interesting details about 84 lakhs of species of living beings; on the ātman; body compared to a field; on Parabrahman (the Absolute).
The work is extremely popular especially in Maharashtra.
A ceremonial recitation and discourses on it are considered as a religious and meritorious act.
See also RĀMADĀSA (SAMARTHA).
See NAVAGVA for details.
Festivals and sacred days have a very important part to play in popular Hinduism. They often act as a catalytic agent to integrate the various sections of the Hindu society.

One of the minor festivals, observed mostly in North India and also on the banks of the big rivers like Kṛṣṇā, Godāvarī and Narmadā, is the Daśaharā (also called Gaṅgā-daśaharā). It occurs on the tenth day of the bright fortnight (śukla-daśamī) of the month of Jyeṣṭha (May-June). The river Gaṅgā is believed to have descended to the earth on this day. If the day happens to be a Tuesday or a Wednesday it is considered even more auspicious. A bath in the river Gaṅgā, especially at the Daśāśvamedha-ghāṭ of Vārāṇasī or Kāśī (in Uttar Pradesh) on this day is said to destroy ten kinds of sins associated with the body, speech and mind. The bath should be followed by worship of the prescribed deity and giving gifts to worthy persons.

The religion of the Vedic Āryans comprised mostly of the performance of Vedic sacrifices. Out of these, Agnyādheya or Agnyādhāna was a primary rite meant for generating the Vedic fires like the gārhapatya. These fires had to be maintained for life and all other sacrifices had to be performed only in them.

The ‘daśahotāraḥ’ is actually a formula of ten sentences taken from the Taittirīya Āraṇyaka (3.1). These mantras have to be repeated when the upper araṇi is placed on the lower one before churning, for generating the fire.
These ten short sentences (oṁ cittiḥ sruk; cittam ājyam; vāg vediḥ and so on) actually identify ten different parts of the human body with ten things connected with the sacrifice.

In the religio-philosophical literature of Hinduism both bhakti (devotion) and jñāna (knowledge) have been given equal prominence. The various teachers of bhakti, over the centuries, gave the common masses a simple philosophy of life to live by. This they did through their teachings, mostly in the form of devotional songs.

The tradition of devotion with its popular religion and ethics, was originated in North India by the musician-saints like Tulasīdās (A. D. 1532-1623), Kabīr (A. D. 1440-1518), Nānak (A. D. 1469-1539), Mīrābāī (A. D. 1450-1547) and others. In Maharashtra, it was Sant Jñāneśvar (13th cent. A. D.), Ekanāth (A. D. 1533-1599), Tukārām (A. D. 1607-1694), Rāmadās (A. D. 1608-1681) and a host of others who did the same. In Bengal, Śrīkṛṣṇa Caitanya (A. D. 1485-1533), Rāmaprasād (A. D. 1720-1781) and Kamalākānta (A. D. 1800 ?) were the important teachers.

In South India, the Āḷvārs (7th to 9th centuries A. D.) and Nāyanmārs (7th and 8th centuries A. D.) spread the cult of bhakti in the Tamil country. The Śiva-śaraṇas (12th cent. A. D.) and the Haridāsas (15th cent. A. D.) were the pioneers of the bhakti movement in Karnataka.

The Haridāsa movement comprised two parallel but closely knit units, generally called the ‘Vyāsakūṭa’ and the ‘Dāsakūṭa’. The former was nourished by the saṁnyāsins of the Mādhva school like Śrīpādarāya (15th cent. A. D.) and Vyāsa-rāya (A. D. 1447-1539) whereas the latter was sustained by Purandaradāsa (A. D. 1484-1564), Kanakadāsa (15th cent. A. D.), Vijayadāsa (A. D. 1687-1755) and other householder-devotees of the same school.
Though the Vyāsakūṭa derived its name from Vyāsarāya (also known as Vyāsatīrtha) who was responsible for the phenomenal growth of both the units, it was Śrīpādarāya who was the pioneer of both.

The saṁnyāsin teachers were great scholars both in Sanskrit and in Kannaḍa (the vernacular of Karnataka). They composed scholarly works in the former and popular devotional songs in the latter. The Haridāsas—though quite a few of them also were great scholars—concentrated on spreading the cult of devotion and the Dvaita Vedānta of Madhvācārya (A. D. 1197-1276) as also simple ethical principles through their songs which became very popular over the centuries.
Apart from Purandaradāsa and Vijayadāsa, Gopāladāsa (A. D. 1721-1762) and Jagannāthadāsa (A. D. 1728-1809) too have contributed profusely to the Haridāsa literature.

Some of the other Haridāsas who contributed significantly to the Dāsakūṭa and the bhakti movement are: Vaikuṇṭha-dāsa, Prasanna-Veṅkaṭadāsa, Timmaṇṇa-dāsa, Mohanadāsa, Heḷavanakaṭṭe Giri-yamma (a lady-saint), Kallūru Subbaṇṇa-dāsa, Aijīdāsa and so on.
The Vijayanagara city and the Raichur district of Karnataka were the main centres of origin and activities of these Haridāsas.

The compositions of these Haridāsas are legion. Their chief characteristic is simplicity. They express the profound truths of Vedānta in a simple language and urge the people to lead a God-centred life even while discharging one’s normal duties in the world. The topics generally dealt with are: description of God’s form and beauty (almost always as Viṣṇu or Kṛṣṇa), childhood pranks of Kṛṣṇa, various devotional practices like repetition of the divine name or singing the glories of God, moral principles like satya (truth) and dharma (righteous living), evil nature of the evil ones (in order to avoid such conduct), some paurāṇic stories as also autobiographical references, activism as well as dependence on God and a host of other miscellaneous subjects.
The contribution of the Dāsakūṭa to Hindu religion and culture through the life and literature of the various Haridāsas is considerable.

Ten aspects of Śakti are sometimes described in tāntric works. They are termed ‘Daśamahāvidyā’s. These are the representations of transcendental know-ledge and power, the sources of all that is to be known.

The first is Kālī, the goddess of time, that destroys everything. Tārā, the second, is the power of the golden embryo (Hiraṇya-garbha) from which the universe evolves. She also stands for void or the boundless space. The third is Ṣoḍaśī. The word literally means ‘one who is sixteen years old.’ She is the personification of fullness, of perfection. Bhuvaneśvarī, the fourth Vidyā, represents the forces of the material world, whereas Bhairavī the fifth, stands for desires and temptations leading to destruction and death. Then comes Chinnamastā, the naked deity holding her own severed head in hand and drinking her own blood! She simply represents the continued state of self-sustenance of the created world in which are seen continuous self-destruction and self-renewal, in a cyclic order. Dhūmāvatī, the seventh, personifies the destruction of the world by fire, when only smoke (Dhūma) from its ashes remains. She is sometimes identified with Alakṣmī or Jyeṣṭhādevī. The eighth Vidyā, Bagalā, is a crane-headed goddess, and represents the ugly side of living creatures like jealousy, hatred and cruelty. Mātaṅgī, the ninth, is the embodiment of the power of domination. The tenth and the last, Kamalā, is the pure consciousness of the Self, bestowing boons and allaying the fears of the supplicants. She is identified with Lakṣmī, the goddess of fortune.

head.note: (‘those [belonging to the order] of ten names’)

description.p: Saṁnyāsa or monasticism is a very ancient institution. The dharmaśāstras list it as the fourth and last stage in a man’s life. (See ĀŚRAMA for details.)

Organised monasticism into a regular Order (in Hinduism)—though common among the Buddhists—can be attributed to Śaṅkara’s (A. D. 788-820) pioneering efforts. He established four centres of his monastic order at Badarī (in Uttar Pradesh), Dvārakā (in Gujarat), Purī (in Orissa) and Śṛṅgerī (in Karnataka). They have been christened as Jyotir Maṭha (or Jośi Maṭha), Kālikā Maṭha, Govardhana Maṭha and Śāradā Maṭha respectively. He is said to have appointed his four chief disciples as the first abbots of these Maṭhas as follows: Toṭaka (Jyotir Maṭha), Padmapāda (Kālikā Maṭha), Hastāmalaka (Govardhana Maṭha) and Sureśvara (Śṛṅgerī Śāradā Maṭha).

He also organised his saṁnyāsin disciples and the tradition of ascetics through them, into ten orders, known as ‘daśanāmī-sampradāya’, (daśa = ten, nāmī = with name; hence ‘daśanāmī’) of the following titles:

ol.li: Araṇya;
Āśrama;
Bhāratī;
Giri;
Parvata;
Purī;
Sarasvatī;
Sāgara;
Tīrtha and
Vana.

description.p: Every saṁnyāsin of these orders adds to his adopted name one of these ten titles as a suffix. For instance: Vidyāraṇya, Nṛsiṁhabhārati, Ānandagiri, Totāpurī, Ānandatīrtha and so on.
These ten orders have been specifically aligned with the four maṭhas as follows:

Jyotirmaṭha—Giri, Parvata and Sāgara.
Śāradāmaṭha—Āśrama and Tīrtha.
Govardhanamaṭha—Araṇya and Vana.
Śṛṅgerīmaṭha—Bhāratī, Purī and Sarasvatī.

Though it is difficult to derive any definite conclusions as to the meanings of these ten terms which may not be related to their normal meanings, traditional interpretations and explanations are on the following lines:

tr.td: indicates a monk living in an araṇya or a forest, completely detached from mundane affairs.
indicates a monk living in an āśrama or a hermitage thus freed from the botheration of wandering.
indicates one laden with learning, who has thrown away all burdens.
indicates one who is steady like a mountain (= giri) or one who lives at the foot of a mountain.
indicates one who lives at the foot of hills and has steadfast knowledge regarding the transient nature of the world.
indicates one who is full of the knowledge of Brahman. (Purī ascetics seem to have been considered as the highest among the monks.)
indicates one who is greatly learned and also an adept in yoga.
indicates one who has dived into the depths of the ocean of knowledge and collected the gems of truth.
indicates one who bathes in the confluence of the three rivers of the knowledge and the realisation of the truth ‘tat tvam asi’ (‘That thou art’).
indicates one who has transcended all the snares of desires and lives quietly in a forest.

description.p: The Daśanāmī monks are further classified into four sampradāyas or traditional sects or groups without reference to their orders, but as assigned to the four monastic centres. They are:
These terms (though they appear to be a little fanciful) respectively indicate freedom from

ol.li: desire for sense-pleasures;
desire for all enjoyments;
desire for worldly possessions;
tendencies hurtful to creatures.

description.p: Each of these four monastic centres, again, has its own devatā and devī (tutelary deities), kṣetra (place of pilgrimage), tīrtha (holy river), gotra (spiritual lineage), Veda, svādhyāya (study of parti-cular Upaniṣads) and a mahāvākya (sentence for contemplation chosen from the Upaniṣads). The table given in page no. 467 gives all the details in a nutshell.

In establishing the Daśanāmī order of monks, as attached to the four maṭhas, Śaṅkara showed remarkable social awareness also which was badly needed during his times. These maṭhas were charged with the task of caring for the welfare of the people of the regions assigned to them, through tours and discourses.
See also MONASTICISM, SAṀNYĀSINS and ŚAṄKARA.

Vedic sacrifices were very common during the early phase of Hinduism. Among the various yāgas or sacrifices, the Somayāgas were performed with the soma juice, the soma plant being a special kind of creeper. This creeper had to be crushed for extracting the juice and then filtered. The strainer was the daśāpavitra and the vessel into which the juice would get collected, the droṇakalaśa.
The daśāpavitra was made of the wool cut from a living ram, the wool being white. The dimensions had to conform to the directions given in the Śrautasūtras.
Festivals and sacred days, which are the popular manifestations of any religion, are legion in Hinduism.

One of the major festivals observed throughout India is the Dasarā festival. It is celebrated from the Āśvayuja śukla pratipad to the daśamī (the bright half of the month Āśvayuja or Āśvina, generally falling in September-October), for nine days (Navarātri, festival of nine nights) or ten days (dasarā = daśa + ahar = ten days). This festival takes many forms. In Bengal, Bihar and Orissa it is celebrated as the Durgāpūjā, worship of the Divine Mother Durgā, usually in a clay image. In Uttar Pradesh and some other northern States it is observed as Rāmalīlā, a re-enactment of the Rāma story.
In Karnataka, it is a multifestival, comprising Sarasvatīpūjā on the saptamī, Durgāpūjā on the aṣṭamī and Āyudhapūjā (worship of weapons and implements) on the navamī days.
The tenth day known as Vijaya-daśamī, again, is observed as the day for immersion of the Durgā images after the Durgāpūjā, wherever it is observed.
Where Rāmalīlā is enacted, Vijaya-daśamī is celebrated as the day of victory of Rāma over Rāvaṇa, the demon-king.

It is also the day on which kings used to start on expeditions of victory or conquests for expansion. Worship of the śamīvṛkṣa (Prosopis spicigera) and the royal weapons like the sword, as also the royal horse and the elephant were part of the Vijayadaśamī festival.

As per the account of various foreign travellers like Abdur Razak (A. D. 1413-1482), Domingos Paes (A. D. 1520) and Fernao Nuniz (A. D. 1536), the Dasarā was being celebrated in all pomp and glory as a State festival with the king being given the prime place, in Vijayanagara, the capital of the Vijayanagara empire. After the fall of the empire, it was taken up by the kings of Mysore State, and celebrated in a grand manner. The celebrations are continued even now, though as a peoples’ festival.
See also DURGĀPŪJĀ, RĀMALĪLĀ and VIJAYADAŚAMĪ.
See SUDĀSA.

Ancient Hindu mythology traces all the kings of Bharatavarṣa (India) to two primeval races: The Sūryavaṁśa and the Candravaṁśa. Since Ikṣvāku and Raghu were the most outstanding emperors of the Sūryavaṁśa, the race has also been known by their names as Ikṣvākuvaṁśa or Raghuvaṁśa. But, the very best of all the kings of this race was Rāma or Śrī Rāma, considered and worshipped as an incarnation of Lord Viṣṇu himself. Daśaratha was the father of this Rāma and the son of another great king of this lineage, Aja.

Though the impression created by the Ayodhyākāṇḍa of the Rāmāyaṇa of Vālmīki is that Daśaratha was a weak king, a prisoner of his infatuation for his wife Kaikeyī and a doting father, he was actually a great hero and a good ruler in his younger days. The very word ‘Daśaratha’ which means ‘one who could drive his ratha or chariot in daśa or ten directions’, is proof enough of his valour.

He was the king of Kosala with its capital at Ayodhyā. He had three queens—Kausalyā, Sumitrā, and Kaikeyī—who were the daughters of the kings Bhānumanta, Śūrasena and Aśvapati Kekaya respectively. A cabinet of eight distinguished ministers, under the able guidance of Sumantra, assisted him in administration.
He had a daughter called Śāntādevī, but no male issues, Śāntādevi had been adopted by the king Romapāda as his daughter and had been married to the sage Ṛṣyaśṛṅga.

On the advice of the royal preceptor Vasiṣṭha, Daśaratha performed the Putra-kāmeṣṭi sacrifice with Ṛṣyaśṛṅga as the head-priest and was blessed with four sons. Rāma (from Kausalyā), Bharata (from Kaikeyī), Lakṣmaṇa and Śatrughna (from Sumitrā).
The four princes grew up into fine young men under the able tutelage of the highly competent sage Vasiṣṭha.

Once, the sage Viśvāmitra arrived at the court of Daśaratha and requested him to send Rāma and Lakṣmaṇa with him to guard the sacrifice he was conducting, against the ruinous attacks of the demons Mārīca and Subāhu. Though Daśaratha was at first unwilling, he later on acceded to the request of the sage (on the intervention of Vasiṣṭha, who knew better) and sent his two sons.

After some heroic exploits and excellent training in the arts of war and peace under Viśvāmitra, the youths arrived at the capital Mithilā of the king Janaka. When the Śivadhanus, the mythical bow of god Śiva, was broken by Rāma, to win the hand of princess Sītā, Janaka’s daughter, Daśaratha arrived soon at Mithilā with his entourage and took part in the marriage of Rāma and Sītā, and also of the other three princes with suitable brides.

As he was getting old, he decided to instal Rāma as the Yuvarāja (crown-prince). When the preparations were in an advanced stage, Kaikeyī, under the wicked spell of her malicious maid Mantharā, demanded the fulfilment of the two boons Daśaratha had given her long back. They were: making her son Bharata the king and banishing Rāma to the forest for fourteen years. Unable, either to change her mind or to accede to her demand, the mortally shocked Daśaratha passed away. Meanwhile Rāma, along with his wife Sītā and brother Lakṣmaṇa had already left for the forest as per Kaikeyī’s words, conveying the ‘order’ of the king and father Daśaratha.
Daśaratha is said to have met this tragic end due to the curse of a sage-couple whose only son he had killed by mistake, long back, in his youth.
As per the description of the Rāmāyaṇa Daśaratha was a good and noble king who had ruled his kingdom righteously.
See also RĀMĀYAṆA.

Over the centuries, the story of Rāmāyaṇa of Vālmīki, has given rise to many other literary works which are faithful adaptations of the original, or, are at variance with it. The Daśarathajātaka, numbered as 461 in the Jātaka Tales series, is one such, belonging to the latter group. In this jātaka, the main story of the Rāmāyaṇa has been retold in a startlingly distorted form.

Daśaratha was the king of Vārāṇasī. Rāmapaṇḍita, Lakṣmaṇakumāra and Sītā-devī were his children by his chief queen. Bharatakumāra was the son of his second wife who became the chief queen after the death of the first. At her behest, to fulfil a boon he had promised earlier he was forced to exile the first three children for 14 years and hand over the kingdom to her son Bharatakumāra. Meanwhile he died. When Rāmapaṇḍita returned after the period of exile was over, he became the king.
It is strange that the Jātaka tale narrates Rāma as having married Sītā who was his own sister!
The view that the Daśarathajātaka must have been based on a much older Rāma story has been thoroughly discounted by scholars of repute, who have shown that the case may just be the reverse!
See also RĀMĀYAṆA.

Hinduism allows the worship of icons or images of deities, not only as their symbolical representations but as the deities themselves, when imbued with their subtle presence through appropriate rites such as āvāhana (inviting) and prāṇapratiṣṭhā (infusing life).

Such images which are generally installed in temples for public worship are to be prepared strictly according to the principles of mūrtiśilpaśāstra or icono-graphy. The basic unit of length used in the sculpturing of images is called ‘tāla’ (or span). It is the measurement of the palm of the hand (from the tip of the middle finger to the wrist) and is equal to the length of the face (from the top of the forehead to the bottom of the chin). This tāla is again divided into 12 equal parts, each part being designated as ‘aṅgula’.
While sculpturing the images, standards are prescribed, based on this tāla (and the aṅgulas). Hence this system is called the ‘tālamāna’ paddhati or system.
If an image is to be ‘daśatāla,’ it simply means that the total height from the bottom of the feet (in the standing posture) to the top of the head should be ten tālas.
The daśatāla measurement is divided into three varieties: uttama (superior), madhyama (middling) and adhama (inferior). The proportions are 124, 120, and 116 aṅgulas respectively.
The daśatāla is the most preferred scale for making the images of the major deities and their female counter parts. It is prescribed for the icons that are worshiped for getting various benefits.
See also MŪRTIŚILPAŚĀSTRA.

To ward off the extraordinary perils to which mankind is prone—may be the visitations from the demons, may be from the human malefactors—and to preserve the socio-ethical order, Lord Viṣṇu whose duty it is to preserve this world, often incarnates himself. Though such incarnations are popularly considered to be ten, there is no limit to their number. Nor are there any restrictions regarding the time and place of their appearance. Whenever dharma declines and adharma prospers he bodies himself forth to restore the balance in the world.

In the Matsyāvatāra (Fish-incarnation), the Lord is said to have saved Manu (the progenitor of mankind) and the Saptarṣis (the seven sages, mind-born sons of Brahmā) along with their wives during the deluge. The world was repopulated through them later on.

Lord Viṣṇu incarnated himself as the Kūrma (the Tortoise) in order to support the mount Mandara which started sinking during the churning of the ocean (samudra-mathana). The gods and demons had jointly undertaken this adventure to get amṛta (nectar) from the ocean.

Next in the series is the Varāhāva-tāra (Boar-incarnation) in which the Lord killed the demon Hiraṇyākṣa and lifted the earth out of the flood waters in which it had been submerged. This may be a symbolic representation of the extrication of the world from the deluge of sin by the power of the Supreme Being.

When Prahlāda, the great devotee of Viṣṇu was being severely tortured by his father, the demon Hiraṇyakaśipu, (who was a non-believer in the existence of an omnipresent and omnipotent God), Narasiṁha (Man-lion) appeared emerging out of the pillar shown by him and killed him. Being a combination of man (the best of higher creatures) and lion (the best of lower creatures) Narasiṁha represents the best of creations. Incidentally this also proves the omnipresence of God. Narasiṁha is especially the embodiment of valour which is a divine attribute and hence worshipped by rulers and warriors. His Mantra is said to be very powerful, capable of destroying enemies and exorcising evil.

When Bali, the grandson of Prahlāda, conquered the three worlds, Indra was deprived of his heavenly kingdom. At the request of Aditi, the mother of Indra, Lord Viṣṇu incarnated as Vāmana (the Dwarf), a young brāhmaṇa boy, and approached Bali who was known for his munificence, for a gift of land that could be covered by three steps. With the first and the second he covered the earth and heaven, and with the third, he pushed down Bali to the netherworld. Hence he is also known as Trivikrama, one who encompassed the world with three big steps.

This myth teaches us that since even God had to resort to the dwarf’s form while begging, one who begs makes himself small! Secondly, a true brāhmaṇa can conquer the three worlds by the power of the spirit. These five avatāras have been referred to in the various sections of the Vedas.
The next five incarnations are in the human form.

Paraśurāma (Rāma with the battle-axe) is the sixth avatāra. Born as the son of the sage-couple, Jamadagni and Reṇukā, he exterminated the tyrannical among the Kṣattriyas led by Kārtavīrya, who were oppressing the people. Whether this story has any historical basis and represents the struggle for supremacy between the brāhmaṇas and kṣattriyas, it is difficult to say.

Śrī Rāma, the next incarnation, met Paraśurāma and absorbed his power into himself. Hence the latter is sometimes considered as āveśāvatāra, an incarnation by the temporary possession of Viṣṇu’s powers.

Śrī Rāma, one of the two most popular incarnations of the Lord Viṣṇu, comes next in the series. His story is too well-known to need any repetition. He typifies the ideal man. His story, the Rāmāyaṇa has now become an immortal epic. His name is known as the ‘tāraka-mantra,’ the mantra that takes one across the ocean of transmigration.

Balarāma, Rāma, the strong, the elder brother of Śrī Kṛṣṇa is the eighth incarnation. His many adventures include the slaying of the ape Dvivida and the demon Dhenuka, shaking the ramparts of Hastināvati (the capital city of the Pāṇḍavas) and dragging the river Yamunā out of its course. The story that the serpent Śeṣa issued forth from his mouth at the time of his death gives credence to the belief that he was the incarnation of Śeṣa. Some scholars, basing their conjecture on the weapon of Balarāma (the hala or plough), opine that he was an agricultural hero raised to the status of an avatāra in course of time.

Śrī Kṛṣṇa, the ninth incarnation of Lord Viṣṇu is, perhaps, the most popular, so much so, that he is considered Pūrṇāva-tāra (the incarnation in toto) and all other deities are regarded as his manifestations. His story and his exploits are too numerous and too well-known to be mentioned here. To the average Hindu, he is the supreme statesman, warrior, hero, philosopher and teacher, nay, God himself. He is the great expounder of the ‘Song Celestial,’ the Bhagavadgītā.

The tenth avatāra Kalki, is yet to come. He will descend upon the earth at the end of the present age (Kali Yuga). Riding on the back of a white horse, with a drawn sword, he will destroy the enemies of dharma and re-establish it in all its glory.

This list of the ten avatāras of Lord Viṣṇu is by no means the standard one accepted by all. Taking Śrī Kṛṣṇa as Viṣṇu Himself, he is not included in some lists. His place is taken over by Buddha. In some other lists, Buddha replaces Balarāma. Iconographically speaking, Buddha seems to have disappeared from such lists only after the 15th century.

Strangely enough, the purpose of the Buddha-incarnation was to mislead men of low birth and genius, who had become too proficient in the sacred lore and were a threat to the supremacy of the gods! This looks more like a joke than a serious proposition. It is obvious that the Hindus sealed the fate of Buddhism in this country by absorbing Buddha into the pantheon of the avatāras.
Haṁsa, Sātvata, Yajña, Dattātreya, Vedavyāsa are some of the avatāras included in other lists, keeping the total as ten only. The number, however, rises sometimes to as high as twentythree.
See also AVATĀRAS.

The words ‘Ārya’ and ‘Dasyu’ are found in the Ṛgveda itself (vide 1.34.7; 1.100.18; 1.51.8; 1.117.21). The word ‘Dasyu’ has been used there in several senses such as: super-human enemies, human foes, aborigines and so on. Some of the words used to describe them give us the impression that they were flat-nosed, ugly and unclean persons who did not perform the sacrificial rites (of the Āryans), hated the gods and were addicted to strange practices.
Cumuri, Śambara and Śuṣṇa are some of the names of the well-known Dasyus mentioned in the Vedas.

They were probably primitive settlers of the regions conquered by the Āryans. Or, they might have been the renegades in the Āryan society who were cultural outcastes. In later literature the word refers to criminals committing atrocities on peace-loving people.
Indra, the lord of the gods, is sometimes referred to as ‘dasyuhatya’ (one who destroys the Dasyus).
The Iranian terms ‘daṅhu’ and ‘daqyn’ are similar to the word ‘Dasyu’ and indicate a country inhabited by hostile people.

The ancient sages of India gave as much importance to life in the next world (pitṛloka, the world of manes) as to the life here. Hence they always hankered after an aurasaputra or a son born out of the wife married as per the rules given in the dharmaśāstras. It was this son (or sons) who had the right to the property of his father and also perform the śrāddha ceremony after his death. (See ŚRĀDDHA.)
If a person had no children from his wife, he was permitted to adopt a son who was called ‘dattaka.’ In course of time elaborate rules were framed for the process of adoption.

Every male Hindu who is a major and of a sound mind can adopt a son, if he himself has no son or grandson or near (male) relative, who is eligible to perform the śrāddha after his death. The boy to be adopted must be from the same caste.
The primary right to give a son for adoption rests with the natural father. The mother can also do so provided she gets the consent of her husband or is a widow.
Persons having more than one son only can give a son for adoption by others. They should not, however give the eldest son.

If there is only one son, he should not be given away in adoption. However, even this has been sometimes allowed on the condition that the boy should be considered as the son of both the natural father and adopting father. In such cases, the adopted boy is called ‘dvyāmuṣyāyaṇa’.

The procedure of adoption given in the dharmaśāstras has several steps. The more important ones are: fasting by the adopter the previous day, offering madhuparka (See MADHUPARKA for details.) to the officiating priest, performance of the dattahoma using Ṛgvedic verses, holding both hands of the boy symbolic of receiving him into ones own family and offering of boiled rice.
By such an adoption, the boy now becomes like an aurasaputra or natural son, enjoying all the rights and privileges and also bound to discharge all the duties and responsibilities.
If a natural son is born to the adopter later on, then the dattaka gets only one-fourth share in the property.
Though adoption was confined mostly to boys, girls too could be adopted. The two famous examples in our epics are those of Śāntā the adopted daughter of Romapāda and Kuntī, of Kuntibhoja.

Hindu mythology abounds in stories of Lord Viṣṇu’s avatāras or incarnations which may be pūrṇāvatāras (full manifestations) like Śrīkṛṣṇa or aṁśāvatāras (partial manifestations) like Kapila or even āveśāvatāras (temporary infilling of the divine power) like Paraśurāma. Dattātreya is regarded as an aṁśāvatāra.

He was the son of the sage Atri and Anasūyā, one of the paragons of wifely virtues and chastity in the mythological lore. According to one of the accounts, Atri who was childless, performed severe austerities to please God and obtain a worthy son. All the three deities of the Hindu Trinity—Brahmā, Viṣṇu and Śiva—appeared before him and granted his desire by being born through their aspects, as three sons: Brahmā as Candra, Viṣṇu as Datta and Śiva as Dūrvāsas.
According to another version, the three who came to test the chastity of Anasūyā were transformed into a child with three heads and six arms! This is how Dattātreya was born.

Dattātreya also called ‘Datta’—has been described as a great sage, counted among the saptarṣis or seven sages in the Svārociṣa-manvantara. (See MANVANTARAS.) He was the originator of certain magical rites and the creator of the soma plant. Sometimes pictured as a teacher of non-Āryan races he has been described as ritually impure. However, his powers of knowledge and enlightenment are so great that no impurity can ever taint him.
The great king Kārttavīryārjuna was a disciple of his.

A cult designated as the Datta-sampradāya has grown round him. It still prevails in Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh and Nepal. His temples are generally called ‘Dattamandira’ and it is his wooden sandals that are normally installed and worshipped. His temples are at Māhūr (Maharashtra) Gāṇagāpura (Karnataka) and Wāḍi (Maharashtra). There is an old shrine on one of the peaks of the Girnar Hill in Gujarat.
The sect of the Mahānubhāvas, started by Cakradhara (A. D. 1263) in Maharashtra considers Dattātreya as a perfect manifestation of the Godhead.

Iconographically Dattātreya may be shown with three heads and six hands, holding the emblems of Brahmā, Viṣṇu and Śiva such as kamaṇḍalu (water pot), śaṅkha (conch), cakra (discus) and triśūla (trident). A bull (vṛṣabha, representing dharma or righteousness) is shown as his mount. Sometimes, four dogs (representing the four Vedas) are also shown as his constant companions.
The well-known treatise of Advaita Vedānta, the Avadhūtagītā, has been attributed to his authorship.
The Dattātreya concept may be an attempt at harmonising the three cults of Brahmā, Viṣṇu and Śiva. It may also have been the medium through which non-Vedic cults were brought into the Hindu fold.

This is a minor Upaniṣad belonging to the cult of Viṣṇu and classed among the ones of the Atharvaṇaveda. There are three khaṇḍas or sections and a total of nine long mantras, all in prose, except one.

The four-faced Brahmā once approached Nārāyaṇa, the Supreme Lord of the universe in the Satyakṣetra—the region situated between the rivers Gaṅgā and Yamunā—and requested him to teach that transcendental wisdom by which one can become free from the rounds of birth and death. Nārāyaṇa advised him to meditate upon his Abode of pure sattva (the quality of substance of purity and effulgence). Those who meditate thus and realise that the Lord is ‘Datta,’ since he gives (datta = what is granted or given) the knowledge of Brahman, and also declare it to others, will never again be bound in saṁsāra or transmigratory existence.
Having been instructed by Nārāyaṇa thus, Brahmā meditated upon the Dattātreya aspect of Nārāyaṇa and taught it as Sat (the eternal Truth) to others.
Next, a series of mantras of Dattātreya are given, classifying them as ekākṣara (one-lettered), ṣaḍakṣara (six lettered) and so on.
They are:
(2) Oṁ śrīṁ hrīṁ klīṁ glauṁ drām ||
(3) drāṁ dattātreyāya namaḥ ||
(4) Om āṁ hrīṁ krom ehi dattātreya svāhā ||

(5) Om aiṁ kroṁ klīṁ klūṁ hrāṁ
hrīṁ hrūṁ sauḥ dattātreyāya svāhā ||

(6) dattātreya hare kṛṣṇa
unmattānandadāyaka |
digambara mune bāla piśāca jñānasāgara ||

The next section gives a very long mantra, called ‘mālāmantra’. It begins thus: ‘Oṁ namo bhagavate dattātreyāya smaraṇamātra-santuṣṭaya....’ and so on. It ends with the words, ‘Oṁ namaśśivāya ityupaniṣat.’

The third or the last section delineates the fruits of the practice of this esoteric science. The results he will get will be equal to that got by repeating the Gāyatrīmantra one lakh times or the Mahārudramantra one lakh times and so on. He purifies a hundred of his predecessors and a hundred of his descendants. He is never tainted even by the most heinous of sins like killing a cow. The knowledge of all mantras and yogas accrue to him of their own accord. In other words he becomes a jīvanmukta, one liberated even while living.
See also DATTĀTREYA and UPANIṢADS.

Full control over one’s own mind is a virtue that we often hanker for. Patañjali (200 B. C.) the great master of Yoga, had dealt with this topic from two standpoints. In the negative aspect, one should try constantly to avoid or overcome the various obstacles that disturb our mental balance or concentration. In the positive aspect, repeated efforts should be made to tackle the mind directly and control it.

Patañjali in his Yogasūtras lists nine major obstacles—which he calls ‘antarāyas’—and five minor ones (vide 1.30, 31) to the control of mind. ‘Daurmanasya’ is listed as the second in the list of minor impediments. Literally it means ‘being in a bad state of mind’ (dur = bad, manas = mind). In effect, it refers to the frustration one gets when one’s desires are unfulfilled or thwarted.

It is neither possible nor desirable to fulfil all our cravings and ambitions. Hence we should take recourse to discrimination and be convinced that desire is the root-cause of all our troubles. Once the intensity of desire is lessened, the shock of disappointment also will be lessened. If and when it is completely eliminated, the problem is permanently solved.
Showing dayā or compassion to all the living creatures and not harming them has been a basic moral discipline enjoined on all, in Hinduism.
The word ‘dayā’ has been defined in various ways:

ol.li: The desire that arises in one’s heart to mitigate the sufferings of others by putting forth the necessary effort.
The desire to do good to others even as one wishes that others should do towards oneself.

description.p: The Devībhāgavatam (1.15.60) des-cribes Dayā as one of the eight female companions accompanying the Devī (Divine Mother).
The word is also used as an appellation for Lakṣmī, the consort of Viṣṇu, since she is the very personification of compassion towards all the living beings who are her children.
Vedānta Deśika (A. D. 1268-1370), the celebrated teacher of the Rāmānuja school, has composed an exquisitely moving hymn called Dayāśatakam on Lakṣmī as Dayā.
The dharmaśāstras are the law-books guiding the Hindu society over the centuries. They contain enough material regarding civil as well as criminal topics.
The smṛtis (secondary scriptures), nibandhas (digests) and purāṇas (mythological works) are the main components of these dharmaśāstras.

One of the topics that has been discussed in great detail in these works is that of division of ancestral property and the rules for inheritance. On the whole, there has been a broad twofold system prevailing in the country, for nearly a thousand years.
They are: the Mitākṣarā school and the Dāyabhāga school.

The Mitākṣarā or Ṛjumitākṣarā is a magnificent commentary by Vijñaneśvara (12th cent. A. D.) on the ancient work, Yājñavalkya Smṛti. The Dāyabhāga is an independent work, a digest, written by Jīmūtavāhana (A. D. 1100). It has a standard commentary called Dāyatattva by Raghunandana (A. D. 1510-1580).
The two schools depend almost entirely on these works.
The Mitākṣarā school is the authority accepted all over India except in Bengal (including Bangladesh). However the Dāyabhāga school seems to be a binding authority in Bengal.

According to the Mitākṣarā law, a son, as soon as he was born, became a coparcener (joint owner) with his father in the ancestral property inherited by him. But in the Dāyabhāga system the son did not automatically acquire that right just by birth.

The father, during his life-time, could alienate the property or give it to his children or prepare a will according to his desire. None had the right to question it. If the person passed away without issues, his widow became the owner of that property and not his brothers or other relatives.

The growth and development of any religion and culture depend to a great extent on the freedom of thought and action, that its votaries enjoy. If Hindu religion and culture have survived the onslaughts of time and change, it is not a little due to this freedom and the reform movements that it engenders. One of the effective and largely successful reform movements of the 19th century is the Āryasamāj Movement. Svamī Dayānanda Sarasvatī was its founder.

He was born in A. D. 1825, in the small town of Ṭaṅkāra in the Morvi district of Gujarat as the son of Ambāśaṅkar Tivārī and Amṛtābāī. His original name was Mūlaśaṅkara. Being born in an orthodox brāhmaṇa family, he underwent the usual religious sacraments like upanayana (investiture with the sacred thread) and Vedic studies as also performing religious rites.

The free movement of a little rat on the Śivaliṅga on a Śivarātri day, became the turning point in his life and in his attitude towards image worship as also ritualistic religion. He developed a great abhorrence for the same.

The death of his uncle and a sister made him more introvert and philosophical. One day, when preparations for his marriage were going on, he managed to slip away from his house, never to return again.

He started travelling from place to place, in search of a competent guru or spiritual teacher. After studying some Vedāntic texts under Svāmī Brahmānanda and Paramahaṁsa Paramānanda, he was ordained into saṁnyāsa or monastic life by one Svāmī Pūrṇānanda Sarasvatī.
From then onwards he came to be known as Svāmī Dayānanda Sarasvatī.

It was actually Svāmī Virajānanda Sarasvatī, a blind but erudite and a highly evolved soul, that fulfilled the spiritual aspirations of Dayānanda. After intensive study and training under Him for about three years, Dayānanda set out on his life’s mission as per the directions of his guru Virajānanda.
Propagation of the pure Vedic religion based entirely on the Saṁhitās was the main task assigned to him by his guru.

Now began his relentless fight against the various unhealthy accretions to the Vedic religion as also the assaults on Hinduism by the Semitic religions. He prepared himself for this onerous task by practising severe austerities for two years in a garden in Agra.

During his ceaseless travels all over the country he mercilessly shattered, through his incisive logic and vast know-ledge of the Vedas, the various opinions and practices of the pundits. He successfully roused the religious conscience of the masses. He also reconverted many people who had gone out of the Hindu fold and even gave them the Gāyatrī-mantra, which he considered as a universal mantra and the common property of all the Hindus.

His insistence on the original Vedic religion as true Hinduism, his call to ignore the caste system as a man-made accretion and his stress on the varṇa system based, not on birth, but on character, earned him a very large following, especially from the deprived sections of the society.

However, his ruthless condemnation of many ritualistic and other practices in the Hindu society based on the secondary scriptures like the purāṇas, created many enemies for him. His criticism of Islam and Christianity as also his campaign for reconversion of those who had left Hindu religion roused the wrath of the Muslims and the Christians. Several attempts were made against his life.

Dayānanda established the Ārya Samāj at Bombay in 1875 with a creed of 28 principles which he later reduced to 10 in the revision he himself made, in 1877. (See ĀRYASAMĀJ for details.) He passed away in 1883 being poisoned by his own cook, whom he forgave and helped to escape!

By his pure life, fearless and uncompromising adherence to the principles of his conviction, crusades against the forays into the Vedic religion by others and scholarly works like the Satyārthaprakāśa (in Hindi) as also Sanskrit commentaries on some portions of the Vedas, Dayānanda has carved out a permanent place for himself in Hinduism.
See also SATYĀRTHAPRAKĀŚA.

head.note: (‘the doctrine [that the] body [itself is] the self ’)

description.p: Indian philosophical systems have been broadly divided into two streams: the āstika and the nāstika. The former accept the Vedas as the final authority whereas the latter do not. One of the three systems of the latter group is the Cārvāka system. Its founder is said to be one Cārvāka or the reputed sage Bṛhaspati.

The word ‘Cārvāka’ might have been derived from its etymology as ‘one who speaks sweetly’ (cāru = sweet, vāk = speech) or as ‘one who preaches the doctrine of “eat drink and be merry” (carv = to eat)’. In other words it stands for Indian materialism.

According to this system, there is no permanent abiding ātman or soul different from and beyond the deha or the physical body. The deha (body) itself is the ātman (the soul). The very fact that we say, ‘I am stout,’ ‘I am lean,’ ‘I am sick’ and so on, shows that we are, in reality, the body.
There is of course consciousness in a living body. But this is a product of the elements of matter like earth and water even as fermentation of certain articles develops the power of intoxication.
The survival of man after death in any form, is unseen and unproved.
Hence make the best of this world even while living here and do not bother about the hereafter.
This is the gist of this school of materialism.

Deoghar—corrupted form of Devagṛha (‘house of God’)—is a town situated in the Santhal Parganas of the Jharkhand State. It is famous for its temple of Vaidyanātha or Baidyanāth (Śiva), one of the twelve Jyotirliṅgas (See JYOTIRLIṄGAS.). Other names by which it was known are: Harītakīvana, Ketakīvana, Rāvaṇavana, Citābhūmi and Hārdapīṭha. Probably it was a forest of trees of inknuts (harītakī) or fragrant screwpine flowers (ketakī).

According to the local legends, when Rāvaṇa got the Śivaliṅga from Śiva Himself to be taken to Laṅkā, the gods contrived to get it fixed to the ground on the way itself. This place has now become the present Vaidyanātha.

This is also the place where the hṛdaya or the heart of Satī’s body (cut by Viṣṇu, by his discus) is said to have fallen. Hence the name Hārdapīṭha (seat of the heart of Satī), one of the 52 Śaktipīṭhas (places of Śakti or the Divine Mother).

The temple of Vaidyanātha Śiva is a simple structure with a pyramidal tower 26.5 metres (72 feet) in height. It faces east. The liṅga is cylindrical in form. It is 10 cms (4 inches) high. The diameter is 12.7 cms. (5 inches). The top of the liṅga is uneven.
There are different porches, some containing pillars and hanging bells.
Near the main entrance there is a well called Candrakūpa (‘well of Candra or the Moon’). It is said to contain the essence of all the holy rivers and lakes.
A little away is the Śivagaṅgā—a large tank measuring 270 metres by 180 metres (900 feet by 600 feet)—with an embankment. It is also called Mānas-sarovar.
The rituals followed in the temple are very simple, like bathing the liṅga with water, smearing with sandal paste and offering bilva leaves as also flowers.
There are pilgrims who bring water from the Gaṅgā near Badarīnāth or even the Mānas-sarovar (in Tibet) just to bathe this liṅga.

Persons suffering from serious ailments or with unfulfilled desires observe certain simple vows as lying on the bare ground and drinking the holy water with which the liṅga has been bathed. They observe it for three days. The redemption is believed to come with revelations during a dream.
There are eleven other shrines in the courtyard of the temple dedicated to deities like Lakṣmī-Nārāyaṇa, Pārvatī, Kālī, Gaṇeśa, Sarasvatī, Rāma and others.
