If the present temple of Vaidyanātha was renovated or rebuilt in A. D. 1596 by one Pūraṇ Mal, the others have come up during the period A. D. 1630 to 1813, built by several others.

Human beings have a strong tendency to cast their gods also in their own mould. The things we like and love to possess or enjoy here must be dear to God too and hence he should not be deprived of them! This appears to be the logic behind the devadāsī system.

Dedicating grown-up girls to the service of God in temples and places of worship seems to have been an ancient practice. It existed in Babylonia, Cyprus, Phoenicia, Greece, Mesopotamea, Syria and Arabia, as also some countries of the South-East.

When exactly this custom began in India, is difficult to say. According to some sociologists, it might have started in the 3rd century A. D., though in the image of a female dancer discovered at Mohenjo Dāro (2500 B. C.) some archaeologists ‘see’ a devadāsī.
The custom might have existed throughout India, but much more in the South than in the North.
Those who were dedicated to the god in a temple were often married ceremonially to the image. Thereafter they were to serve that god devotedly.

The duties of a devadāsī were, in general, as follows: Keeping the temple precincts clean and neat; preparing flower garlands and other decorative materials for the deity; music and dancing, as a part of the temple rituals and so on.
They were expected to be adepts in music and dancing. Hence they were specially trained in this art.
A lady could become a devadāsī in several ways. Seven such ways have been mentioned in the relevant works. They are:

dl.dd: One who has offered herself to a temple.
One who has sold herself to a temple.
One who has given herself to the temple for the upkeep of her family.
One who has chosen to become a devadāsī out of devotion to the Lord.
One who has been abducted and offered to a temple.
One who was offered to a temple by a king or his minister as per some tradition.
One appointed for singing and dancing in a temple as a profession.

description.p: In some of the edicts found in Karnataka, the service to a god in a temple has been classified into two kinds: aṅga-bhoga and raṅgabhoga. The former consists of direct services to the image like bath, anointing with sandal paste, burning of incense and waving of lights, offering flowers and food articles and so on. The latter comprises mainly music and dancing by the devadāsīs.
Enough provision used to be made for their maintenance by the kings or the society through grant of lands, money and materials.
They were also given a place of honour in the society.

Whatever might have bean the original intentions behind this system—noble or devotional—it soon degenerated into prostitution with a ‘divine’ sanction. It also gave rise to exploitation of the weaker sex in the name of religion.

Though several serious attempts have been made to eradicate it through punishments to the agents or reformation of the devadāsīs themselves, the success achieved has not been commensurate with the efforts.

Remnants of the custom continue to exist even today in some parts of Karnataka (jogiti tradition in the Ellamma temple at Saundatti, Belgaum district), Goa, Maharashtra (where the devadāsīs are called ‘bhāvins’) and Tamil Nadu.

In imitation of the well-known Bhagavadgītā, a number of other Gītās have appeared in the later religious literature of Hinduism. One of them is the Kapilagītā from the Bhāgavatam (3.25-33). Here, the great sage Kapila, reputed to be an incarnation of Lord Viṣṇu, teaches Sāṅkhya or spiritual wisdom, to his own mother Devahūti.

Devahūti was the second of the three daughters of Svāyambhuva Manu. She was married to the sage Kardama and gave birth to nine daughters including Arundhatī (wife of the sage Vasiṣṭha) and Anasūyā (the paragon of wifely virtues and the wife of the great sage Atri) and a son, Kapila.

Kapila was Viṣṇu himself born as their son. When Kardama left for the forest to lead a life of retirement and austerities, he advised Devahūti to approach their divine son for spiritual knowledge. Accordingly Kapila taught her Sāṅkhyaśāstra. After teaching her, Kapila too departed for the forest.
Then Devahūti performed a sacrifice on the banks of the Sarasvatī river and did severe austerities. She thus realized the Truth and gave up the body.
See also KAPILA and KARDAMA.
One of the several epithets of Śrī Kṛṣṇa is ‘Devakīnandana,’ ‘One who gives joy to Devakī’. Devakī was his mother and Vasudeva, the father.

Devakī was one of the seven daughters of King Devaka of the race of Yadus. She and Vasudeva were Pṛśni and Sutapā in a previous life. They had performed severe penance and had asked the boon from Viṣṇu that he should be born as their son in a future incarnation.

After marriage to Vasudeva, when the tyrant Kaṁsa, her cousin, was taking the couple out in a chariot driven by himself, a voice from the void predicted that her eighth child would kill him. This enraged Kaṁsa so much that he tried to kill her then and there. Her life was saved on the intervention of Vasudeva who promised to hand over all the children born of her. Kaṁsa imprisoned the couple and killed all the six babies born to them one after another. The seventh baby was mysteriously transferred to the womb of Rohiṇī, the elder wife of Vasudeva. He was Balarāma, the elder brother of Śrī Kṛṣṇa. The eighth child was Śrī Kṛṣṇa who later on killed Kaṁsa, to the great relief of all.
After the exit of Śrī Kṛṣṇa from the world and the death of Vasudeva, Devakī along with Rohiṇī, gave up her body in the funeral fire (in sahagamana).

Sages—known as ṛṣis and munis—were always held in high esteem in ancient India. The fact that Arjuna, the principal hero of the Mahābhārata war, mentions the name of Asita-devala (‘Devala, the dark one’) among the great sages (vide Bhagavadgītā 10.13), shows that Devala was an ancient and highly respected sage. Devala has been described in the Mahābhārata (Ādiparva 67) as the son of Pratyūṣa who was one of the eight Vasus. (See AṢṬAVASUS.) He was a brahmarṣi (the highest status accorded to a sage in the scriptures). Dhaumya, another ṛṣi, who was the chief priest of the Pāṇḍavas, was his brother.
He is said to have been present at the Sarpayāga (snake-sacrifice) conducted by the king Janamejaya (the son of Parīkṣit, grandson of the Pāṇḍava hero Arjuna).

In the dharmaśāstra literature, mention is often made of the Dharmasūtra of Devala. He has been profusely quoted by other, later, writers. Even Śaṅkara (A. D. 788-820) mentions his name. The work itself, however, has not been traced till now. Even if all that is quoted from his work by other writers is collected, edited and published, it will prove to be a valuable addition to the extant dharma-śāstra works.
See HINDU TEMPLES.
Hindu scriptures have been broadly divided into two groups: Śruti and smṛti.

The Vedas including the Upaniṣads are the Śruti. All other secondary works like itihāsas, purāṇas, smṛtis of Manu and others, as also dharmaśāstras, are clubbed together under the omnibus term ‘smṛti’.

Since the Vedas deal only with the spiritual and otherworldly matters, gradually, a vast class of a special literature dealing more explicitly with the life here and now, both at the individual and at the social level, developed. This came to be known as ‘dharmaśāstras’.

If some of the more ancient books among the dharmasāstras like the smṛtis of Manu and Yājñavalkya or the dharma-sūtras of Āpastamba or Baudhāyana did pioneering work in the field, later writers put forth a commendable effort in preparing compilations and digests culling the relevant topics from the earlier canonical literature.

One such well-known digest is the Smṛticandrikā of Devaṇṇbhaṭṭa, who was also known by other names such as Devaṇṇa-bhaṭṭopādhyāya, Devaṇa, Devā-nanda and Devagaṇa. He was the son of Keśava-bhaṭṭopādhyāya and might have existed in the 12th century A. D.

The Smṛticandrikā is an extensive digest and its author claims that he has only collected in one place the opinions of various authorities, adding nothing of his own. He quotes profusely from several sources and earlier authors. He refers to Vijñāneśvara (author of Mitākṣarā on the Yājñavalkya Smṛti) with great respect though he differs from him on several points.

The contents of the work may be briefly summarised as follows: Various saṁskāras or sacraments; duties of brahmacārins (Vedic students) and gṛhasthas (house-holders); daily duties such as sandhyā, śrauta and smārta rites; procedure of law-courts, partnership rules; dāyabhāga (See DĀYABHĀGA.); details about śrāddha and so on.
Some other writers too—like Śukadevamiśra and Āpadeva—have named their works as Smṛticandrikā, but they are not so well-known.
Devaṇṇabhaṭṭa is said to have written another work, on music and dancing, called Saṅgītamuktāvalī.
Devāpi was the elder brother of the king Śantanu (father of Bhiṣma and great-grandfather of the Pāṇḍavas).
He was the eldest son of the king Pratīpa of Candravaṁśa (the Lunar dynasty) by his queen Sunandā.

Though he succeeded his father to the kingdom, he was forced to abdicate by the people in favour of Śantanu, since he became afflicted with leprosy. (Incidentally, this shows the power that the people of a country exerted on the royal house even in the ancient days.) Devāpi then took saṁnyāsa (monastic orders) and started living independently.

During Śantanu’s rule, the country faced a severe famine. Then Śantanu went to Devāpi, offered his apology and requested for his blessings. Soon afterwards, there were heavy rains and people were saved from the calamity of starvation.
Devāpi is also the name of another person, a kṣattriya by birth, who attained brāhmaṇahood through tapas or austerity.
The king of the Cedi country who fought on behalf of the Pāṇḍavas in the Kurukṣetra war and was killed by Karṇa was also known as Devāpi.

Throughout the history of mankind, human beings have been seeking—whether they know it or not—unalloyed happiness or bliss. Freedom from suffering and attainment of eternal peace and joy, have been the universally acclaimed goals of life.

From times immemorial, a firm belief in the existence of a Supernatural Being, omniscient and omnipotent, seems to have been ingrained in the very nature of man. By somehow establishing a contact with this Being, often called ‘God’, one can get whatever one wants in life. This is the conviction resulting from this belief.

Hinduism proclaims that this God is both nirākāra and nirguṇa (without any particular form or attributes) as also sākāra and saguṇa (capable of assuming any form and attributes at will). He can also manifest himself as a personality without any particular form, but with all the blessed qualities that one can imagine. Nothing prevents him, if need be, from assuming any form that a votary devotedly hankers for seeing or even incarnate here in the human form to set right the mess we create!

An illustration can make this point more clear. Water can exist in three states: ice, liquid water and water vapour or steam. Water vapour has no particular form whereas ice has. But liquid water can assume the shape of the vessel into which it is poured. In all these three states, vastu or substance is one and the same, though nāma (nomenclature) and rūpa (form) are different. Similar is the case with God.

Though Hinduism concedes that the gaining of freedom from all suffering and attainment of eternal bliss, are possible by adopting any one of the four well-known yogas (paths of spiritual disciplines)—Jñānayoga, Bhaktiyoga, Rājayoga and Karmayoga—Bhaktiyoga or the path of bhakti (devotion to God in his sākāra saguṇa aspect) is, comparatively speaking, much easier in this age, characterised as it is, by an excessive attachment to the physical body and (consequently) to physical comforts.
Once this is acknowledged, the necessity for and the role of rituals in this path of bhakti can easily be recognised and appreciated.

By the word ‘rituals,’ certain religious observances and practices performed in a systematic way as per the directions given in the scriptures are meant. Pūjā (worship of God or a deity), sandhyopāsanā (meditation on God as the light of knowledge and wisdom at dawn and dusk), homa (offering of oblations unto a deity in a duly consecrated fire), upavāsa (ceremonial fasting) and jāgaraṇa (keeping vigil at night as a part of spiritual discipline)—all these are rituals.

The philosophical truths contained in the Vedas, Upaniṣads and other similar scriptural works are, very often, too recondite to comprehend. Apart from an incisive intellect, purity of mind resulting from a pure sinless life is necessary to understand them. Performance of rituals is one of the easier means to achieve this purity of mind. However they should be done meticulously with a proper knowledge of the spirit behind them.

A great majority of human beings are incapable of even conceiving—let alone contemplate upon—God as the Supreme Power or Intelligence without any particular name or form. This is because of the limitation imposed by the body-mind complex and the consequent identification with it. However, an icon—an image or a picture or even a symbol—can definitely help in this process of contemplation, even as a limited window in our room gives us a view of the unlimited sky as long as we are sitting in it.

If the symbolical meaning and signi-ficance of the icon is understood properly, the icon itself will become an actualised form of the ideal. Then, viewing it will be almost as good as viewing the original it represents. It is akin to remembering a person when we look at his photograph.

We may also look at it in another way. An abacus is needed (and used) to teach certain fundamental concepts of arithmetic, to little children. Similarly an icon, especially the one installed in a temple, along with the associated ideas, can help us to conceive of and contemplate on God.
Icons or concrete symbols have played a prominent part in all religions.

Worship of images, both at home and in temples, as well as in public places of worship is widespread and popular in Hinduism. There is a mistaken notion that this is pure and simple idolatry. When in idolatry, the physical symbol itself is revered as God, in image worship, the reverence is offered to God in and through the image.

Preparation of images of deities, worship to the deities through them, either in one’s own personal or in family shrines or even in temples seems to be an ancient custom. Reference to images is found even in the Vedas (vide Ṛgveda 4.24.10). Worship of deities through images is explicitly referred to in the Rāmāyaṇa (Ayodhyā-kāṇḍa 20.14, 15) and Mahābhārata (Ādiparva 70.49; Anuśāsanaparva 10.20, 21).
Often, the images are replaced by symbolical objects such as śivaliṅgas, śālagrāmas and yantras, and worshipped.

Worship of God can be either internal or external. Internal worship called ‘mānasapūjā’ is actually meditation which may be a simple process of contemplation on the form of the deity or may involve a regular ritualistic worship with all the ingredients, but all done mentally.
External worship is the worship of the deity in an image or a symbol with all the necessary articles needed for the worship as per the religious works.

When the external worship is performed properly in the right spirit, over a period of time, it may lead to greater and greater introversion. As a result, external, formal, worship may drop off by itself. Then, only internal worship or meditation can be continued.

Some schools of devotion have put forward the theory that God descends (= avatāra) into the image at the time of worship (= arcā) in a subtle form when invited through appropriate mantras. It is something like putting on the switch to make the electric current flow through a lamp and give light.

By the same logic, when an image fixed in a temple, is consecrated as per the prescribed procedure (in which prāṇa-pratiṣṭhā or infusing with life, is an important aspect), the deity ‘lives’ in that image permanently, in a divine or subtle form.
Hence the worshipper has to be extraordinarily careful while performing the ritualistic worship to such consecrated images.
Now, the various steps involved in an actual pūjā or worship may be described.

Since external cleanliness and neatness are conducive to internal purity, the first thing to be done before starting pūjā is to clean the pūjā-room and the surrounding area thoroughly. Of course, it goes without saying, that the worshipper should take bath and wear washed and clean clothes for the pūjā. It may be a good custom even to keep two sets of clothes to be worn (by turns) only at the time of ritualistic worship.

After arranging all the vessels and materials needed for the pūjā properly, the worshipper should sit on the pūjā-seat (which should be used only for the purposes of pūjā) in such a way that he is facing the deity or keeping the deity to his left.
Generally, facing east or north is preferred and facing south is forbidden.
The whole rite of pūjā—for that matter, any religious or ritualistic act—should begin with ācamana or ceremonial sipping of water with certain mantras.

This should be followed by saṅkalpa or religious resolve. Apart from the details of that particular day according to the Hindu calendar (followed in the tradition of the worshipper’s family), the saṅkalpa-mantra also contains some other statements such as the destruction of one’s sins, acquisition of religious merit and some other particulars connected with the mode of worship.

Then come some purificatory processes like āsanaśuddhi (ritual sanctification of the seat), bhūtāpasāraṇa (driving away the evil spirits), puṣpaśuddhi (ritual cleansing of flowers, bilva and tulasī leaves) and agniprākāracintā (erecting a wall of fire through imagination) and so on.
The next steps are prāṇāyāma (breath control in aid of peace and concentration) as also bhūtaśuddhi or creating a spiritual body in place of the physical one.
Prāṇapratiṣṭhā (filling the spiritual body with the presence of the deity), nyāsas (ritual purification of limbs) and mudrās (postures of fingers and hands) follow next.
Now, are taken up the most important parts of the worship—dhyāna (meditation on the deity in one’s heart and transferring the same into the image or symbol) and upacāras (modes of direct service).

These upacāras can be 5 or 10 or 16. Sometimes they are raised to 64 or even 108! But, normally, the first two are common for daily worship and 16 upacāras for special worship. The other two are done only in temples on very special occasions.
These upacāras are ceremonially offered with appropriate mantras to the deity invoked into the image or symbol.

The ten upacāras are: pādya (water for washing the feet), arghya (water for washing the hands), ācamanīya (water for rinsing the mouth), snānīya (giving a bath by pouring water over the image or the symbol with Vedic mantras), gandha (applying fresh sandal paste), puṣpa (offering of flowers, bilva and tulasī leaves), dhūpa (waving of lighted incense sticks), dīpa (waving of a lighted lamp), naivedya (giving food-offering as also drinking water) and punarācamanīya (giving water for rinsing the mouth at the end).
At the end of the worship, puṣpāñjali (offering of a handful of flowers) is laid at the feet of the deity, indicating the conclusion of the whole ritual.

Where the pūjā is done to the deity in a temporarily invoked image (as in the worship of clay icons of Gaṇapati or Durgā), udvāsanā or visarjana also has to be done. It is the ceremonial withdrawal of the deity from the image, back into one’s own heart, after which the image or the symbol (like a flower) can be disposed off.
The mode of worship described so far, is according to the tāntric tradition. The Vedic tradition is slightly different from this. A brief account of the same is as follows:

Dīpajvalana (lighting the lamp and praying to it as the symbol of the deity and requesting it to burn steadily till the pūjā is over), ācamana, guruvandana (obeisance to one’s own guru or spiritual teacher), prayer to Vighneśvara or Gaṇapati (for the removal of obstacles to the pūjā), ghaṇṭānāda (ringing the bell with appropriate mantras to drive away the demons and welcome the gods) (Ringing the bell is necessary at other times also as during ceremonial bath to the deity and offering incense etc.), recitation of two Vedic mantras to steady the mind (Ṛgveda 10.63.3 and 4.50.6), maṇṭapadhyāna (meditation on the miniature shrine structure, generally made of wood), āsanamantra (for purification and steadiness of the seat), prāṇāyāma, saṅkalpa, ceremonial purification of the water in the kalaśa (water vessel) to make it fit for using in pūjā, filling up the śaṅkha (conch) with that water and inviting its presiding deities (like Sūrya, Varuṇa, Candra and others) to reside in it in a subtle form, sprinkling that water over all the articles of pūjā to consecrate them, nyāsa with the Puruṣasūkta (Ṛgveda 10.7.90), invoking the presence of the deity into the image and offering the upacāras.

The sixteen upacāras offered are: āvāhana, āsana, pādya, arghya, ācama-nīya, snāna, vastra (cloth) as also upavīta (sacred thread, called ‘yajñopavīta’), gandha, puṣpa, dhūpa, dīpa, naivedya, tāmbūla (betel leaf and nut), recitation of the Mantrapuṣpa (Taittirīya Āraṇyaka— Aruṇapraśna 78 to 84), pradakṣiṇa (circumambulation) and namaskāra (obeisance).
Some more, traditional and interesting, aspects of this worship may now be stated.

In the pañcāyatanapūjā (pūjā to the five standard deities viz., Śiva, Devī, Viṣṇu, Gaṇeśa and Sūrya), one’s own family deity should be kept in the centre and the other four around it in the prescribed order.
Abhiṣeka (pouring water for giving bath to the image) is to be done with gośṛṅga (horn of a cow) to the śivaliṅga and with śaṅkha to Viṣṇu or śālagrāma.

While offering cloth in pūjā, different types of cloth are offered to different deities, which can be known from the concerned scriptural injunctions. In the routine daily pūjā even flowers can be offered in place of cloth, as a substitute.
Dhūpa is offered to the feet and dīpa before the face of the deity. In general ārati (waving of lights), the dīpa has to be waved all over the deity’s image.
Pradakṣiṇā is to be done three times in the clockwise direction, slowly, with folded hands. Then comes sāṣṭāṅga-praṇāma, done by lying down on the chest, on the floor.
At the end, tīrtha (the consecrated water of the pūjā) and prasāda (consecrated food offering) should be received by all who have taken part in the pūjā or witnessed it.
What has been described till now, just gives an idea of the philosophy and the spirit behind the Hindu ritualistic worship.

The Hindu scriptures themselves consider these rituals as the kindergarten of religion. When understood properly and performed meticulously, they lead to inner purity and concentration. When this concentration becomes deep, the external rituals drop off by themselves. Till then, they must be performed.
A human being is said to be born under the load of three ṛṇas or debts.
Deva-ṛṇa or the debt to be paid to the gods is one of them. It can be repaid by the regular and proper performance of the prescribed Vedic rites.
See ṚṆATRAYA for details.
Sages of knowledge and wisdom (ṛṣis) as also of austerity (munis, tapasvīs) have been well-known in the Hindu scriptural works.
Among the several kinds of ṛṣis mentioned there, the devarṣis are one group.
The word ‘devarṣi’ has been defined as a ‘sage who is like a god’ or as ‘one who is revered even by the gods’.

The most well-known of all the devarṣis is Nārada. The others are: Atri, Bhṛgu, Kutsa, Vasiṣṭha, Gautama, Kaśyapa and Aṅgiras. In other lists the names of Tumburu, Bharata, Parvata and Devala appear. There seems to be no unanimity in the classified lists.
See also ṚṢIS.

Derived from the root ‘div’ (= to shine) the word ‘deva’ represents the divine beings inhabiting the heavenly regions. They are described as the sons of the sage Kaśyapa from his first wife Aditi. Hence they are also known as ādityas or āditeyas.
In the Vedic literature their number is often stated as 33. The break-up is: 8 Vasus, 11 Rudras, 12 Ādityas, Indra and Prajāpati. (See under each title for details.)
But again, they are all the manifestations of the one Supreme God.

In the mythological literature—Vedic and post-Vedic—the devas are pictured as constantly in conflict with the asuras (antigods or demoniac beings). The asuras are probably of two types: the daityas and the dānavas. They were the sons of Diti and Danu who too were the wives of Kaśyapa.
Indra was the king of the devas and Virocana, of asuras.

Devasenā and Daityasenā were the daughters of Dakṣaprajāpati and hence sisters. Once they were abducted by a demon called Keśin, but were rescued by Indra. When Ṣaṇmukha or Subrahmaṇya (also known as Kārttikeya) led the army of the gods against Padmāsura and Tārakāsura and killed them, Indra was so pleased that he gave Devasenā in marriage to him. Bṛhaspati is said to have performed the religious rites of the marriage. According to this story, the well-known festival day, Skandaṣaṣṭhī or Subrahmaṇya ṣaṣṭhī, is this day of marriage.

Etymologically, the word could just mean ‘the army of the gods’. Since Ṣaṇmukha led that army as its chief he was called ‘Devasenāpati’ (pati = lord, master). Since the word ‘Devasenā’ is in the feminine gender, the story that ‘she’ was a princess and he was her husband could have been invented and later interpolated into the purāṇas.
Etymologically speaking, the words ‘devatā’ and ‘deva’ mean the same thing. The devatās are gods or deities or divine beings endowed with extraordinary or supernatural powers.

In the Vedic literature, especially in the Ṛgveda, we come across a number of devatās. They are usually enumerated as 33. (See DEVAS for details.) Apart from these gods, many inanimate objects like grinding stone, qualities like faith, emotions like anger, aspects of nature like dawn have been deified and described. There are quite a few female devatās also though they are not as prominent as the male deities.
These deities may have an anthro-pomorphic form or may not have. As an aspect of nature or a physical object they don’t. But, as the presiding deity behind them they do have.

The Vedic deities have been allotted different places in the universe. Agni, Pṛthvī and Somapavamāna belong to the pṛthvī (earth). Indra, Vāyu and Parjanya belong to antarikṣa (sky). Varuṇa, Mitra, Sūrya and Viṣṇu belong to dyuloka (heaven).
But, ultimately, all of them are different aspects of the Supreme God, Brahman-Ātman.

Sometimes these devatās are described as being born from one another. For instance Agni is born from Sūrya and again, Sūrya from Agni. Being too remote in point of time, it is rather difficult for us to explain these anomalies. Sometimes, even the explanations of the Nirukta by Yāska do not help us much.

The paurāṇic Hinduism has offered a large number of devatās, gods and goddesses, most of whom do not seem to have existed during the Vedic period. However, the basic idea that all of them are different aspects of one and the same Supreme God (Brahman or Paramātman) persists.

head.note: (‘One [whose] penance [is as good as that of a] god’)

description.p: ‘Devavrata’ was the original name of Bhīṣma, the famous grandsire of the Mahābhārata. See BHĪṢMA for details.

According to the Padmapurāṇa (Pātālakhaṇḍa, 73) Devavrata was a brāhmaṇa who was born as a bamboo stem in the Vṛndāvana where Kṛṣṇa lived, since he had incurred the wrath of the devotee of Viṣṇu and had been cursed by him. When Kṛṣṇa cut it, made a flute out of it and started playing on it, Devavrata was liberated.

‘Devavrata’ is also the name of a vrata or religious observance mentioned in some of the purāṇas. Worshipping Maheśvara (Śiva) on a caturdaśī day (14th day after full-moon or new-moon) with the star Maghā (comprising alpha, eta, gamma, zeta and two more stars) and the planet Guru (Jupiter) in conjunction, will bestow long life, wealth and fame. This is one vrata called ‘Devavrata’. In another type, nakta (eating once only at night) for eight days and gifting a golden trident and discus as also two garments is the discipline prescribed. Result promised is freedom from even grave sins.

An awareness of one’s social respons-ibilities and earnest attempts to repay one’s debts to the concerned persons gradually evolved into the principle of ṛṇatraya (three debts) even at birth. The same was expanded in scope into an allied principle of pañcayajñas. They apply to all human beings, especially to the gṛhasthas or house-holders.

Deva-ṛṇa or the debt towards the gods like Indra and Varuṇa has to be paid back by devayajña (also spelt as daiva-yajña) or offering of oblations ceremonially into the duly consecrated fire. Being pleased by (and also sustained by) such sacrificial offerings, these gods who have control over the elemental forces like rain or the growth of crops or granting worthy progeny, fulfil our desires. By thus mutually co-operating with each other both these gods and the human beings can live happily and even prosper well.
See also PAÑCAYAJÑAS and ṚṆATRAYA.

Birth and death have always proved to be a deep mystery for mankind. Every religion has tried to solve this in its own way. The solution Hinduism offers is found in the Vedic literature—the Ṛgveda, the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa and some of the Upaniṣads like the Bṛhadāraṇyaka and the Chāndogya.

The religion of the Ṛgveda, the earliest available record of human civilisation, is not only optimistic but also dynamic. A life lived well here, in accordance with the principles of ṛta (straightforwardness), satya (truth) and dharma (righteousness), will automatically give you happiness and peace in the life hereafter also. This is the main teaching of the Vedas, the Upaniṣads and all the allied scriptures.

A strong belief in an uncreated, unborn eternal soul, born out of their mystical experiences, naturally made the Vedic seers reflect on its sojourn after the death of this body also. What they discovered in their moments of revelation was given expression to in some of the mantras.

Generally, three destinies for the soul of a dead person have been predicated in these Vedic works: going to the Brahma-loka (or the world of Brahmā) by the Arcirādimārga (the path of light, also called Devayāna or Uttarāyaṇa), from which there is no return to this mundane existence; going to the Pitṛloka or Candra-loka (the world of manes) by the Dhūmādi-mārga (the path of smoke) from which there is return after exhausting the fruits of the merit acquired earlier in this world; repeated birth and death in various bodies.

The first mention of the words Devayāna and Pitṛyāna is found in the Ṛgveda where Agni is addressed as the knower of the path of gods (1.72.7) and the path of the manes (10.2.7). In the mantra (10.18.1) Mṛtyu, the god of death, is requested to clear away from the path of gods. The Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa also mentions these paths in several places. The Ṛgvedic verse (10.18.1) is repeated almost verbatim in the Atharvaveda (12.2.21).

It is quite likely that the Devayāna and the Pitṛyāna were the celestial paths by which the gods (like Indra) and the manes used to descend to this earth to receive their sacrificial and obsequial offerings and return. Gradually, however the paths were ‘thrown open’ as it were, to deserving human beings too.

The Devayāna starts with arcis or the light of the funeral pyre and ends with the Brahmaloka. Various stations are mentioned in between. The enumeration of these stations is found in the following Upaniṣads: Bṛhadāraṇyaka (6.2.15 and 16); Chāndogya (4.15.5 and 5.10.1 to 6); Kauṣītaki-brāhmaṇa (1.3). It is mentioned in the Bhagavadgītā (8.24) also. The stations commonly mentioned are:
Arcis (light), ahaḥ (day), āpūrya-māṇapakṣa (bright fortnight), uttarāyaṇa (summer solstice), saṁvatsara (year), āditya (sun) and candramas (moon).
At this point, an ‘amānavapuruṣa’ (a being who is not a human; a divine being) will come and take the soul to Brahmā in Brahmaloka or Satyaloka.
Sometimes ‘candramas’ is omitted and ‘devaloka’ is substituted for ‘saṁ-vatsara’. The divine being had also been called ‘puruṣo mānasaḥ’ (‘the mind-born person’).
The terms used in these lists such as arcis (light) or ahaḥ (day) actually refer to the ātivāhikās or divine guides on the path (vide Brahmasūtras 4.3.4).

Who are those fortunate persons considered as fit enough to tread this path and go to Brahmaloka, from which there is no return? The Chāndogya (5.10.1) and the Bṛhadāraṇyaka (6.2.15) Upaniṣads declare that the knowers of the Pañcāgni-vidyā (‘the doctrine of five fires’) (See PAÑCĀGNIVIDYĀ.) as also those who live in the forests, devoted to faith, austerity and truth, go by this path. The Muṇḍaka Upaniṣad too (1.2.11) mentions that those who are self-controlled, full of knowledge and wisdom, living on alms and in forests and devoted to austerity, go by the ‘Sūryadvāra’ (i.e., Devayāna) and attain the Immortal Being. The Praśna Upaniṣad (1.10) also proclaims the same thing.

Those who reach the Brahmaloka are supposed to live there enjoying great peace and bliss till the end of Brahmā’s life, after which they—along with the Brahma-loka and Brahmā—get merged in Parabrahman or the Supreme Spirit.
This mode of mukti or liberation is called kramamukti or gradual liberation.
See also PITṚYĀNA.

Ever since the elaborate rituals to consecrated images in temples became an established tradition, each temple too started having its own special celebrations. Such celebrations are called ‘yātrā’ or ‘utsava’ or ‘yātrotsava’.
There are some general rules guiding such festivals, especially regarding the auspicious days on which they should be done. The following table gives an idea of the same:
All gods—, Pūrṇimā (full-moon day)
Durgā—, Navamī (ninth day after full-moon or new-moon day)
Lakṣmī—, Pañcamī (fifth day after full-moon or new-moon day)
Śiva—, Aṣṭamī or Caturdaśī (eighth day after full-moon or new-moon day) (fourteenth day after full-moon or new-moon day)
Skanda (Ṣaṇmukha)—, Ṣaṣṭhī (sixth day after full-moon or new-moon day)
Vināyaka (Gaṇapati)—, Caturthī (fourth day after full-moon or new-moon day)
Of course, local customs can differ and other days may be chosen for the temple festivals.
The ‘devī’ is the feminine counterpart of ‘deva’ and hence means a goddess.

The concept as well as the worship of God as the Mother of the universe—deification into a feminine form, of the Supreme Power ruling over the universe—is as old as the human civilisation. The people of Assyria and Babylonia worshipped the goddess Ishtar, as the goddess par excellence.
There is enough evidence to believe that Mother-worship existed during the Indus valley Civilisation (2800 B. C.).

The Ṛgveda (2.1.11; 8.10.2) refers to several female deities as the consorts of male deities or even as independent and separate goddesses such as Aditi, Uṣas, Pṛthvī, Rātri, Vāc, Śraddhā and so on. Sacred rivers like Sarasvatī, Gaṅgā, Yamunā, Śutudrū and Paruṣṇī were also deified as goddesses.
In course of time, many folk-goddesses of great antiquity and uncertain origin were also absorbed into the Devī-cult.

However, it is in the paurāṇic age that the notion of the Mother-goddess, Devī, came to be associated with the three prominent deities (the Trimūrtis) Brahmā, Viṣṇu and Śiva, thereby giving rise to a great number of her aspects.
The three major goddesses are Sarasvatī (consort of Brahmā), Lakṣmī (consort of Viṣṇu) and Pārvatī (consort of Śiva).

In the purāṇas, while there is an attempt to depict them as three aspects of one and the same Devī, there are also legends trying to project one of them as superior to and hence the mistress of, the other two.

By and large, an overwhelming majority of the goddesses are either different facets of the goddess Pārvatī (the spouse of Śiva) or her attendants or her associates. In fact, even the word ‘Devī’ has been specially reserved for her.
For details, see under each title such as LAKṢMĪ, PĀRVATĪ, SARASVATĪ.
The purāṇas or Hindu mythological lore, have been classed among the secondary scriptures of Hinduism. Yet, modern Hindu religious practices are, for the most part, dependent on them.

The great antiquity of the core content of the purāṇas, known as Purānāsaṁhitā, is, by now, well-established. Over the centuries, it gave rise to the eighteen Mahāpurāṇas as we know them today. Its derivatives include the eighteen Upapurāṇas (minor works) also. The Devībhāgavata is one of the more well-known and fairly popular purāṇas.

Whether the Devībhāgavata is a Mahāpurāṇa or only an Upapurāṇa, has been a contentious issue. If the Vaiṣṇavas (followers of the Viṣṇu cult) argue that the Bhāgavata in the list of Mahāpurāṇas is the Viṣṇubhāgavata, the Śāktas (followers of the cult of Śakti or the Divine Mother) vehemently assert that it is the Devībhāgavata that is meant. Since controversies lead to unnecessary and undesirable conflicts, and obstruct the process of spiritual evolution, it is better to ignore them.
Some scholars opine that a śākta brāhmaṇa of Vārāṇasī (or Kāśī) might have composed it during the 11th or the 12th century.
However, the text follows the general pattern of the other purāṇas.

King Janamejaya (son of the well-known king Parīkṣit and grandson of Arjuna, the famous Pāṇḍava hero) incurred great sin for having massacred innumerable serpents in his Sarpayāga (Serpent-sacrifice, akin to a black-magical rite). He had performed it to avenge the death of his father by the bite of Takṣaka, the king of reptiles.
To ward off the effects of this sin the sage Vyāsa taught him this Devī-bhāgavata.

As the very name indicates, the main content of the work is the story of the exploits of the Devī (Mother Divine). It is almost identical with—though in greater detail—the story as delineated in the more well-known, but much shorter, work, the Devīmāhātmya.
There are 12 skandhas or Books, the number of adhyāyas (Chapters) and ślokas (couplets or verses) being 318 and 18,457 respectively.
A brief synopsis of the contents may now be given here, to get an idea of this work:
Stories of Śuka, Hayagrīva, Madhu and Kaiṭabha and Brahmā’s prayer to the Devī find a prominent place in this book.
Stories of Vyāsa, Śantanu, Bhīṣma and the Pāṇḍavas are delineated here.

Story of the king Sudarśana of Kāśī who was a great devotee of the Devī and at whose request the Devī stayed back there as also details of the Durgāpūjā, known as Śaran-navarātri-vrata, the origin of which goes back to Śrī Rāma’s first worship as per the advice of the sage Nārada find a prominent place in this section.
Doctrine of Karma, stories of Nara-Nārāyaṇa and of Kṛṣṇa are the main contents of this skandha.

This skandha contains the entire story of the Devīmāhātmya (also known as Durgāsaptaśatī and Caṇḍī) but in greater detail. The story of Mahiṣāsura’s birth and of his falling in love with the Devī before being obliged to fight with her and be killed, is an additional feature. The rest of the story is the same as in the other work.
(See DEVĪMĀHĀTMYA for the details of the story.)
Stories of Vṛtrāsura, Nahuṣa, Śunśśepha as also of Nārada’s being deluded by the power of all-bewitching māyā of Lord Viṣṇu are the main themes dealt with here.

Apart from stories and legends of the princess Sukanyā and her husband, the sage Cyavana, of Triśaṅku, Hariścandra and Viśvāmitra, this skandha gives many details of the various aspects of the Devī like Śākambharī and Gaurī. Some miscellaneous topics like Yoga, Bhaktiyoga, temples of Devī and her worship have also been dealt with.
The special feature of this section is a detailed description of world geography, of Bhāratavarṣa (India), some astronomical factors as also a description of hells.

By far, this is the biggest of all the skandhas of this work. The well-known and popular story of Sāvitrī, other less known legends like that of Mahālakṣmī and Maṅgalacaṇḍī find a place here. Several mantras and procedures for meditation on some aspects of Devī like Rādhā, Durgā and Manasā are also given here.
The story of Devīmāhātmya given in greater detail in the 5th skandha has been repeated here, though in a condensed form.

This skandha is devoted entirely to sadācāra and pūjā, various ritualistic items connected with the daily routine of a religious person. Rules of good conduct, personal cleanliness, details of the rudrākṣa beads, some vratas or religious observances and vows, the sandhyā ritual, special worship processes, ritual repetition of the famous Gāyatrīmantra as also the details connected with the preparation and wearing of bhasma or vibhūti (sacred ash, dear to Śiva) are delineated in this section.

This small book gives some details regarding the Gāyatrīmantra and dīkṣā (initiation into spiritual life). It concludes with a description of the Ambāyajña (sacrifice conducted to please the Devī) performed by the king Janamejaya.
On the whole, one has to concede, that this purāṇa successfully propagates the cult of the Devī or the Divine Mother and has given a lot of additional information useful to the spiritual aspirants.

The Bhagavadgītā of the Mahā-bhārata has become so well-known and so highly respected as a basic scripture by itself that several Gītās in imitation of the same have been composed in later times. Some of them are parts of other bigger works like the Adhyātma Rāmāyaṇa and the Bhāgavata (vide Rāmagītā, Kapilagītā and Bhikṣugītā) while others like the Aṣṭāvakragītā and the Avadhūtagītā are independent works. The Devīgītā belongs to the second category.

It is in the form of a dialogue in 9 chapters between the Devī Pārvatī (as the teacher) and her father Himavān (as the disciple). She teaches the advaita doctrine as expounded by Śaṅkara (A. D. 788-820). Advaitic experience can be obtained only by meditation on the Upaniṣadic texts like tat tvam asi. Such meditation becomes possible only to those who have a strong and pure mind. This, again, can be obtained only by the proper performance of one’s duties as per one’s varṇa (caste) and āśrama (station in life).

Other subjects dealt with are: Viśvarūpa (universal form) of the Devī; aṣṭāṅga yoga or the eight steps of Yoga as taught by Patañjali (200 B. C.); other yogas viz., those of jñāna, karma and bhakti; temples of Devī and her worship (both Vedic and tāntrik) and so on.
Obviously it is a later work of the Devī-cult.

head.note: (‘the greatness of the Devī [or the Goddess]’)

description.p: The Devī-cult is centred round the concept and the worship of God as the Divine Mother. The Devīmāhātmya as also the Devībhāgavata are the two most important works of this cult.

The roots of this cult can be traced to the Ṛgveda itself. The Ambhṛṇīsūkta (10.125.1) and the Rātrīsūkta (10.127.1) are pointers to this. Some of the minor Upaniṣads like the Devī Upaniṣad as also the tantras (Śāktāgamas) have expounded this cult in greater detail.

Gradually, as the paurāṇic religion became more popular, three aspects of the Devī—Sarasvatī, Lakṣmī and Pārvatī—were projected by the scriptures for worship and meditation. However, it is Pārvatī who has been almost exclusively meant by the word ‘Devī’ and the innumerable goddesses considered as her aspects.

The Devīmāhātmya is considered as a part of the Mārkaṇḍeya Purāṇa (chapters 78 to 90), though it is more likely to be an independent work, grafted on to this purāṇa later. It is also known by two more names: Durgāsaptaśatī (since it contains saptaśata or 700 verses extolling the greatness of Mother Durgā) and Caṇḍī (since it deals with the exploits of the fierce goddess Caṇḍī or Caṇḍikā).
The work has thirteen adhyāyas or chapters divided into three Caritras or major sections as follows:

Prathamacaritra: Chapter 1.
Madhyamacaritra: Chapter 2, 3, and 4.
Uttamacaritra: Chapter 5 to 13.
These three Caritras are devoted to the exposition of the greatness of the three aspects of the Devī, viz., Mahākālī, Mahā-lakṣmī and Mahāsarasvatī, in that order.

The first section starts with the story of a king, Suratha by name, and the merchant Samādhi, both of whom had been deprived of their wealth and possessions by their own near and dear ones. They met at the hermitage of the sage Sumedhas, to where they had come, seeking peace. After hearing from each other about the tragedies that had struck them, they approached the sage Sumedhas, with the question as to why they were still mentally attached to their possessions and their relatives even though the latter had deliberately wronged them.

In his long reply the sage described this blind attachment and infatuation as the direct result of the power of moha or māyā, the spell cast by the Devī or the Divine Mother on all the living beings. When their curiosity to know more was roused, the sage started describing in detail, the stories related to her.

The first story concerns the Devī as Yoganidrā. At the end of a kalpa (cycle of creation) Nārāyaṇa was in deep sleep. Using this opportunity, two demons Madhu and Kaiṭabha—tried to attack and kill Brahmā (the creator, seated on the navel-lotus of Nārāyaṇa). Brahmā prayed to Yoganidrā (an aspect of Kālī), to come out of Nārāyaṇa so that he could wake up. She obliged, appeared before him and then disappeared. Nārāyaṇa then killed the demons and rescued Brahmā. With this ends the Prathamacaritra or the first section.

The second section known as the Madhyamacaritra contains the story of Mahiṣāsura, the king of the asuras or demons. He had usurped the kingdom of heaven and driven away all the devas or gods including Indra. Then these gods under the leadership of Brahmā came to Viṣṇu and Śiva and recounted their tale of woe. As the two gods got angry, and a brilliant light emerged from their faces, the energies of all the others too emerged similarly out of them, merging into one huge mass of brilliant blazing light and power, which took the form of the goddess Durgā. As all the gods equipped her with their respective weapons, she went to Mahiṣāsura, challenged him for fight and ultimately killed him. The heavenly region was restored to the gods. The Devī Durgā promised to come to the rescue of the gods whenever they called upon her for help. Thus ends the second section.

The last section called Uttamacaritra (or Tṛtīyacaritra) begins with the outrageous misdeeds of the demon brothers, Śumbha and Niśumbha, who too, like Mahiṣāsura, had forcibly occupied the heavenly regions and driven away the gods. Remembering the promise given by the Devī, the gods prayed to her. She manifested herself as Kauśikī Durgā, of bewitching beauty and started roaming about the Himālayan region. She was noticed by two servants of Śumbha who informed him about her presence in ‘his kingdom,’ stressing, on her captivating beauty. When Śumbha sent messengers to her with a proposal for marriage, she informed them about her vow, taken out of ‘ignorance,’ to marry only him who will conquer her in combat! All attempts by Śumbha’s men, including several generals of his armed forces, to capture her, dead or alive, ended in total disaster. The Devī, with her emanations like Brahmāṇī, Nārāyaṇī, Kaumārī and others, successfully killed all the demons like Caṇḍa, Muṇḍa and Raktabīja. Finally, after withdrawing them into herself, she despatched both Niśumbha and Śumbha, to the world of Yama, the god of death, thereby ridding the world, of a great terror.
After listening to these exploits of the Devī and learning from the sage Sumedhas the methods of worshipping her to get her grace, Suratha and Samādhi practised severe austerities for three years.
They got her vision and obtained, through her grace, what they wanted. Suratha got back his kingdom whereas Samādhi succeeded in attaining supreme knowledge for which alone he had hankered.

The work contains four hymns which are exquisitely beautiful and are a signal contribution to the hymnal literature.
They are:

dl.dt: (2) Hymn by all the gods, led by Indra, expressing their gratefulness after Mahiṣāsura was killed by Durgā—
dl.p: This hymn is known as Indrādistuti.
dl.dt: (3) Hymn by all the gods, on the bank of the river Gaṅgā in the Himālayas—
(4) Hymn by all the gods, after Śumbha and Niśumbha were killed—

description.p: This hymn is the famous Nārāyaṇī-stuti.
The entire Devīmāhātmya is considered as a mantra, endowed with mystical powers. That is why a ritual recitation of the same is encouraged, nay even recommended, for the fulfilment of one’s desires.
Such a ritual recitation normally consists of the following procedure:

ācamana (ceremonial sipping of water before beginning any religious rite), prāṇā-yāma (breath-control), saṅkalpa (religious resolve stating the details of the ritual), dīpasthāpana (lighting a lamp and offering a simple worship to it, considering as a representation of the Devī), worship of the Devīmāhātmya book used for the ceremonial chanting, repetition of the śāpoddhāramantra to ward off the effects of the curses of the sages of yore, if any, and then the actual recital.

The recital should include: Kavaca-stotra, Argalāstotra, Kīlakastotra, repetition of the well-known Navārṇamantra (which has to be received from a competent guru in initiation), recital of Rātrisūkta, the entire text of the Devīmāhātmya, the Devīsūkta, the Rahasyatraya (Prādhānika, Vaikṛtika and Mūrti Rahasyas), śāpoddhāramantra and kṣamāprārthanā (recital of the Aparādhakṣamāpaṇastotra).

There are several modes of chanting for specific purposes like freedom from diseases, attaining wealth or position, for the birth of children and so on. These have to be learnt from teachers who are experts in the field.

Recitations called Śatacaṇḍī (ten brāhmaṇas reciting it for four days—once on the first day, twice on the second day, thrice on the third day and four times on the fourth day) and Sahasracaṇḍī (with one hundred brāhmaṇas, the procedure being similar) are forms of congregational worship and are done for the welfare of the society.
In all these rites, homa (offering of oblations into a duly consecrated fire) is also done.
The Devīmāhātmya is highly revered even now and its recitation is quite popular.

The Devīpurāṇa is an Upapurāṇa, belonging to the cult of Śakti worship. The printed edition available now seems to be only a part of a much bigger original. It was probably composed in Bengal in the seventh century A. D.
The book deals mainly with the exploits of the Devī, especially as Vindhya-vāsinī. However, many other topics also have been dealt with. They are:

Various stories connected with Devī’s incarnations; her relationship with Śiva and other gods; Śākta iconography and Śākta vows; some cults of Śiva, Viṣṇu and Gaṇapati; construction of towns and forts; different Vedic schools; the science of medicine; holy places; giving gifts; customs and usages of people and so on.
The method of the worship of the Devī mentioned here is very different from that followed in present-day Bengal.

head.note: (‘hymn of the Devī or the goddess’)

description.p: Worship of God as the Mother of the universe is a very ancient practice, especially in Hinduism. One of the oft-quoted authorities to prove this point is the Devīsūkta of the Ṛgveda (10.125.1-8).

This sūkta or hymn is also known as the Vāgāmbhṛṇīsūkta since it was revealed to the woman ṛṣi Vāc who was the daughter of the sage Ambhṛṇa. It has eight mantras or stanzas wherein Vāc describes her mystical experiences and her identity with Paramātman or God.

There are quite a few instances in the scriptural works wherein the sages who had attained mystical union with God had declared that they themselves were God (vide Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.4.10; Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad 3.1 and 2). Similar is the case here also.
Commentators of the Viṣṇu cult identify her with Lakṣmī, the eternal consort of Viṣṇu-Nārāyaṇa.

The first verse declares that it is she (viz., Vāgāmbhṛṇī) that is moving in the form of the various Vedic deities like the eleven Rudras, the eight Vasus, the twelve Ādityas as also the Viśvedevas. It is she who is supporting and sustaining the gods Mitra, Varuṇa, Indra, Agni and the Aśvinīdevatās.
Again, it is she who is sustaining the soma juice, and the gods Tvaṣṭā, Bhaga and Pūṣan. It is verily she who rewards a sacrificer when he performs it.
She is the mistress of the whole world, awarding rewards to the worshippers. She is the primary deity propitiated in the vedic sacrifices. She exists everywhere.
It is she who is responsible for all the psycho-physical activities in the living beings.
Those who please her by proper acts of propitiation are elevated to the level of a ṛṣi (sage, a seer of mantras) or even Brahmā, the creator!
It is she that strings the bow of Śiva when he decides to destroy the demons of the three cities (Tripurāsuras).
She has created the svargaloka or heaven. She has also entered into all the worlds and all the beings. She it is, who is moving freely in the universe, even like the wind.
Such is the greatness of the Devī.
In spite of all the efforts of the various commentators, the purport of this hymn seems to remain rather elusive.

This is a small Upaniṣad of only 32 mantras, assigned to the Atharvaveda. The mantras are both in prose and in verses. The Devī or God as the Divine Mother is the main theme. Verses included here seem to have been culled out from the Devīsūkta of the Ṛgveda, the Devī-māhātmya of the Mārkaṇḍeya Purāṇa as also the Durgāsūkta of the Mahānārāyaṇa Upaniṣad.

Once all the gods approached the Devī (the Mother Divine) and asked her who she was. In reply she said she was Brahman and that the whole world comprising matter and souls, the five elements, the sacred and the secular sciences, the unborn and the born or in fact, all that exists every where, is herself. It is again she that exists in the form of the Rudras, the Vasus, and the Viśvedevas (various kinds of divine beings inhabiting the worlds). It is she that is helping Viṣṇu, Brahmā and others to sustain themselves. Due to her power and grace only, performers of Vedic sacrifices are able to reap their benefits.

Hearing this, the gods praised her through a beautiful hymn: Obeisance to the auspicious goddess, the origin of the universe and the brilliantly shining deity. We take refuge in her, the goddess Durgā, Sarasvatī the mistress of speech, the consort of Śiva (as Dakṣa’s daughter) and the power of Viṣṇu (Vaiṣṇavī). We bow down to her.
The Upaniṣad then goes on to give the well-known Devīmantras like the pañcadaśākṣarī (ka e ī la hrīm, ha sa ka ha la hrīm, sa ka la hrīm) and the navākṣarī (aiṁ hrīṁ klīṁ cāmuṇḍāyai vicce).
It concludes with a long list of the fruits one gets by the repetition of this Upaniṣad and the mantras therein.
See also DEVĪ and UPANIṢADS.
The word means an abode or a sacred place, a place of pilgrimage.

The four well-known pilgrim centers—Badarīnātha in the north, Jagannātha-purī or Purī in the east, Rāmeśvara in the South and Dvārakā in the west—are specially known as ‘Caturdhāmas’ (Cār Dhām in Hindī) and are coveted places of pilgrimage for all the Hindus.
It is obvious that in the attempt at a visit to these centres, practically all the other important places of pilgrimage all over India too, are covered.
See under each title for details.

Some of the mystics of medieval India made serious attempts to weld the Hindus and the Muslims into one great brother-hood. Prāṇanātha was one of them. He must have lived during the period A. D. 1700-1750. He was an adept in the scriptures of both Hinduism and Islam. He founded a sect called the ‘Dhāmī Sect,’ which was monotheistic in character and liberal in outlook.

Members of this sect call God as ‘dhāman or Home’. Their religious life is founded on moral purity, compassion, service and love of humanity. In their places of worship, both Hindus and Muslims pray together.

The word ‘Veda’ is a general term used to indicate any branch of organised knowledge. The word ‘dhanus’ can mean weapons in general and the bow (and arrow) in particular. Hence ‘Dhanurveda’ means military science or the science of archery. But, the latter sense is more common.
Another name commonly used is ‘Dhanurvidyā’. It is supposed to be subsidiary to Yajurveda.
The science itself is quite ancient and there are references to it even in the Ṛgveda and the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa.
No scientific work known as Dhanurveda is extant now. However, a work called Dhanurveda Saṁhitā available now, is considered to be of a much later date.
The Agnipurāṇa (chapters 249-252) as also the Viṣṇudharmottarapurāṇa (chapters 178-182) contain a lot of information about Dhanurveda.

Weapons of war are generally classified into four groups: Yantramukta (discharged by a contrivance or machine); Pāṇimukta or hastamukta (discharged by hand); Muktāmukta (discharged by hand or used by holding in hand) and amukta (used directly by hand). The examples are arrow, discus, spear and sword respectively.
The dhanurvidyā is concerned exclusively with archery. Use of bows and arrows was quite common even up to the 16th century.

Several varieties of the bows. depending upon the material out of which they are made, are mentioned in certain works like the Arthaśāstra of Kauṭilya (300 B. C. They are: kārmuka (made of palm-tree), kodaṇḍa (of bamboo), druṇa (of sandalwood) and dhanu (of bone or horns). Another division is two fold: śārṅga (made of śṛṅga or horns) and vaṁśa (made of bamboo).
Sometimes these classifications are made keeping the size and the weight in view. One work, the Kodaṇḍamaṇḍana, gives eighteen such varieties.
In our epics and purāṇas, the Śārṅga of Viṣṇu, the Pināka of Śiva, the Kodaṇḍa of Śrī Rāma and the Gāṇḍīva of Arjuna are known as formidable weapons.

Since bows are useless without arrows, a lot of information has been provided by these works on the arrows also. They are prepared out of bamboo or steel. Usually feathers of birds are stuck at the back end. Sometimes poisonous substances would be smeared on the front end. Five kinds of arrows—veṇu, śara, daṇḍaśara, śalāka and nārāca—are known to have existed. When discharged with appropriate mantras, they would get transformed into very powerful missiles called ‘astras’. Some of the famous astras are Brahmāstra, Pāśupatāstra, Nārāyaṇāstra, Āgneyāstra and Sarpāstra.

The bag in which the arrows are kept and tied to one’s back is called ‘tūṇīra’. Some great warriors who had been blessed by the divine powers or deities had ‘akṣaya-tūṇīras,’ a bag of arrows which would never become empty!

For discharging the arrows effectively, several postures like samapāda, maṇḍala, ālīḍha and daṇḍayāta have been prescribed which also have to be learnt from a competent teacher like other aspects of archery.
Though dhanurvidyā was a part of military science, only a brāhmaṇa could be a teacher and even the kṣattriya boys and youth had to learn from him!
Agastya, Paraśurāma and Bhāra-dvāja were the greatest teachers of this science of archery.

Whether the stars and planets in the sky have any effect on our life here and now, has been a fascinating subject of study for several centuries. This has resulted in the evolution of a regular science called Jyautiṣa (also Jyotiṣa) or astrology.

Hindu astrological works divide the zodiac—the annual path of the sun round the earth—into 12 equal parts of 30° each. Each of these is called a ‘rāśi’ (a zodiacal sign). The sun travels through these 12 rāśis in a year. The time taken by the sun to travel through one rāśi is the length of a solar month.

The Dhanus or Dhanūrāśi (also called Taukṣika) is the 9th in the series of 12 and is called Sagittarius (archer) in Greek astrology. It resembles an archer. It comprises the two nakṣatras, Mūlā and Pūrvāṣāḍhā as also the first quarter of Uttarāṣāḍhā.
If time is considered as a personified being (‘kālapuruṣa’) then Dhanūrāśi forms his thighs. Guru or Bṛhaspati (Jupiter) is said to be the lord of Dhanūrāśi.

During a day of 24 hours, as the earth goes round itself once, the sun appears to move through all the 12 rāśīs, though the duration of its being seen in each of the rāśis varies. For the Dhanūrāśi it is 5 ghaṭikās and 30 vighaṭikās i.e, 2 hrs. and 12 mts. These movements and their durations are needed in astrological calculations.
See also RĀŚIS.

head.note: (‘[place sanctified by] the extremity of the bow [of Rāma]’)

description.p: Also spelt as ‘Dhanuṣkoḍi,’ it is an important place of pilgrimage of hoary antiquity, contiguous with the land-mass of the island of Rāmeśvaram. It got its name from the ancient legend that Rāma, at the request of the king Vibhīṣaṇa, destroyed the bridge he had got built by the monkey-army, with the koṭi (= extremity) of his dhanus (= bow), so that there would be no future invasions of Laṅkā, after its being handed over to Vibhīṣaṇa.

This small, but beautiful, temple-town situated at a distance of 20 kms. (12.5 miles) from Rāmeśvaram was almost totally devastated by the fierce cyclone of A. D. 1964. Miraculously, only the temple of Kodaṇḍarāmasvāmi survived. It is standing there in its place even today.
It can be approached by any four-wheeler for a distance of 10 kms. (6.2 miles), the rest of the distance being traversed on foot, since it is laden with sand.
Where the Kodaṇḍarāmasvāmi temple stands at present (8 kms. or 5 miles from Rāmeśvaram), is said to be the place of surrender of Vibhīṣaṇa (younger brother of Rāvaṇa) at the feet of Rāma.
The temple itself—of Draviḍian archi-tecture—contains the images of Rāma, Sītā, Lakṣmaṇa, Hanumān and Vibhīṣaṇa.
At Dhanuṣkoṭi, the Bay of Bengal meets the Indian Ocean. This place is called Ratnākara. Pilgrims take a bath here and perform śrāddhas (obsequial rites).

There are a number of boulders in shallow waters up to Sri Lanka. This—though called ‘Adam’s Bridge’—may be the remnant of the famous bridge which Rāma got built during his invasion of Laṅkā. A recent satellite picture seems to indicate the remnants of a very old bridge of boulders here.
At the edge of the island, there is a range of sand-dunes popularly called ‘floating stones’.
See also RĀMEŚVARAM.
Āyurveda, the science of health and longevity, is very ancient. Dhanvantari is said to be the originator of this science.

Considered as a partial manifestation of Viṣṇu and the physician of the gods, Dhanvantari rose from the ocean of milk at the time of churning it (See SAMUDRA-MATHANA for details.) with the amṛta-kalaśa or pot of ambrosia in his hands.
He was reborn as Divodāsa, the king of Kāśī and composed a standard and basic work on the Āyurveda, comprising eight sections.
Dhanvantari has been mentioned in several works such as Rāmāyaṇa, Harivaṁśa and Bhāgavata.

In course of time, ‘Dhanvantari’ became a title for the very best of physicians, one who had mastered the administration of 300 medicines, the other two titles being bhiṣak (expert in 200 medicines) and vaidya (expert in 100 medicines).
Nineteen works authored by Dhanvantari have found mention in other standard works. Some of them are: Cikitsā-dīpikā, Bālacikitsā, Dhanvantari-nighaṇṭu, Vaidya-bhāskarodaya and Āyurveda-sārāvalī.
The Dhanvantari-nighaṇṭu is considered as the most ancient of these works.

Dhanvantari icons are shown in various postures. A two-armed figure holding the amṛtakalaśa or the pot of ambrosia is the most common. He is shown with four or even six arms, holding the emblems of Viṣṇu like śaṅkha and cakra, apart from the amṛtakalaśa. Sometimes he is shown as bathing himself with the amṛta or nectar, pouring it from the pot.
In one of the more curious forms he is shown holding a leach in one of his hands, suggesting blood-letting or surgery.
See ADHIVĀSA.

Controlling the vagaries of one’s mind and concentrating it on a particular subject has been a life-time’s ambition for many a cultured human being. Patañjali (200 B. C.), the ancient teacher of Yoga, has given us enough material and guidance in this regard in his incomparable work, the Yogasūtras.

Out of the eight standard steps he recommends, dhāraṇā is the sixth. It is the fixing of attention on a definite locus, such as the lotus of the heart (imagining a red, twelve-petalled, lotus in the region of the heart for purposes of meditation), the light in the brain (imagining a brilliant light in the crown of the head), on the tip of the nose or the tongue, or on an external object like the moon or the image of a god and so on.

It is natural for the fickle mind to get distracted and run away from this object of concentration. However, it is to be repeatedly brought back through strenuous efforts until it develops into dhyāna or continuous flow (of the mind) towards the object.
See YOGADARŚANA for details.

Temples have exerted a great influence on the Hindu society for several centuries. Though the ancient temples built of perishable materials like wood, have disappeared due to the ravages of nature and time, those built of stones have survived. One such is the Pañca-keśvara temple—also known as Dorānātha temple—at the village Dhāreśvara, near the town Kumaṭa in the North Kanara district of Karnataka. It is a beautiful temple built in the Cāḷukyan style. There is a nice tank just inside the main compound. There are also two ‘hero-stones’ (Vīragallu, a stone slab or pillar erected in honour of a hero who fought for the people) and a stone edict (A. D. 1083) containing the description of a gift by the local queen.

According to mythological accounts, when Rāvaṇa, the demon king of Laṅkā, was bringing the ātmaliṅga (śivaliṅga) from Kailāsa, it got stuck on the ground at Gokarṇa (in North Kanara, Karnataka). Rāvaṇa could not dislodge the liṅga from the ground but succeeded in pulling out the cloth and thread from it and threw it away. The thread fell at Dhāreśvara and became a liṅga.
There are many beautiful images in the area around Dhāreśvara like those of Narasiṁha and Veṇugopāla. There is a broad road in front of the temple for the rathotsava or temple-car festival.

Our scriptures are full of eulogy for dharma. Who has not heard of the famous quotation from the Mahābhārata, ‘dharma eva hato hanti dharmo rakṣati rakṣitaḥ,’ ‘It is dharma that destroys (us) when destroyed; it is dharma again that protects (us) when protected by (us)’? Or, that famous sentence put in the mouth of Gāndhārī, ‘yato dharmastato jayaḥ,’ ‘Where there is dharma, there victory also is’? Consequently we are advised in poignant terms to accumulate dharma in our lives: ‘anityāni śarīrāṇi vibhavo naiva śāśvataḥ, nityaṁ sannihito mṛtyuḥ kartavyo dharma-saṅgrahaḥ,’ ‘(Our) bodies are short-lived, wealth does not last long, death is constantly knocking at our door; (so) accumulation of dharma is a must.’
What is this ‘dharma’ about which our scriptures and great men have waxed so eloquent throughout our history?

As is the case with many other Sanskrit words, it is rather difficult to give an exact translation of the word dharma. It has been variously translated as ‘religion,’ ‘law,’ ‘duty,’ ‘religious ordinance or rite,’ ‘code of conduct’ and so on. It can mean anyone or more or all of these, depending upon the context. The reason seems to be that the word itself has been used in various senses down the ages and its meaning as also scope has been enlarged. It will be worthwhile to study this development.

It is universally accepted that the word dharma comes from the root ‘dhṛ’ (‘to uphold,’ ‘to support,’ ‘to sustain’). An oftquoted verse from the Mahābhārata says: ‘dhāraṇāt dharmam ityāhuḥ dharmo dhārayate prajāḥ,’ ‘They call it dharma since it upholds; it is dharma that upholds the people (of the world).’

That which upholds this created universe, supports it and sustains it, without which the universe just falls apart, is dharma. Viewed from this standpoint, dharma is none other than God Himself. It is what the Upaniṣads describe as sat or tat, the very essence of one’s being. Whatever conduct or way of life helps us to reveal this fundamental principle in us, can also be called dharma, though in a secondary sense. Hence religious rites, ceremonies and observances, fixed principles of conduct, privileges, duties and obligations of a man depending upon his stage of life and status in society, even rules of law, customs and manners of society—everyone of these can be included under the term dharma.

It may be interesting and instructive to turn our attention to two more ancient words, ṛta and satya, which are closely connected with, if not forms of, dharma. The word ṛta has been used profusely in the Vedas, especially in the Ṛgveda and the Kṛṣṇa Yajurveda. The word in its simplest form, seems to indicate a straight or direct line and so, universal laws of nature, an impersonal order. When extended to the moral world, it denotes a straight conduct based on truth which itself is also dharma. It has also been used in the sense of an inner awareness of what is true, based on the scriptural teachings and the needs of the duties on hand. When this awareness expresses itself through words and actions, it becomes satya. Thus we see that the meanings of all the three words more or less coalesce.
description.h1: DHARMA AS THE FOUNDATION OF THE WORLD
description.p: Since everything in this world appears to have a beginning and an end, with an intervening period of existence, it is but natural for the human intelligence to conceive of a beginning for this creation and to posit an eternal God who existed before creation and from whom creation proceeded. For instance: ‘sadeva somyeda-magra āsīt, ekamevādvitīyam... tadaikṣata bahu syām prajāyeya iti,’ ‘My dear (boy), in the beginning Sat alone existed, the One without a second. It reflected, “May I become many! May I be born!” ’ (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.2.1-3). The ‘many’ that were created, needed a central integrating force, a law or a principle; for, otherwise, chaos would result. This law or principle is dharma. Even this was created by God himself: ‘tat śreyorūpam asṛjata dharmam... tasmāt dharmāt param nāsti... yo vai sa dharmaḥ satyaṁ vai tat,’ ‘He specially created that dharma, of the form of the highest good... therefore there is nothing higher than that... that dharma is verily satya’ (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.4.14). This dharma is the firm foundation upon which the entire universe stands (‘dharmo viśvasya jagataḥ pratiṣṭhā’—Mahānārāyaṇa Upaniṣad 79.7). Obviously here, dharma means righteous behaviour based on truth and knowledge of the unity in spite of the diversity, and capable of bringing the highest good to the whole creation. All other meanings, senses and derivations of this in later literature are corollaries of this central idea.

The word dharma occurs in the Ṛgveda fifty-six times (e.g., 5.63.7; 5.72.2; 9.7.1; 9.25.2; 10.88.1; 10.170.2). But in almost all these places it has been used in the sense of duty or action which contributes to the sustenance of the world (‘jagad-dhāraka-karma’). In the Upaniṣads, this sense becomes more explicit. As a member of the society each one of us has certain duties and obligations which must be discharged by performing the prescribed actions. This sustains the structure of the society. Similarly, in our journey towards perfection we have to pass through several stages of spiritual development and each such stage devolves upon us certain duties or a code of conduct. This helps to sustain our inner development and simultaneously contributes to the well-being of the society also. The seeds of this—which is well-known as varṇa-āśrama-dharma in later literature—are to be found in the Puruṣasūkta and in the earlier Upaniṣads also. For instance, in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka passage already quoted (1.4.14) there is clear reference to dharma as a force that regulates even a kṣattriya, who by virtue of his position as a ruler, could misuse his powers for self-aggrandizement. In the famous passage of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad (2.31.1) the reference to the duties of āśramas is crystal clear: ‘trayo dharmaskandhā yajño’dhyayanaṁ dānamiti prathamaḥ...’ ‘Dharma has three branches. Performance of sacrifice, study of scriptures and giving gifts—this is the first.’

Sometimes, the word dharma has also been used in the Upaniṣads in the sense of apūrva of the Pūrva Mīmāṁsā System (vide Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.5.11—‘ayaṁ dharmaḥ sarveṣām bhūtānām madhu’). This apūrva is nothing but the subtle effect of an action performed as per the directions of the scriptures, which will produce suitable results later.

In rare cases, the word has also been used to denote the ātman or the Self: ‘aṇureṣa dharmaḥ,’ ‘This Self is very subtle’ (Kaṭha Upaniṣad 1.21); ‘evaṁ dharmān pṛthak paśyan,’ ‘thus, considering the selves to be separate’ (i.e., ‘different in different bodies’) (ibid 4.14).
In the Ācāryopadeśa of the Taittirīya Upaniṣad, the word dharma has been clearly used in the sense of obligatory works: ‘dharmaṁ cara,’ ‘Perform your ordained actions’ (1.11.1).

Coming to the Bhagavadgītā, we find the term used in a more definite and clear sense. Dharma is righteousness, the basis of all puruṣārthas (18.34). It is one’s duty ordained by the scriptures as per one’s varṇa and āśrama, by properly performing which, man attains both well-being in this world (abhyudaya) and highest good (niśśreyasa) (vide 4.8; 18.31; 1.40; 7.11 etc.). Sometimes it has also been used as synonymous with ātmajñāna (vide 9.3) or with Karmayoga (2.40).

Let us now turn to the two epics. The very name Rāmāyaṇa has been explained as ‘rāmasya ayanaṁ vṛttaṁ caritam,’ ‘the path trodden by Rāma or the conduct of Rāma.’ Śrī Rāma is the hero here, depicted as the ideal man. His conduct was in perfect conformity with dharma as taught and understood then. To such an extent did he go that he has been described by the sage Vālmīki as ‘rāmo vigrahavān dharmaḥ,’ ‘Rāma is dharma personified’. To speak the truth and to keep up the promise given, under all circumstances—this is the keynote of dharma in the Rāmāyaṇa. No hardship is too great, no sacrifice is too great, when compared to the fulfilment of this dharma. Rāma had the full power and strength to vanquish Daśaratha or anybody else and anoint himself as the king. Yet he did not do it since he was afraid of adharma (Rāmāyaṇa 2.53.26). To please his father and help him keep up his promise to Kaikeyī he was prepared to jump into the fire or consume deadly poison or drown himself in the ocean (ibid., 2.18.28-29). He was ready to give up his life or Sītā or even Lakṣmaṇa but would never break the promise once made (ibid., 3.10.19). He was not at all hesitant to forsake even Sītā in order to set up a very high standard of family life. Since his observance of dharma was dynamic, we can safely surmise that he set up new norms of dharma by accepting the hospitality of Guha and Śabarī, by refusing to have more than one wife and by forcing Vibhīṣaṇa to conduct the last rites of Rāvaṇa.

The Mahābhārata is a veritable encyclopaedia of dharma. It is here that the well-known definition of dharma (‘dhāraṇād dharmamityāhuḥ’) already quoted, occurs. The epic gives a detailed delineation of the varṇāśrama-dharmas. The dhārmic virtues like satya and ahiṁsā are highly extolled. Performance of ordained duties, however small or mean or repulsive they may appear to be, is recommended and eulogised through the stories of Dharmavyādha, Tulādhāra and the simple housewife. The idea of the four puruṣārthas is well-developed, giving worldly life and worldly pursuits a decent place in the scheme of life. Another very interesting feature of this epic is the relaxation of the well-known moral standards and norms in times of distress and emergencies (termed as āpad-dharma) which bespeaks of the robust common sense of the author of the epic.
description.h1: DHARMA IN MĪMĀṀSĀ AND VAIŚEṢIKA SYSTEMS
description.p: It may not be out of place here to refer to two more interpretations of dharma. Jaimini in his Pūrvamīmāṁsā Sūtras (1.1.2) uses the word in a very restricted sense: ‘codanā-lakṣaṇo’rtho dharmaḥ,’ ‘Dharma is the desirable goal or result that is indicated by injunctive (Vedic) passages’. So, dharma means the Vedic ritualistic actions leading to happiness here or hereafter. Kaṇāda on the other hand, gives a more liberal definition: “yato’bhyudaya-niśśreyasa-siddhiḥ sa dharmaḥ,” ‘Dharma is that from which will result both worldly well-being and final beatitude’ (Vaiśeṣika Sūtras 1.2).

However it is in the smṛtis that we come across a very detailed treatment of the subject of dharma in all its intricacies. That is why they have been rightly designated as ‘Dharmaśāstras.’ If dharma is the Cosmic Law which holds together the beings of the world and sustains them, it is very necessary that they be given detailed practical instructions about the way of life which helps them to be always in step and in tune with this dharma. Since human beings, like animals, are gregarious by nature, these instructions naturally have to have a sociological bias. This is exactly what the dharmaśāstras have done when they delineate the varṇa-āśrama-dharmas. True to the tradition of our motherland, all the dharmaśāstras owe their allegiance to the Vedas. In addition, they also accept the words and conduct of saints, sages and seers well-versed in the knowledge of the Vedas, as authoritative in determining dharma (vide Manusmṛti 2.6; Gautama Dharmasūtras 1.1-2; Āpastamba Dharmasūtras 1.1.1.2; Yājñavalkya Smṛti 1.7).

Since man is a rational being and since life-situations are sometimes quite intriguing, the dharmaśāstras wisely recognised the need for reflective morality also, as for instance in Yājñavalkya Smṛti (1.7): ‘śrutiḥ smṛtiḥ sadācāraḥ svasya ca priyamātmanaḥ samyaksaṅkalpajaḥ kāmo dharmamūlam idaṁ smṛtam,’ ‘The Vedas, smṛtis, usages of good men, what is agreeable to one’s self and desire born of deliberation—these are traditionally recognised as the source of dharma’.

Hinduism considers man’s life as a long journey towards perfection. In this journey, natural desires and inclinations of man to possess and enjoy the good things of life cannot be overlooked. Hence the dharmaśāstras provide for these in their scheme of life while amplifying the theory of the puruṣārthas. Great care has been taken to give detailed rules and regulations in the acquisition of artha (wealth) and kāma (enjoyment of fleshly desires) within the framework of dharma. However, following in the footsteps of the Jñānakāṇḍa (section that deals with spiritual wisdom) of the Vedas, they always stress the importance of trying for mokṣa or liberation as the summum bonum of life (vide Manusmṛti 12.116 to 125).

No society under the sun is absolutely homogeneous. Differences do exist. Even the five fingers of our own hand exhibit this principle. The dharmaśāstras recognised this natural division, called it God-made and gave detailed instructions regarding the duties and responsibilities of various groups or varṇas of society towards one another in their group and towards other groups. Stressing that these divisions were evolved due to guṇa (quality) and karma (vocation), they have also provided for stringent punishments for derelictions of duty and rewards for sincere performance. Relaxations of these rules have however been provided for, in times of distress.

While dealing with the duties of a king, the dharmaśāstras have given us a fairly well-developed form of Indian Jurisprudence. Fairness and justice occupy the central place in all these rules (vide Manusmṛti, chapters 8 & 9).
